description:
Overdue drafted review:

What place has a hot steaming nai wong bao at night? 

HERE!!! I was so happy. And my friend had never had one either.

The shell was HUGE, the biggest I've seen. The taste was alright. Not the best, but the shabby.

But the most important part was the custard filling. 

And it was the first time my friend saw the excitement on my face for usually I'm just unphased. But yeah we went last August.
author: Lilian L.

description:
CASH only, this is the oldest bakery in Chinatown. 

Realized I had not tried the eggtarts here so I made a stop recently. Egg tarts are $1.75 a pop.


How were they? 
The crust was very tough and not very good so it didn't do well in my egg tart rankings below.

If you like my review...give my profile a follow. Why "follow" someone? B/c then their reviews tier to the top when you pull up a business.  Comes in very handy!
I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank places in the SF Bay Area that sell Egg Tart...yes Egg Tart. Obviously given the nature of the food most of these places are in SF or Oakland Chinatown. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba,Tacos, Ice Cream,  Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?).  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 
1 Mr.Bread
2 Golden Gate Bakery
3 Yummy Bakery 
4 New Hollywood Bakery
5 The AA Bakery & Café
6 Bake Cheese Tart
7 Ruby King Bakery
8 Napolean Super Bakery
9 Café Honolulu
10 Sheng Kee Bakery 
11 Wonder Food Bakery 
12 Eastern Bakery
13 Sum Yee Pastry
14 Grand Mission Donuts and Bakery
author: Rod M.

description:
A cash only tourist bakery that sells other things. So passed by here several times when coming back from Chinatown walking. This is the closes bakery to Market St.  

A family member gets cakes here once in a while. I came here finally to check it out myself. The bakery was completely empty when I came on a Tuesday afternoon. 

All I can see visible were the cakes a sweet stuff. When I was about to leave the boss/ manager came out in a very loud voice asking what I had wanted then opened up a warm often where they had baked and steamed items mixed together. 

So I got a few buns so I wouldn't be walking out empty handed and something to snack on. The cashier wouldn't take my money and that boss/ manager took it and gave me back the change. When I arrived back I noticed the quarter was different in some way, it was a Piso. This was the only place I stopped for lunch, so only place I got change from.
author: M C.

description: This bakery has fantastic customer service and is so helpful. My aunt loved the pork bun.
author: Ali G.

description:
This is my 2nd time shopped there. I couldn't resist the look of that sticky rice wrapped in bamboo leaves. Air was stuffy inside so I sat on bench outside of the bakery and enjoyed my food and street activities.
I also bought two sets of small moon cakes which were inexpensive and fresh. One set for my friend living in Fremont and the other, for myself.
author: Trudy L.

description: Take note it's cash only. But the prices are cheap that if you have a few dollars laying around you can walk out with something. I forget which bread I ordered but I wasn't impressed with it. It had a stale crumbly texture. The sweet lady recommended the pork bun which I am glad I got. The bun is warm and soft with a savory and tender pork filling. However there was a slight sour flavor. I couldn't tell if it was intentional or spoiled.
author: Korrie K.

description:
Don't be confused what to get.

This review is only for two things:
1. Try the coffee crunch cake. 
2. Try the Tikoy if you're there around the Lunar New Year. Buy it...bring home...slice and pan fry. mmm!  Legit. 

Friendly ladies working the store. 
Cash only.
author: Margaret W.

description:
CASH ONLY!

Great little shop to grab a bite and enjoy traditional Chinese pastries. The pork buns were amazing and as someone who enjoys savory pastries more than sweet desserts, these pork buns were a great little "pick me up" while walking the streets of Chinatown during their annual Chinese New Year's Parade
author: Aaron H.

description:
This place is truly no-frills. Service is quick - you're going to be better off if you know what you want in advance. I didn't - and I did feel under pressure to order quickly. 
Despite my rush, I was pretty pleased. I ordered 5 pastries for $8.50 - quite reasonable. Not the cheapest in the area but definitely not over priced. I ended up with two coconut filled, two lotus and one red bean pastries and they were all delightful. I want to say the coconut was stand-out but truthfully I enjoyed them all. They were authentic, flakey and sweet and lasted really well until the next day. 
It's cash only - so be wary of this - because the staff do seem to get frustrated when they're waiting around - but all in all, definitely worth it!
author: Poppy C.

description:
This place is so amazing. It's definitely worth the uphill walk from the Montgomery Muni Station. It has some tables and seats in the back if you want to break and enjoy your bread. It is indeed CASH ONLY and not too many drinks. The best bread, in my opinion, are the coconut buns. If you arrive between 10am to 1pm, they are freshly made and come out just right and very warm! 

Also, as a bonus, walk outside to Commercial Street and check out the beautiful Bruce Lee mural!
author: Christian M.

description:
Walking around Chinatown, we came across Eastern Bakery.

They have a variety of baked goods, all looked delicious and fresh. Some seating is available in the back. We enjoyed their egg tarts and pork buns. I love that their pork buns are filled to the max with meaty goodness and just a thin layer of bread. It had a nice consistency and flavor was on point. Prices are very reasonable as well. The cashier was friendly and quick. She wrapped our goodies neatly and we were in and out in no time.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
The only bakery we found my mom's "wife" cake at! They were a little pricey but these are pretty big. My mom calls them a cookie but honestly it's way to big to be called a cookie. It's filled with a soft melon flavored filling. With a flakey outside crust. Even my BF liked these cookies/cake! We went back the bakery twice during our time here in SF. They had moon cakes for sale way cheaper than the other bakeries we saw. 

The ladies behind the counter were really pushy but honestly it's what I'm use to. These Chinese ladies don't mess around when it comes to making a sale. It helped I was able to speak Cantonese. But man they drive a hard bargain. Defiantly one the more reasonably priced bakeries here. I didn't try the moon cakes here but they did look really fresh and good.
author: Karen H.

description: Cute little authentic Chinese bakery in the midst of Chinatown. Two elderly ladies ran it and were very friendly and accommodating. The prices were so cheap and very worth! We got a red bean moon cake, sponge cake, and egg tart. The flavors all tasted very homemade. Sponge cake was a little dry and not full of flavor, the egg tart was good and bouncy tasting, and the moon cake was delicious! It had the right consistency and taste. We only spent $5 for all pastries. There was even sitting inside! And a bathroom, although it is $2 if you don't buy anything.
author: Lilan N.

description:
I have been coming here since I was a kid!

They have the best strawberry champagne cake. Be careful because a whole sheet of it is WAY BIGGER THAN USUAL! You will have left over cake forever! Half sheet should be perf for a regular sized bday party. A full sheet would be more for a wedding.

I always get a dozen steamed pork buns (the baked ones are also good) & a dozen Chinese black bean cakes which are actually red bean hopia (similar Filipino dessert).

Prices are fine but CASH ONLY! There's a B of A across the Street anyway. 

The workers are friendly and helpful!
author: Jazmine S.

description: This place is a staple for me every time I come to Chinatown.  I love coconut buns and this place always has them hot and fresh!! They have never let me down.  They also have many other goodies and it's easy to get in and out with some great goodies. The ladies have always been helpful and let me know about some other little goodies I might wanna try....they are good on the up-sell. Come in and check them out, you will be happy you did.
author: Heidi H.

description:
If there was one thing I wanted to get upon my visit to San Francisco, it was to get egg tarts. Egg tarts are my absolute favorite Chinese pastry

Now I will admit I was aiming to go to Golden Gate Bakery to get my egg tart fix but alas they were closed. I also was a bit far from Good Mong Kok Bakery. I thought my quest to get egg tarts were gone until I spotted Eastern Bakery! Yes, I found Eastern Bakery unplanned and it was a pleasant surprise to find out that it is the oldest Chinese bakery in San Francisco's Chinatown. It looked like it had a bit of a following too and even former president Bill Clinton had visited here before.

They had several Chinese pastries such as moon cake, sesame balls and my favorite egg tarts! I saw both the egg tarts and sesame balls had a special of 4 for $5. I asked if I could do a mix and match of the egg tarts and sesame balls but alas the guy at the counter smiled at me and said no. I could not thus partake in the deal. I ended up purchasing two egg tarts and two sesame balls.

The first thing I noticed were the sesame balls were gigantic in size! They're also best eaten while warm because it still has the right amount of chewiness. The sesame balls here were actually pretty good and well worth trying.

Next up were the egg tarts. The egg tarts here were not as large in size. The good thing however was the egg filling itself was quite generous. I enjoyed the soft filling and it simply melted in my mouth. As for the crust, it was just alright. It was crisp but didn't quite have the best buttery, flaky crust I've had elsewhere. Nevertheless they were still good!

Eastern Bakery was not on original places to try while in Chinatown but I am glad that I found it on accident! I'm thankful to have found this place and got my egg tart fix as well as some sesame balls.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Parking is horrific. Find a nearby garage or have someone else drop you off and pick you up.
Little hole in the wall bakery with amazing treats.
If you are Oriental, the moon cakes are amazing.
Everyone is a fan of the pork buns.
They excel at their baked goods: coffee crunch cake, lemon tarts, etc, etc.
Have been going there for over 30 years and have never been disappointed.
author: Teresa W.

description:
Stopped in here on a whim while wondering around Chinatown. So glad I did! I got a pork bun ($1.50) and eyed all the desserts. Ended up chatting with a guy who got a chocolate and coconut something or other and he said it was really good.

Pork bun was perfection! If I weren't on my way to the airport I would have made a point of coming back and getting more.
author: Mandy M.

description:
Eastern is really everything a bakery should be: fast, friendly, delicious, and inexpensive! I would frequent this place if I lived closer. 

It was crowded during Lunar New Year festivities, but the line moved super quickly. I almost wished it had moved a little slower so I could have more time to ponder the many offerings before ordering. Note that the setup is a little funky and there are more offerings to the right of the register, which we almost missed before ordering.

Despite picking our pastries more or less on the spot, everything we ordered was delicious. The butterfly cookie was buttery and flaky, the cream bun coconutty and light. We had these plus some sponge cake and moon cakes and everything came out to around $8-9 dollars, so pricing is great!

I love the idea of neighborhood businesses, so it made me happy watching the people behind the counter take the time to chat with some of their customers. Everyone was warm and friendly despite working quickly.

Cash only, which is the only bummer about this place. It's worth a quick trip to the ATM though!
author: Audrey S.

description:
Eastern Bakery has been a fixture on Grant catering to tourists visiting SF Chinatown from times immemorial. I have passed by many times but have always consciously avoided it, but you can't resist the itch for ever so finally a couple of days ago I gave in and gave it a try. Like every other bakery in Chinatown it is pretty tiny.

I decided to get a bunch of items to give me a wide understating of what they had to offer. I got an egg tart, pineapple bun, puff pastry and a coconut filled cake. Everything was pretty cheap and my total was under $10 which made the lady helping me kind of sad. Or maybe that was the expression that she had on all the time, I just noticed it while paying. Anyway, suffice it to say that the interaction was not a nice warm experience.

Let's come to the food. Let's start with the good. The pineapple bun was borderline good. It would have been great if it was fresh but this tasted about a day old. The average was the egg tart. It did not have the flaky, crunchy crust that Golden Gate's egg tarts are famous for. In the bad category was the puff pastry. Maybe it is a matter of personal taste; I just did not like it. The coconut filled cake was in the terrible category. Even though it was neatly wrapped in plastic, it tasted like it was weeks old. There was no way that I could eat this. Overall there are definitely better bakeries than Eastern in Chinatown. I'll leave this for the tourists and move on.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Definite must for traditional Chinese baked goods. Friendly and smiley counter service. The owner says this is the oldest bakery in Chinatown (94 years old). All goods are freshly made on the premises. They have seating on premises to enjoy the goodies with beverages.
We had the lotus bean moon cake, shrimp chips, and coffee. Everything was the best of the best. 
Get out of the comfort zone and enjoy real traditional Chinese baked goods. You will love this place.
author: Joe L.

description:
CASH ONLY, but worth the hassle. 

BBQ pork buns are delicious. 

Best cocktail buns I've had. 

Heard everyone goes here for their coffee crunch cake. I will definitely check it out the next time I come. 

The only downside I would say is parking is hard to find and the last time I went the lady's math was off from what was posted on the board. It was only about $.30 so I didn't worry about it too much.
author: Janice A.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a toddler for their Chinese donuts. I remember always devouring those warm, golden, sesame coated rice spheres. Nothing hit the spot better on an overcast SF day. I came back today after probably almost a decade and got to experience the place through more mature eyes and man, is this place full of clutter. There is no way this place is up to code. If there was an earthquake you'd for sure get toppled by several boxes full of I don't even know what. The workers touch the pastries with their bare hands and don't use gloves. There's crap everywhere. The condiment bar isn't stocked. They aren't warm or welcoming. The Chinese donuts we ordered were cold and had probably been out a few hours. 
However; I am still giving this three stars because 1. The older man who started taking orders while we were leaving was super nice and helpful. 2. I friggin loved this place when I was a kid and the donuts came out nice and fresh. And 3. The donuts despite being cold were still pretty bomb greasy golden treats to enjoy on an overcast SF Tuesday afternoon. You can't beat the prices and if you're willing to get what you pay for then this will still be a nice place to come stop for some donuts in the end.
author: Graesyn H.

description:
As does the rest of China Town, this bakery was.like the rest in looks. I had purchased baked BBQ pork buns (6) and red bean cakes (3). Not the cleanest or organized I can compare to in similar bakeries I go to in SoCal. The baked pork buns were in a warmer across from the case, the employee had come from behind the bakery display case to this warmer. The warmer door was not closed tight. I can only imagine what may fly in there, from insects to dirt.

There's a few tables in the back to enjoy the pastries.

The food was priced OK. But my friend had said this place is really good. $13.45 later, the pork buns was just OK. It was pretty meaty, but it wasn't the red BBQ pork flavor I was expecting. It was above room temperature, but would have loved to have had it a little warmer.

The red bean cake was OK too. I had one as a snack when I arrived at my airport terminal.

It was not crowded here at all.  The employees were friendly. This is a cash only place, so bring cash if you intend to purchase here.
author: Antonio L.

description:
They have cheap buns for about $1.50 per bun. There's a sign of all the different flavors and I had the pork bun which was available in steamed and baked varieties (I got it baked). Overall it was okay, it's not exactly amazing food, but I didn't really enter the shop for amazing food. 

It's cheap, the people there are mostly friendly, and it's pretty tasty for a quick bite. They are cash only though, so make sure you hit the ATM before hand!
author: Tyler T.

description:
Service was extremely friendly! The man at the counter greeted us immediately and began selling his goods as soon as we walked in! I appreciated his hustle and charisma!

We got three sesame balls filled with red bean paste, an egg tart and rice flour pancake. Sesame balls were $1.25 each, and I believe the egg tarts were the same price.

The sesame balls were huge and almost the size of my head! (Kid you not) we got them fresh as they were warm and steaming when we took a bite. I liked it!

The rice flour pancake was not good and tasted extremely plain. I don't recommend getting it--they had fresh buns of all sorts which I didn't get but they looked tasty! Egg tarts were solid but not the best we've ever had. Recommend going to Gooden gate bakery for that :) 

There's seating in the bakery and a bathroom as well. Great place for a cheap Chinese treat!!
author: Alyssa W.

description:
CASH ONLY!

The Food 
I ordered the egg tart and steamed pork buns. They were both alright, I have tasted something better. 

Atmosphere
The place is small and it's meant​ to be that way i guess

Service
Service was standard. CASH ONLY, so be prepared.

Overall Experience
I'm not sure if i'll be going back but if I happened to be near the place and craving for some pork buns or egg tart. I would definitely stop by! ​
author: Cindy W.

description: I usually don't even like sesame balls, but Eastern Bakery does them right. Each one is the size of a small cannon ball (over three inches in diameter) and only cost $1.25. That's pretty cheap for a giant stand-alone dessert. I've gone several times and each time they were served warm, slightly crispy on the outside, and gluey/gummy on the inside with a thick semi-sweet red bean paste filling. That description may sound weird if you've never had one, but as long as you like sesame and red bean paste, you will love these.
author: Abdullah A.

description:
Great joint for cheap, authentic Chinese baked goods.  Too bad they don't have coconut tarts :( Egg tarts are solid and WAYYY cheaper than certain hyped up bakery down the block (cough cough)
But they take card.... well unless you meet grumpy grandma who insists on cash. So take one star off due to the inconsistency :(
author: Chloe Z.

description: Classic Chinese bakery located in the heart of Chinatown.  This place looks old and run down and that is why the food is so good.  They spend no time cleaning up but they sure do put out some tasty baked goods and savory stuff.  My personal favorite is the BBQ pork bun.  They also have a Chinese burrito which is like something I've never had.  All of the sweet treats are amazing and so many to choose from.  Best part is you can spend 3 dollars and be full for the day.  If you need a quick snack while in Chinatown this is your place.
author: Andrew S.

description: My son and I are big egg custard tart fans.  We went to two bakeries and did side-by-side comparison of egg custard tarts from Eastern Bakery vs another nearby bakery. Eastern Bakery tarts had flaky, buttery crust. Custard was yolky and flavorful, not too sweet and over all very balanced. The other bakery had tarts that looked prettier and larger with a slightly better texture of the custard, but lacked the flavor of the ones from Eastern bakery.  I wish I had time to go to all of the  bakeries in Chinatown but maybe next time...
author: Roxanne H.

description:
$40 later and there is no regrets so far. 
We asked the guy what was good and he recommended a coconut and cream filled bread that was still warm. I think that is my favorite dessert/bakery now in China town.
We had a bunch of other baked goods and all were delicious. 
Make sure to also take some baked pork buns! They keep them warm.
author: Leonela L.

description:
The small slice of coffee crunch cake slice is $5.  Ouch

But it tastes great


I also bought a custard tart but somehow it wasn't the one I wanted and they seemed a bit confused. It was good tho, just not what I ordered
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Food 2/5. Service 3/5. Ambiance 3/5. 

There is tons of Chinese bakeries in Chinatown. This place is no different than the others. It's a little dingy with boxes everywhere with a few Chinese people who speak minimal English. The cases are filled with cheap Chinese pastries ranging from cream buns, pineapple bun, to sesame balls. Any of the pastries were well under $1.50.

I myself got the custard tart and usually I love custard tarts. But this was very mediocre. The custard felt too dense and wasn't sweet enough. The pastries that surrounded the custard wasn't as flaky and it was tougher than usual. 

Overall, for a Chinese bakery its good for what it is. 

Tips - Bring cash its cash only! If you are to get something try the sesame ball! 

Pros - Everything is super cheap under $1.50.

Cons - There are better places to in Chinatown, but convenient and average if you want a pastry.
author: Brian N.

description:
Tried to visit last night at 8:20pm, but was closed (business hours on the storefront now say until 7:30pm).

So this morning I stopped in for a custard tart. Cash only. I was helped quickly. Very delicious fresh and flaky crust, filling was not too sweet and dense but fluffy. Great mid-morning treat!
author: Maya B.

description: I'm so glad this place is still here. Best coffee crunch cake ever. They still have the butterflies and cow ear cookies.  Sach kei ma is crunchy and soft, and you can still get the nutty gai jie bang (when they haven't sold out). When I go to The City I have to stop here.
author: Gingerlily L.

description:
My coworker told me a story that when he was 3 he use to come by here all the time to get the pineapple bun and black bean cake. He's almost 40 now so this bakery must have been doing something right if they've lasted this long.

I got both items like he suggested and the pineapple is indeed delicious. I really liked this style of bread because it's much less sweet than an American made one. As for the black bean cake, it was a bit dry for me. I think I would have preferred to get a red bean one because I'm sure it's more moist but nonetheless, both were good but not the best thing I've ever eaten. The pastries were relatively inexpensive. Pineapple bun was .95 cents and the black bean was $1.95. If I ever drove by the area I would definitely go in and grab a pasty.
author: Andrew T.

description: I love the egg tart here, it's not too sweet as some others. Also nice to know this is one of the oldest bakery in Chinatown
author: Maria L.

description:
Came back to grab a quick bite for lunch. Only came to try out their Chinese "tamales" (hubby was confused when I called them that then laughed when I explained what they really were). Yes, they're actually labeled as "tamales".

$3.35 for the savory ones - peanut or mung bean with pork, salty egg, chinese sausage. And they're pretty generous with their filling. I grew up on Taiwanese style zongzi with shitake and a brown "sauce" that seeps into the rice so though these were good they aren't my preference. Not enough savory oomph for me. 

You can eat in but then you'll pay an additional 29¢ tax. There are about 4-6 tables in the back that seat less than 20. It's pretty warm inside though.

The women who work here don't speak Mandarin so just ask for things as they are labeled and not what they're called in Mandarin because they won't understand.
author: Jean K.

description: Best bakery in town!!! Love the cocktail buns and the bbq pork bun!! Tried others in China town but not as good as the ones from eastern Bakery. This place is the best!! Been coming here for a few years now!! Can't wait to go back!
author: Garrett F.

description:
Overpriced tourist trap. Wow.
$3 for a large cookie that costs $1 in the sunset neighborhood. 
$5.75 for a moon cake that tastes mediocre.

Actually it tastesd too sweet and I ended up leaving it for others...
author: George K.

description:
You can tell this bakery has been here for awhile. 

The banh baos are delicious! I tried the bbq pork and Chinese sausage.

Just be careful when you go on, I almost tripped on cases of water on the floor as I backed up to move so the lady can bring some supplies in. Almost knocked down a shelf of smackles! Oh man, not the smackles.

I'll be coming back for some more banh baos. I only hope they declutter the front. (And maybe the back of the counter too, there's a lot of papers and things stuffed in the shelves)

Enjoy!
author: Teena N.

description: I thought this place was eh. I got the pork bun (not great), chicken bun (better but not great), and the coconut bread was actually pretty good. I would not go back, but the services was pretty helpful.
author: Tina L.

description: The moon cakes are amazing there more expensive at this bakery than others but they taste extremely fresh there around 5 to 6 dollars each for the larger ones there's a large selection of other pastries to really good
author: Shannon S.

description: This place was a true hole-in-the-wall place that I never thought I would stumble upon while visiting San Francisco. The place has been open since before the first World War I and this is the only place (that I know of) that serves fresh moon-cakes all year round. It's cash only but 100% worth it.
author: Phi N.

description:
One of our talents was sweet enough to bring some goodies to work from Eastern Bakery on Friday, October 28th. Since I had just had lunch, I thought, this would be the perfect dessert!

We had a box of Dan Tats (egg custard tarts) and some mini Mooncakes. I had to have one of each! The dan tats were creamy yet firm and the crust, super buttery and flaky! So good! My only critique would be, they were a touch too sweet. But my sweet tooth didn't mind it much. I can only eat so much mooncake since it's so dense. These were a good size. The one I had was filled with lotus seed paste with no egg. I'm not a huge fan of the ones with egg, so I was happy. The texture and sweetness level were good as well.

I adore dan tats, so I'm glad I was finally able to try Eastern Bakery!
author: Elena N.

description: My family has been coming in here for YEARS for pineapple buns and pork buns - always phenomenal and a must go to in San Francisco. We love it!
author: Courtney F.

description: This is a small bakery located in Chinatown.  While they claim that the moon cakes are one of their star items, I found them to be very dry and I definitely have had much better.  However, the sesame balls and the steamed custard buns were delicious. It is cash only so be sure to stop at the ATM prior to visiting.
author: Melanie B.

description:
The service was speedy given our time crunch (where we parked was ending in a few minutes). Prices also seem good too. 

The highlights: the egg tart was the best I've had ever, with a flaky and buttery crust and a caramelized sweeten egg filling. The sesame balls were also large in size, and a good chewy consistency with good amount of red bean paste. 

The Ok: the pork buns were so-so, the meat inside was mostly squishy in texture, without any noticeable chunks of meat. The bun outside though was a good texture with a hint of sweetness, without being overly sweet. 

Not as great: I also wasn't a fan of the buttercream bun, I didnt realize it had coconut outside, but other than that, the cream was greasy feeling and the breading was a bit more stale in texture.
author: Evan H.

description:
Ordered 2 Pork Steam buns, 3 coconut buns and 1 small lotus moon cake and came out to almost $9. 
Not very impressed to the quality of food. The pork steam bun dough was on a tough side and the ccocnut bread filling was too sweet. The sugar wasnt mixed well with the coconut flakes and it was very doughy. The lotus mooncake was dry too.
author: Kath S.

description: When my fatass can't fit into my clothes anymore, it will 100000% be because of the Eastern Bakery. The red bean mooncakes, buttercream buns and custard pies are delicious and authentic. Everything is ridiculously cheap. I'll be returning again and again.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Their coffee crunch cake is reason enough for me to drive all the way to Chinatown! Delicious, moist cake balanced with nice coffee crunch on the exterior. Growing up, coffee crunch cakes and princess cakes were special treats for family birthdays. Now, I love sharing it with my friends :)

Note: If you add a message on top, the coffee crunch is only on the side. So if you like lots of coffee crunch, get it without any writing! I just added a "Happy Birthday" plastic cake decoration and some candles to make it just as cute without sacrificing the crunch and flavor.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Old school bakery. I was at 41 Ross when I learned that Eastern Bakery shares ownership with GGB down the street... so I wish they carried the same egg tarts. Anyways, I only order three things from Eastern Bakery: mooncakes, pineapple buns, and bai tang gao (white sugar sponge cake...? bad translation but I don't have a better one). 

Yearly mooncakes are a must here. They are simply the best. Nothing else to be said here. Skin, fillings, everything is on point.

I really come here more regularly for their pineapple buns which are fantastic. Nice flaky top and sweet but chewy interior. 

I really only get the bai tang gao when I come here and the pineapple buns are sold out. They're okay. Nothing stand out but tastes good as well.

Eastern Bakery is literally the OG bakery. Prices are still cheap. I love it.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Tried the baked bbq buns. They were cold and the meat was spoiled (sour). Ewwww  go further into Chinatown (away from Gate) and there are much busier bakeries with hot pastries.
author: Oh Trust M E.

description: Mmm.  My favorite Chinese dessert is gin doi and theirs was delicious.  It is mochi filled with sweet black bean paste, rolled in sesame seeds, and fried crisp.  I did not care for their steamed rice cake which was too sour.  No frills here just straight up Chinese treats.
author: Shevon R.

description: I'm no expert on Chinese bakery items but I wandered in right before closing and got a fresh warm coconut bun and a cream bun. Yummmmmm! I'll be back
author: Piper W.

description: The bread part of both the steamed and baked BBQ pork buns are out of this world; the filling itself is decent. The pineapple buns are phenomenal; crispy topping with soft, buttery, chewy bread. Cocktail bun is fantastic as well. Egg tarts are just ok. Service is good and quick.
author: Vincent C.

description: I've come here a couple times, tried their veggie steamed bun (a little salty, but good filling), baked pork bun (not red as people have commented, but tastes fine), egg tart (pretty good). The prices are comparable to other places, but they almost never have a line and are much closer to my work. For that reason, I'm more inclined to come here than some of the more famous, better quality places in the greater Chinatown neighborhood. I think for a quick dim sum snack, this place hits the spot just fine.
author: Ari F.

description:
You need to give this place a try.

TIME: I reached around 7:00 pm on Thursday and they were out of egg tarts, pineapple cream bun.
FOOD: I tried the coconut cream bun and the eclair; they were very fresh and flavorful. I recommend both of these.
PRICE: I found the price reasonable against the quality and quality of food. The only thing I didn't like was to pay extra when you use your card. So I paid in cash. (approximately $4)
STAFF: Friendly and helping.
author: Manjari R.

description:
This bakery is historic in SF for being the oldest, having opened way back in 1924. It also has some history with President Bill Clinton having come to visit it.

The place does get quite a bit of business with people coming in to try their bakery goods. I find everything to be just decent, with the mooncakes being the more interesting and special good to get here. It's easy to tell this place is getting a bit old as the establishments comes off as being a bit dirty and not so clean. The workers here are very friendly though comparative to other bakeries within Chinatown.

The one thing I know this place for is their Coffee Crunch Cake. It's not "out of this world" amazing, but it's pretty stinking good. It has a nice level of sweetness and mild coffee creme flavor within the cake with layers of soft sponge. The distinguishing feature of the cake are the little crumbles of coffee flavored candy bits surrounding the diameter of the cake. They add a nice sugary crunch to the cake that makes it a family favorite.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Randomly passed by, my daughter got a mooncake since it was Mooncake festival holiday. We are from NYC and was on US 1 and NPs Road trip in 2016. San Francisco was one of stops. Anyway, mooncake tasted fabulous which made me regret even today I should get more. 
Now, one of my hiking friends in San Francisco. Since I need store address to send her over if she by a chance is strolling around in that area tomorrow, I looked internet and found the store. 
Yeah, a review from me. I miss that taste even though the moon cake costs more money. I will get it whenever I can.
author: Ron Z.

description:
This place is crowded, so much wonderful Chinese pastry offerings! I'm more focused on the bao and they don't disappoint!
From pork, coconut, sweet beans, sausage etc., this would be your go to place!

There's also chocolates and other pastries to enjoy. Seating is available in the back but it's definitely a place where the service is good and the bao is delicious!
:)
author: Ryo Hanalei Z.

description:
If you have any emotional connection with Chinatown San Francisco, its a 5 star... 
But I will add "Authentic Experience" doesn't always translate to everyone... and thats what I'm reading between the lines in some of the more negative reviews. Its less "tourist Trap" than I'm seeing posted here, and more so that this place harkens back to O.G. Chinatown SF, which is more homestyle, cantonese, than some of the glitzier foodie fav, or Taiwanese style places you find in say Orange County.

the "Coffee Crunch Cake" is probably their claim to fame, and my favorite.  Coffee whipped in to real whip Cream frosting.  the layered Cake is based on Chinese Sponge cake which has a great lightness and bounce to it.  topped with a "Coffee-Toffee" candy thats been crushed.  Truly a mix of Chinese and American influences. 

BBQ Pork buns are also a favorite and reasonably priced.  
Moon Cakes are also a specialty here.  
I also love getting a bag of Shrimp Chips that sting a little as they melt on my tongue. It takes me back... 

But Experience is the thing.  this is like the Chinatown SF equivalent of the small town family Diner.
author: Andy L.

description: This brings me back to my childhood to receive the famous " cow ear cookies." They are made the best and only cow ear cookies!!! Their BBQ pork buns off the chain. They are friendly and easy to speak with to get the orders done right. They speak enough English too but I got to practice my Cantonese which I need to do. Please stop by here if you're in the area of cow ear cookies. If not anything else the broken cookies are $1!
author: Jaci Y.

description: Wife cake was a bit too sweet for my taste. There are other bakeries around that I wouldn't rush back here. Good Mong Kok was one of our favorites. Just saying.
author: Clarence E.

description:
On the day of the Lunar New Year parade, I ventured into Chinatown to seek out mooncakes at Eastern bakery per a friend's friend's recommendation. It was crazy town in there, with the line winding around inside the entire store and little room to wiggle. 

With the wait time in line, I was able to narrow down "I want one of everything to try" to 3 mini red bean moon cakes, 3 mini lotus moon cakes, one cocktail bun, 3 "crispitos", one steamed pork bun, and one baked pork bun. 

The mini mooncakes are the perfect size for you to treat yourself to one and to tell your friend that it's too small to share and they should get their own. They were delightfully smooth and lightly sweet. The next day however, they have a stale oily type taste, so I would recommend eating them the day of purchase. 
The cocktail bun is standard soft bread with coconut in it. It could have used more coconut. 
Crispitos are small coconut, sesame, and peanut filled pastries that are fried. It was too fried for me, but my boyfriend enjoyed them, as they were reminiscent of the type his granny used to make. 
The pork buns had a good meat to bread ratio, but the exteriors were not as fluffy as I would have liked, a la Good Mong Kok. 

Pineapple buns were sold out and I was disappointed. All in all, would revisit for pineapple buns during a less festive/crowded season. Maybe another mooncake too.
author: Shirley V.

description: This is a very authentic Chinese bakery. A husband and wife own the bakery and the pastries are made fresh daily. I grabbed some pound cake to go and it was indescribable. Give them a chance if you're in town.
author: Becky G.

description:
OLD DIM SUM & RUDE MANAGEMENT

Not to mention this place is disgustingly dirty. Every sign is faded, dust on every surface, and floors are very sticky. I'll keep this review short because it's not even worth me using more time to discuss why I feel a better business should replace this establishment as soon as possible.

Do yourself a favor and head to another bakery in Chinatown with fresh dim sum and less of a chance of food poisoning.
author: Kay B.

description:
I've loved coming to this bakery for years! I just recently paid attention to the name (we've always found it by looking for the picture of Bill Clinton in the window).

The only thing I ever get here are their BBQ pork buns which are AMAZING. I'm only giving them 4 stars because its a little run down inside and not too clean... My parents spotted some cockroaches the last time they visited. I've never seen any, but maybe ignorance is bliss?

I'd still recommend
author: Kelsey H.

description:
Crazy coffee crunch cake.

A friend of ours was celebrating her birthday up in Tahoe, and her boyfriend asked me to pick up an Asian birthday cake, preferably coffee-flavored. The first thought was tiramisu, but Yelp also pointed me to coffee crunch cakes from Yasukochi's Sweet Stop and Eastern Bakery. Looking over reviews, Yasukochi's was the favorite in terms of quality, but Eastern was preferred for quantity. With an entire cabin to feed, we opted for the latter.

And talk about quantity. An 8" cake serves 8 people for $20.10, 10" for $30.10, 12" serves 15-19 for $40.10, and a half sheet is $55. If you want writing on the top of the cake, you have to forego some coffee crunch toppings. We called in the glorious 12" cake to pick up the following afternoon. Upon opening the bright pink lid, we found a humongous coffee crunch-laden cake that fed our crew's sweet teeth for the entire weekend with a bowl of leftovers for the ride home.

In terms of taste, it's good but not great. The coffee crunch is very sticky and slightly saccharine. Fortunately, the sponge cake and fluffy whipped cream are not sickeningly sweet, so a good number of us ended up scraping off the coffee crunch bits. Thinking back on it, I would have sacrificed that excess of coffee crunch bits in order to have birthday writing on the cake.

Coffee crunch cake sans a bit of crunch = perfect.
author: Adele F.

description:
I love Eastern Bakery, super quick, easy, yummy, and cheap!!!!

My roommate found out about this place bc she works nearby. Now I come here on occasion to stock up on Baked BBQ Pork Buns!! Their Baked cocktail and pineapple-shaped buns are yum too! Going to try their Steamed Custard bun next :)
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: I don't think there was anything at this bakery that anyone finished. I'm not sure why the high rating. It was ok but nothing was really good.
author: Chad E.

description:
This bakery is a landmark for Chinatown. It's a must see & try if you're visiting San Fran for the first time. The owners are amazingly sweet and the gentlemen is so full of life it'll brighten your day. He's extremely helpful and even offers to ship product to your home if your heart desires it at a later time. 

My traveling partner was on the hunt for some sort of Asian bread and couldn't for the life of her remember the name of it. After walking into Eastern Bakery and describing the bread to the older male owner he allowed her to try a piece of his fresh baked bread. It knocked her socks off. That's it!!!! she said. I don't do yeast but she described it as better than Hawaiian rolls (I definitely grew up on those delicious, moist, succulent Hawaiian rolls). 

I opted for the dark chocolate covered fortune cookies; being that I'm addicted to dark chocolate and all. I also went with a moon cake which was superb. The texture was unique, soft with a jelly-like sweet inside. 

You must take a trip through the bakery; it's not fancy but it's awesome in its own right. 

Thank me later,
~Christy
author: Christy A.

description: This bakery has been around for over 40 years. It's not just the tourists but for locals too. Brings back my childhood memories for Chinese bakery.  It definitely will give you a taste of Chinatown.
author: Angela W.

description:
BEST place in Chinatown for Pork Buns.  I stop here often to get them for my granddaughter. 

She gives a SOLID thumbs up.
author: kat v.

description: Excellent range of traditional Chinese baked goods using different preparation techniques and a wide variety ingredients. The right taste, texture, and eye appeal. Mooncake with mixed nuts is fantastic and filling. Can be hard to decide what to buy!
author: Geoffrey F.

description: Been coming here since I was a kid.  The food is always good and pricing is phenomenal.  If you need a quick bite to eat as you walk around, stop in and pick out something to go.
author: Eliana R.

description: Most expensive bakery in Chinatown. Only for tourist. Locals go couple blocks on Stockton for much better bakeries.
author: carrie H.

description: Being a huge fan of Chinese deserts, I definitely had to stop by during my visit to Chinatown. I always come back for their lotus pancakes and steamed rice cakes, not too sweet but not bland either. The shop had a good vibe and had many people coming in and out with pastries in hand. Don't miss out!
author: Bea A.

description:
This place got such good ratings...I somehow must have ordered the wrong things? I also came around 5pm so maybe everything was getting too old?

Ambiance: nothing about this place felt clean, but I didn't factor that into my rating because most of China town is like this. The plates, plastic ware (that had been washed and reused), tables, sauce holders, chairs...all of them could have been wiped down more.

Food: The person I came with LOVES Chinese food so I was really hoping she would enjoy this. Nothing that we had would call us back.
-Pork bun: relatively decent ratio of meat to bun. Not terrible, but not great. Both the bun and the meat were sweet.
-Chicken combo bun: there was some boiled egg in here along with other random meat-like looking stuff. I've had a Vietnamese version of this that was delicious. This tasted bland and old.
-Pork dim sum: the best thing we ordered but that's not saying much. Perhaps it would have been better if it were fresh.
-Vegetable dim sum: horrible. There was not any vegetable in here. It was literally gooey peanuts. We both took a couple of bites and left the rest.

Service: the ladies in here were very friendly and kind. Definitely nice to have a smiling face, especially in Chinatown in the evening. This is what earned them a couple of stars in my book.
author: Susan G.

description:
The cream puffs are delicious! 

When you walk in, you'll find that the store is quite narrow and looks a little run down. However, the pastries are quite delicious - namely, the cream puffs. 

Sweets lovers rejoice, because the cream puffs here are airy and has just the right amount of cream to bun ratio. If you ever had a cream puff before, you might find that sometimes there is just too much cream and not enough bun, and the entire puff is in an imbalance between flavor and texture. This cream puff is made perfectly so you can enjoy all of the puff's elements. The cream itself is not too sweet and not too bland, but has the lightest whipped texture - SO DELICIOUS.

However, I took a star off for the chocolate covered moon cakes because I found the chocolate too overwhelming. If you love chocolate, then this may not be a problem. I would have liked to taste the moon cake more, but I had trouble distinguishing the flavors because of the excess amount of chocolate. 

Overall, this is a great place if you like cream and custard pastries!
author: Robin C.

description:
Thought this place was somewhat touristy but had some decent baos.  The wait was long because there are a lot of tourists just packing the place up.  

I got the bo Lo Bao , Dan tat, and char siu bao.  The bo Lo Bao and char siu Bao was not bad.  The Dan tat was just god awful though.  The egg custard part was cooked all the way through which made for a really strange texture and taste.  Noticed that since I spoke canto to them while ordering they gave me much fresher stuff than the baos sitting in the display so that was nice.  Besides from the Dan tat I'm pretty satisfied and would come back if the other bakeries aren't that great.
author: Alexander C.

description:
I heard that this bakery is the oldest bakery in SF Chinatown and it sure looks like it because the bakery looks really run down and ancient! 

They have assortment of Chinese mooncakes to choose from and lots of random Chinese pastries. They have these interesting looking chocolate dipped fortune cookies that I do not want to try...lol

Apparently according to other Yelp reviewers, they are known for their coffee crunch cake. I knew I definitely needed to try it and I did by ordering it for my coworker's birthday. It was delicious and it didn't taste or look like those disgusting Chinese bakery fruit birthday cakes. BEST CHINATOWN CAKE EVER!!!

Thanks fellow Yelpers for the awesome recommendation!
author: Alice X.

description:
A hidden gem in Chinatown! This bakery is my favorite! I live an hour train ride outside of SF and will ride the train some Saturdays just to get a dozen pork buns, some Chinese doughnuts and a couple egg tarts, they're all to die for! Haven't tried anything I didn't like here! 

Beware they are cash only, but there is an ATM across the street so no worries there!
author: Andrew O.

description: Amazing pork buns! The lovely owner said he had been their for 20+ years and read our minds for what we wanted when we walked in. Gorgeous sponge cake too
author: Tori B.

description: Garbage dim sum. Old. Almost inedible. Also expensive for what I got. If you are just going to rehear old dim sum charge less!
author: Matt G.

description:
I get that this place is historic. Nevertheless, standards don't seem really high when it comes to grub in the West Bay's Chinatown these days, yet even against these watered-down norms, this venue is below average. 

No matter what it is you're getting, whether an egg tart (dan tat) or a roast pork bun, it just won't measure up to what you can get from bakeries elsewhere in Chinatown as well as more modern (if albeit more expensive) bakeries in suburbia. It's as if not a whole lotta love goes into anything that's baked here, let alone the dingy venue itself. 

Sadly, just because a place is historic doesn't mean that it's kept up with the competition - or the times.
author: Vincent L.

description: Ok I was excited to get The  steamed rice cake. I bought a dozen to bring home to San Diego, and when I tried them as soon as we left the bakery, the cake was kind of sour.
author: Frances C.

description: Place is great stumbled on it while walking through Chinatown. BBQ sweet pork roll was different but very good! The coconut filled bread(not sure the exact name) was amazing. Definitely worth a stop in. Like others said it's cash only so be prepared.
author: Will S.

description:
COCKTAIL BUNS! They are so gooooooooood!
I came in one late Saturday night looking for their butter cream buns (been coming here for a while), only to find there was only one left (there were 3 of us). The man behind the counter told me if I would like to try their cocktail buns because they also had coconut in them. 
I said why not, paid, walked outside and huddled with my sisters to taste these suckers.

We ate 4 of them in less than 5 minutes. 

We shamefully walked back in, where to my surprise the man started talking to us in Spanish (MY PEOPLE!!!!). I asked for 6 more buns, and had a lovely conversation with the dude about speaking Spanish (you are gold in my eyes sir) then we went on our merry way with our tasty buns.

Now about these buns. They were sitting in a steam box, so they we moist and warm. Inside of them is this coconut mixture that pairs well with the not so sweet bun. 

I highly recommend taking one of these babies, along with their other offerings (i've had the coffee crunch cake, the moon cakes, and other confections).

Maybe on the next round I'll get a savory bun just to keep it interesting. Oh yeah, its cash only and can get kind crowded, so make sure you're ready if order!
author: Em C.

description: Best coffee crunch cake in the Bay Area. Every single year we get this cake for my daughter birthday and she is going to be 17
author: Wolfie M.

description: Came in on a Saturday morning when it was very empty! The mooncake was very dry and seemed "meh" compared to other mooncakes I've tried in NY Chinatown/Flushing and Asia. My friend got the coconut fruit filled cake because they didn't have coconut buns. This was even more dry which was so disappointing! Probably should've gotten a pineapple bun instead :( Eastern Bakery seems slightly overrated but there is a ton of historic value here so if I am in the area I may give it another try
author: Hana S.

description:
They have many Chinese delicatese, but they are well known for the moon cakes. They have many different kinds, start by the traditional without yoke. 
If you never had one, try the mini moon cake, in case you don't like it.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
Ever since I took my sister here the first time she came to visit she's always asking me to take her whenever she's in town for their moon cakes.  I can't say they're the best in the city just good.  Haven't found great moon cakes in city but egg tart at Golden Gate bakery and fortune cookies at Golden Gate Fortune Cookies at Ross Alley are my favorite places to take visitors.

Check out the picture of Bill Clinton behind the counter.
author: Naty D.

description:
Buns: big dough, small meat.
#thatswhatshesaid in Chinese:
#zhejiushitashuo
author: Dan B.

description: Their selection is far too much for me to handle but their EGG CUSTARD TARTS and their CHAU SIU BAO were freshly made and cooked to perfection. That was all I needed, and I was a happy camper. Check this place out, it reminds me of what Chinatown in LA should really be like. ENJOY!
author: Darlene Y.

description:
A real hole-in-the-wall with a huge selection, but you really have to know what to get or you'll walk out disappointed.


---- WHAT'S GOOD ----

Egg Tart:  4.5 stars
Custard pretty perfect, flavourful and not too sweet.   Super crisp flaky pastry shell.

BBQ Pork Bun (Baked):  4 stars
The baked bun dough is wonderful, miles ahead of the steamed buns.  The fililng is your typical char siew filling (but a grey colour, not dyed red).

Cocktail Bun: 4 stars
Yummy sweet bun with coconut jam filling, warm from their oven.

Coffee Crunch Cake: 3 stars
Beautifully soft sponge cake with slightly sweetened cream. I just really don't like the sweet artificial taste of the coffee hard candy sprinkled on top... which is the "coffee crunch."


---- AVOID ----

Chicken Bao (Steamed):  2.5 stars
Uninspired.  Large with thick bread that gets soggy easily, but the filling is a dry, haphazard mix of Chinese sausage, unidentifiable chicken parts, hard-boiled egg, etc in a bit of gravy with weird aftertaste.  Good Mong Kok and other dimsum spots have better steamed buns for sure.

Crispitos:  2.5 stars
Just a deep-fried wonton skin dusted with sweet stuff.

Yellow Bean Preserved Egg Puff Pastry  皮蛋酥:  2.5 stars
The puff pastry is wonderfully flaky (similar to Lao Po Bing 老婆饼), but the filling is much too sweet and tastes weird with coconut strips in them.  It also has a godawful rubbery preserved egg in there (the 皮蛋 in this 皮蛋酥).  For $3.50 this is a whole load of sugar...  I would not buy this again.

Vegetarian 饺子:  3 stars
Not bad, and I like that it is completely vegetarian (no meat or seafood), but the filling is just cabbage, frozen peas & carrots, and boiled peanuts.  Meh.
author: Letitia L.

description: Best place for steamed pork buns in the city. So warm and delicious. Grab a few and enjoy them as you walk around china town or grab a dozen for later. Best I've ever had. Baked buns aren't as good as the steamed though.
author: Andrian T.

description:
Do not ask for hot cappucino. They will serve in a thin plastic glass with a straw. And do not drink with straw or else you burn your mouth. 

Found a fly in my coffee. Got a refund for my coffee. Really unhygenic place. Not sure how this place got so many good reviews. Bakery stuff tastes good, but i really doubt the hygiene. Never going back.
author: Anup B.

description: This review is for their bbq pork bun only.  It was nice and hot, generous on their filling, and the bread was very thin.  Very tasty too.   This and tc bakery in Daly City have the best bbq pork buns in the bay!!
author: Cal Y.

description:
After reading raves on Yelp for their steamed cha sao bao (aka bbq pork buns), I decided to give it a shot despite my consistently bad experience with Chinatown food.  I asked the shopkeeper if the bao was hot.  He confirmed that it was warm so I pressed on to complete the purchase.  Sadly, he exaggerated.  It was slightly warmer than room temperature.  The bun itself was lifeless and flat, unlike those you get at dim sum.  It didn't rise sufficiently when steamed.  There was a reasonable amount of filling with chunky pieces of pork.  However, it was gross, covered with congealed fat, probably due to poor temperature control.  Rounding out the experience, the man behind the counter also gave me the wrong change.  I let it go since I was beat after work and this place can use a facelift.  

Last but not least, what's up with the chocolate covered everything?  Is this how Chinese bakeries evolve over time in the US or are they just trying to hide poor pastry making skills under brown gunk?
author: Amy J.

description:
I love the egg tarts here! I can't say I've had the ones at Golden Gate Bakery, as they have the tendency to be on vacation, so I cannot compare. I've had other egg tarts, however, and they weren't as good as the ones at Eastern Bakery. The custard component is silky, has the perfect amount of sweetness, and isn't overly eggy. The crust is flakey and complements the custard nicely.

A big positive for me worth mentioning is that  they continue baking egg tarts into the afternoon. I even got a couple on a Sunday evening  once! Came here in the afternoon last week and while they didn't have a lot on display, they had some in the oven. Got a dozen hot and fresh tarts! 

Random, but their shrimp chips are good too! Greasy, but delicious.

Service isn't noteworthy, but I don't expect that so much in Chinatown. They get the job done.
author: Vanessa U.

description: I love pineapple buns and I though this place was so good. Each bun was $0.95 which is on the cheaper side. The bread was so fluffy and the egg crust tasted great. I regret not buying more to take home.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Review is only for lopo bang-- wifey winter melon "cakes".

$1.75/small

Lots of layers of Lardy freshness , but for a true connoisseur, it's lacking a looseness that is difficult to achieve. A stellar cake ought be filled with flakiness, dry enough on the texture, but still soft when biting into it.
This was not.

Inside wintermelon filling was also not that delicious soft chew with fluff that HK excels at. I dunno-- not as good as I once recall. Either that or I'm getting darned pickier!

The place is a mess, just as it always is! Hire an organizer and just keep it up!
author: Jana C.

description: Over-rated, unbelievably bad service.  I watched the grandma yell at the poor lady in front of me, and be completely put out by her order.  Even though I spoke mandarin with her, she was also short with me.  I get it if the dim sum is outstanding, but it really isn't.  The char siew baos (baked) were undercooked and the filling had a slight twang to it.  Kids actually spit it out!  The dan tat was ok, a little bland.  Not sure what the #1 ranking is all about, I didn't see it.  Much better bakeries in Chinatown, and with much better attitudes.  Pass.
author: Rob K.

description: Ehhh it's a tourist trap. I've had a lot better. Still not a huge fan of The San Francisco Chinatown. The NYC one by far is still the best!
author: Amy W.

description:
Strolling (or more aptly, rucking) through Chinatown on a drizzly Saturday afternoon had us in and out of many spots looking at all of the trinkets and food.  Eastern Bakery has a wide variety of sweets and pastries - kids picked the bouncy rice cakes ($.75 each), and the wife and I split the stunning moon cakes (full description next to register - you'll get pointed there when you ask 'what's in a moon cake').  

Curt, efficient service with a quick 'thank you' on the way out helps add to the experience that is Eastern Bakery.
author: Patrick K.

description: We stopped by this place on the way back to our hotel to check out what baked goods they had. Sure enough they had what I was craving! Steamed and roasted pork buns. It's a no frills place with minimal seating. The items for sale are displayed in the window, food case/counter, and against the wall. The instant I walked in, I was reminded of my favorite place in NYC Chinatown that sells the same food! The pork buns were priced pretty well rather in my opinion at around $1.35 each. I walked out a happy camper and was able to enjoy my snack for the rest of our walk back to the hotel!
author: Christine B.

description:
Avoid their dim sum, but do get their coffee crunch cake.  It's simply scrumptious. 

Their dough that they use is thick and not thin for the peel of the dim sum steamed orders.  

It's a small spot for the dry bakery goods and not much of a sit down place. 

Convenient grab, but if you go more central Chinatown, dim sum fares better that way.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
If you are around Chinatown SF and don't exactly want a full meal, try this place out or better yet grab some to go. My family and I wanted something to snack on before dinner.. haha I know.. so luckily we found this place thanks to reviews. So many options from sweets to pork or vegetable filled dim sum, you're bound to find something to your liking. We ordered the rice cake, coconut almond cake bun, pork dim sum, potstickers, and a green chili Chinese tamale. The flavors were amazing and some required an acquired taste like the rice cake and Chinese tamale. 

All items were decently priced, so it makes it easy to try a bunch of different things.
author: Shaundiin Y.

description:
This was an excellent stop on our was to the bar for the night. Delicious and cheap pork buns, with an incredibly fun and authentic feelings inside. I grew up in Asia, and this tasted just like home. I'd suggest getting one or two of the savory BBQ pork buns here, as they are quite large. They had delicious sesame red bean sweet buns as well, which I would definitely suggest to the adventurous eater. There's no grandeur here - the food and the staff are honest and down-to-earth. 

My colleague and I were lucky enough to get a live show, as the staff were busy putting together a large order of mooncakes, which looked absolutely delicious. There are small tables at the back to sit at, but this is definitely not a place for large groups, or to plan to stay for very long to eat/work. I would suggest this spot to anyone visiting the Bay Area, and will absolutely be back next time I'm in town!
author: Chelsie G.

description: Walking around Chinatown we stumble across this little bakery. They offered a variety of goodies and have delicious baked char siu bao. The lady who helped me was really sweet. She tried to upsell me some items. I got Chinese candy. Delicious. Check it out. Lots of good stuff!
author: Shaun E.

description:
Rating is solely based on pineapple bun. Wished the bun had some custard inside. I would've given this place 5 stars if it did. 

WOW! Amazing delicious, affordable, and President Bill Clinton has been to it!
author: Jen H.

description:
Stopped in for the first time ever at about 7:30 tonight to see what they had. Walked out with a lemon pinwheel cake, two steamed pork buns, and a giant almond cookie. 
Cookie was good, nothing spectacular other than its an almond cookie x 5!! 
The lemon cake was super soft, lemony sweet and tart, but the sponge cake lacked a little sweetness. But still excellent regardless. The pork buns were excellent. Soft, sweet and savory, moist and a really good meat to bread ratio. I'd eat them over and over again. The lady working was polite, but a bit rushed, speeding us thru our ordering. If you're going thru China Town do yourself a favor and give them a shot.
author: Andre R.

description:
By far has the BEST pineapple buns i've had in awhile, especially if you get them fresh out of the oven! (Around noon on weekdays seems to be when they pull a fresh batch out). Gets pretty crowded around 1130, but if you go right after you eat lunch the crowd clears away a bit and you can get some delicious fresh pineapple buns. Highly recommend!

BTW. Cash only!
author: Sam L.

description:
YELP 365 CHALLENGE 2014-(272/365) "More Custardy Goodness!"

EGG TART SCRAMBLE-Stop # 2
 
After checking out the trinkets and toys at the souvenir shop nearby, we stumbled upon Eastern Bakery. Eastern has been around longer than any other Chinese bakery in the U.S., according to Wikipedia.

 Everywhere you turn, sweets of all shapes, sizes, and flavors tempt you, but having a pretty good egg tart earlier at Anna Bakery, I wanted to compare Eastern Bakery's version and see how it stacked up. These were warm, flaky and creamy without being too sweet, soggy, or having an overly eggy taste and texture which I don't care for.

The man behind the counter was pretty adamant about us trying his Coconut Bread which was oven fresh and piping hot, so we decided to get one as well. great flavors, and even better when its hot. The man was happy we enjoyed his Coconut Bread and laughingly commented "See! You will be back!". He was wrong though, not because we didn't enjoy the items we tried...it was because 10 courses of deliciousness was waiting for us at R&G Lounge nearby.   ALOHA!!!

Shaka Meter:\uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  4
author: Nelson Q.

description: Hands down, best BBQ Pork Bun in the Bay Area.  I was introduced to Eastern Bakery years ago when I used to work on California & Kearney.  I've been going ever since, even though I no longer work in the city.  It's so worth the drive from Contra Costa County just to make a special trip to buy their Pork buns.  I buy a dozen and they freeze beautifully.  Their steamed Pork buns as well as their Cocktail Buns are equally delicious.  Their staff is great, prices are wonderful.  Parking is tough, however.  My husband drops me off and drives around the block a few times and then picks me up around the corner.  I highly recommend the Eastern Bakery.  Give it a try.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Nancy E.

description: Long lines but fast service. Tasty baked goods. Great for a snack or on the go. Just an all around great bakery.
author: Marc R.

description: The gai mei baos (cocktail buns) are the BEST here. They have the perfect ratio of bread to filling, with no significant air gaps in the middle. The wash on the bun makes it shiny and sticky. When you get these fresh (or even at the end of the day), the bun is so soft. The filling isn't overly sweet too. Just perfect.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Nom Nom Nom Nom Nom. 

Best BBQ baked pork bun I've had in a long time. And cheap! Bring cash. A fun stop by in Chinatown.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Best Coffee Crunch cake!!! 
Long lines.... Moon cake was good, Chinese lotus cake was delicious... If you like sesame balls.... They're humongous here.... They are friendly.... Limited English but friendly. 
The only thing is... There's no ambience..... Great for food to go...
author: Zean C.

description: They make good cookies and its very resonable priced. I go here to grab cookies for friends and co workers. Delicous baked goods. Freshly baked and very nice staff.
author: Tony N.

description: An amazing experience here. For those who don't know what mooncake is, it's a must try! This bakery is actually the only domestic producer of mooncake in the US and it lives up to its reputation. I ordered a single yolk, lotus mooncake. Mooncake is basically a circular pastry filled with a paste like filling and usually a salted boiled egg yolk. As soon as I took my first bite I was in love. Although I wasnt a fan of the salty yolk, the sweet lotus filling was a new and tasty experience. If your in chinatown make sure to stop by!
author: Adrian E.

description:
Eastern Bakery is historic. According to Wikipedia, Eastern Bakery is the oldest Chinese Bakery in North America. Obviously, it has been around for years ... and sadly it kind of feels old inside. 

Tourists flock to Eastern Bakery because of its location and fame. It's known for Chinese mooncakes as well as cookies, buns, sticky rice, egg tarts, fortune cookies, and mung bean cakes. Olivia Z. and me popped in for some Egg Tarts and Pineapple Buns.

The lady behind the counter was pretty impatient, so, we got our tarts and buns out of the store as quickly as possible. Both the egg tarts and pineapple bun were pretty average. The didn't stand out at all. That's a good thing when selling to out-of-town visitors who want some pretty typical flavors, but 3-star breads and tarts won't be enough to draw locals to Chinatown.

Eastern Bakery was a-ok. If you're there, get something to eat ... otherwise enjoy the history of the bakery while knowing there are better Chinese bakeries nearby.
author: Michael S.

description: The best coffee crunch cake! Loved their sweet roll bread filled with coconut and butter so delicious very good prices!
author: Sonia Q.

description: Quick and easy! You don't have to wait for an egg tart at this joint! You can find this little bakery in Chinatown. We actually came here late at night and got us some goodies. We of course had to have egg tarts. I know there are so many places in this area selling those little gems but theirs is really good!
author: Kristie A.

description: Mom bought a lemon crunch cake. It was very big and pretty good.
author: Denise C.

description:
best pineapple bun ive ever had in my life. 
my Taiwanese friend said it was just as good as the ones from the homeland.
so fresh. so hot. so noms.
hnnnnngggg.

also tried the bbq pork bun, which was also tasty. but that pineapple bun...
author: Timothy H.

description:
I promised my uncle that I would bring him a box of Lotus Paste with single yolk Moon Cake: they are typically gifts  that you don't buy for yourself. My family has been eating these for decades and they have been discontinued from LA Chinatown for at least 8-9 years and it brings back many fond memories for my uncle. The moon cakes are $5.50 each and there are four in a box. The lady told me they last 3 weeks...

This bakery is as old school as it gets and if you didn't grow up with these pastries, this place would not be appealing. The bakery is a dump and the baked goods look very sloppy and unpresentable. 

They also sell Chinese candies and Smackles (a thin savory and sweet cracker with a crunchy texture). If my mom knew I was here she would have requested them, they are only sold in SF Chinatown. I had friends who have come here and bought over 20 bags to bring home. Everyone wants them ;P

Every time I'm here I get Char Sui and Chinese Sausage buns for my kids. They fight over them and are cheap and filling. They have stale samples in the front but don't be afraid because they are served fresh from steamers in the back. I have tried the egg tarts here before and they were fine, made from lard I think (the traditional way).

Bill Clinton has been here to try a Moon cake. They proudly display two blown up pictures of him eating one :P
author: Christina W.

description:
After family lunch at the New Woey Loy Goey, a walk on Grant Avenue brought us to Eastern Bakery for dessert.

I remember our grocery store (back in the days) would carry their mooncakes (4 ct.) during the Harvest Moon Festival season for sale.  The mooncakes were tasty back then, but I don't eat them anymore as the desire for them is gone.  

However, I am a big fan of their coffee crunch cake, which my office used to order it quite often for our potlucks.  Some of my co-workers like the cake, but others say the cake is coarse and refer to it as a "cornmeal" cake.  The cake isn't overly sweet and it does go well with a cup of coffee or tea.

I have to chuckle to myself, seeing those ngow yee biang (cow ear cookie).  Nope, I did not buy any of those.  

My brother-in-law wanted some sesame balls.  OMG, they were pretty big, piping hot and somewhat greasy.  It just came out of the deep fryer, so they were fresh.  (Hey, I was not going to eat one and burn my palate...I don't think so.)

The cream roll cakes looked pretty good, especially the lemon one.  I chose not buy it, as my husband and I don't eat a whole lot of cake.

Finally, thanks to a fellow yelper (Rick S) for mentioning that Eastern Bakery sells the coffee crunch cake "by the slice for $4".  I will stop in the bakery in the future to purchase a slice.
author: Carol C.

description:
Who would think you can get delicious Coffee Crunch Cake in Chinatown!!! Eastern Bakery is a little shop that is easily missed in the heart of Chinatown, but look for it! You kind of just have to step up and shout out your order. 

The tight space, non-personable workers, and cash-only register are definitely worth the inconvenience though. Oh, and you'll even be treated to a laminated picture on the wall of Bill Clinton visiting the shop! It is a good place to find mooncakes, fortune cookies, cookies, mung bean cakes and egg tarts. What I come here for:

Coffee Crunch Cake ~ a winner!!!  Pillowy soft cake with the light crunch of the crumble. It demands a good cup of coffee or tea to accompany it and it simply deserves to be savored!

Steamed Pork Buns ~ I first ordered a steam pork bun, thinking it would be the red BBQ pork meat filling. Instead it was brown, but surprisingly just as sweet as the BBQ filling I was expecting. Delicious!

Lotus Moon Cakes ~ many varieties are laid out in the display case; different fillings are identified and prices (ranging from $2.25 to $6.00 with discounts for quantity) are clearly marked. My favorite, lotus bean paste with salty egg yolk!

So don't get deceived by the small exterior of the bakery they have lots of treats to make anyone happy and fat!
author: Maria M.

description:
Let me say that I love mooncake and my favorite is the Lotus paste with egg yolks.  Having lived in Hong Kong, I had them fresh during the autumn moon festival.  The mooncake here is even better because the pastry is super thin which means more filling!  

It's the perfect balance of sweet and savory.  Worth the calories.

And, don't forget the coffee crunch cake.  My absolute fav!  Light sponge cake, mocha like cream and the crunch of the candy. It's a party in my mouth!

While the decor leaves a lot to be desired, look past it because the best food comes out of places like this.  Don't be a snob!
author: B F.

description: Delicious is one word, a must try is there coconut bun, we also tried the steamed pork bun and BBQ pork bun both of them were delicious!
author: Sahil S.

description: Delicious pastries, cash only! recommend the baked pork buns. I love the dough taste, slightly sweet but not too sweet. Brought some pastries home with me to NJ to give to my parents. Their moon pies are individually wrapped, so it stayed fresh.
author: Stephy S.

description: FRESH PINEAPPLE BUN. That's all I need to say. It's to die for... you can not leave SF Chinatown until this has been tried... lines pretty long but it goes quick and it's worth it! I'm from LA but I try to make a point to come whenever I'm In SF.. or I'll ask a favor of somebody who's visiting. A must try!!
author: betsy c.

description:
This is a tricky review.
Eastern Bakery has been around if not forever then near enough. As far as I know it opened in 1924 or so, and has been in it's current format since the early 1940's. Like a lot of places that have been around for a long time people can let nostalgia color their opinions of what the current quality is like. 
Also like many places that have been around forever this place has totally seen better days.  
The inside and outside is very gritty, the magnificent neon sign hasn't worked in so long that people have forgotten that it's there. Ditto for what was once some epic outdoor styling. Inside has a few tables and chairs for consuming tea and a sweet, but that space usually has boxes stacked in it. If you are in a restaurant, and they are using part of the customer facing area for storage, including and especially the seating that's a bad sign.
The bakery offers just about every kind of Chinese style Asian baked good that can be made, and they are especially popular during the holidays (any holiday. Not just the Asian ones.)  During these times there will be a line, and they do a fair amount of bulk orders. While they bake items daily what you get in the case may or may not be made fresh that day.
Some items are a sure bet here-the cocktail buns, mantou, and crispitos are filled with win. The mochi, pineapple buns and egg or custard items are better elsewhere and under no circumstances should you try the Zongzi (Chinese tamales.). The Chinese tamales have various fillings which consist of..........you know what, just don't. Really. Don't.
This place is great for the old school chinatown expierence. Especially if you are an adventurous eater. 
When you go make sure to get a photo or two for memory as chinatown is changing very rapidly and bastions of old chinatown such as this are fading fast.
I'm giving this a generous four stars mostly for nostalgia, and because my last visit offered the hope that it may return to it's better days, focused on quality instead of making the cheapest possible product.
Otherwise  a three or two star review would be far more realistic.
Sigh.
author: Steven W.

description:
Haven't been here since I was a teenager. Yes that was a while ago. From my memory it was meh  so so. I came back here cause I was in the area maybe retracing my past here. It's the same as I remember: bland and catered towards tourist. I tried the Dan tat (egg tart) and chicken sausage bun. The Dan tat was generic tasting and the bun was dry and lacked any taste. 

This place may just be more catered towards a different pallette and audience ( chocolate flavored fortune cookies) but it as a local it's not for me.
author: Jude N.

description:
Man, reading the reviews on here has made me realize just how little I know about Eastern Bakery.  I had no idea so many of their bakery items were so good!  It actually makes me a little sad since I've never tried any of them despite how many times my family has come here over the years.  Then again, when we do come in, it's with the sole purpose of getting one thing...the Coffee Crunch Cake!

While I've never been a huge fan of most Chinese bakery cakes (especially the ones with mixed fruit and white cream), this one is the exception.  The cake itself is pretty moist and fluffy, but I really like how they don't go overboard with lathering on the cream.  Although it's nice and light with a bit of coffee flavor, the cake would be too sweet if it had any more on there.  After all, there's still all those delicious bits of coffee "crunch" on the outside too!

Considering how long they've been around, Eastern Bakery's less than stellar looks shouldn't be all that surprising.  Besides, it is a Chinese bakery in Chinatown...can't expect too much people!  Personally, I didn't think it looked all that bad when I was here, but I admit I don't stick around for long either.  Usually, I'm in and out with my coffee crunch cake in tow that tastes just as good as the first time I had it.  Thanks for the memories Eastern Bakery!
author: Mike L.

description: Minus points for the Asian cashier who gave us the wrong pastry but still charged us for the thing...dude it was a dollar twenty? No matter how good the pineapple bun was (it was EXTREMELY GOOD), I don't tolerate service like this. It's one thing to apologize and give us another one but it's another to give us attitude (she said the one we had was good too while glaring) and accepting our money when we paid for it. If I were a store owner and made a mistake, I think I could part with one freaking pastry...It was so tiny and cheap probably took less than 10 cents to make.
author: Tiffany E.

description:
Mehhhhh. The best thing about this place is the coffee crunch cake..but even that is not as good as the one from Yatsukochi!!

What I've tried:
