1. Egg Tarts - When you're a block away from Golden Gate Bakery..I'm not sure why you'd come here..except when GGB is closed. Still...it is second best when it comes down to what is in the area...

2. Pork Buns - I opted for the steamed ones, but apparently the baked ones are better. This isn't the pork and veggie buns..it is BBQ pork! Personally, I'd just walk the extra 2 blocks to Good Mong Kok..

3. Veggie Buns - Not a fan at all. The veggies are soggy and gross..and the bread is sticky and soggy..

4. Cocktail Buns - Pretty standard..not the best. It's just coconuty enough..but not enough filler..

5. Coffee Crunch Cake - The best thing in this place!! The cake here is more cakey and less spongey if that makes sense. I prefer the coffee crunch cake from Yatsukochi in Japantown, but if I don't feel like making it over to jtown - this is the next best thing..and way more conveniently located.. :)

6. Nian Gao - Nian Gao is difficult to mess up...so its not bad here. They have it in coconut, black sugar, and red bean...not bad at all, except theres no nutritional value in nian gao at all..lol

7. Moon Cake - They have moon cake here YEAR ROUND. If you're craving it randomly, this is definitely the place to go.

Pretty okay all around..but nothing exceptional IMO..
author: Jennifer S.

description:
The coffee crunch cake isn't on display, but that's what you should get. That and one of their gigantic moon cakes.

The pricing isn't displayed for the coffee crunch cake, but this is how it's priced:
Whole cake (8 slices): $15.50
Half cake (4 slices): $10
One slice: $4

I originally wanted to buy two slices, but after hearing how it was priced, I decided to just go with the half cake for $10. I figure I can give some away to friends or family (or eat it myself !!)
author: Audrey L.

description: I tried the vegetable steamed bun and it was perfect! It had a sticky and soft texture, but it did not stick in your hands. The vegetables inside were delicious, warm and filling. I also had the sweet bun filled with coconut and cream and it was an excellent way to end the visit. The sugary goodness wasn't overpowering. 4/5 for taste. 5/5 for friendly staff. 5/5 for authentic atmosphere. 6/5 for price.
author: Gary H.

description: Place is super packed since its on the busy block of Chinatown, didnt try their buns but bought two mini mooncakes for $2.50 each pricy but it was delicious. The lotus seed one wasnt too sweet and had no yolk. Great flavor. Staff speak English which is a plus and they sell its it ice cream sandwiches in the freezer!!
author: Prima Z.

description:
Our experience here was hysterical. Although the food was completely underwhelming.. on the cusp of being pretty bad, it was still a hilarious experience and I don't regret having tried out Eastern Bakery. 

The restaurant is incredibly old and there isn't any etiquette or rules and you're kind of totally in the dark about whether your order was even received and placed, so you stand there confused. This is exactly what my partner did while I reserved a seat in the back area. 

So confused, we waited for our food. It was handed to us in a brown paper bag. There were no utensils to be found to eat our egg tart, 6 pork dumplings, and 2 pork buns to share. I went up to ask for chopsticks. No chopsticks, so I said forks are fine. He said we don't have that either. So I went over to our table and broke the news. The man called me back to the counter and said I have one fork and handed a plastic fork. I started cracking up and reported to our table with one fork. 

He found another one! Then I think he felt bad and went to the back and brought us a glass plate. Which I sincerely appreciated and the fact that he noticed and acted so we could have basic things to make this easier was actually really nice.

When customers order bubble tea, someone from the back comes out a long time later and shouts "hello" multiple times until the customer claims it. My partner ordered bubble tea, claimed his and the man tried to give me the other one that I didn't order. 

There are more cardboard boxes in this Bakery than an Amazon warehouse. FUN WAS HAD. But the food was not good. Dumplings were overloaded with meat with mild flavor. The pork buns didn't seem fresh. And we didn't even finish one egg tart between the two of us. I get that this has been around for a long time and is pretty popular. I came into it completely unaware and was underwhelmed.
author: Priti K.

description:
Sometimes when i find myself in Chinatown I want an Asian baked good, so to Eastern Bakery we go! I'll keep this short and sweet.

Service - Rushed. Even with no one behind you, it's all about the quickness.

Ambiance - Outdated. Not that I would usually hang out in a bakery anyway, but it's all part of the vibe.

Baked Goods - I saw the chocolate covered fortune cookie and I just HAD to try it, but never again for $1 each. However the BBQ pork bun ($1.10) while confusing at first (I didn't reach any pork until halfway through my bun!), the dough was marvelous.
author: Connie H.

description:
Cash only

Walked by this place to Golden Gate Bakery only to find that place with a line out the door and to the corner with 15 mins to closing. Yea, so we turned around and came here. Luck, or perhaps the prevalence of Chinese culture, found me amazing baked good. 

Steamed buns - great. - fluffy, full of flavor, warm and full of bbq pork.
Pineapple shaped bread - great. - sweet, good mix of fluffy insides and firm coat
Sausage breads - great - good sausage in good bread. A bonafied chinese corndog (cept not)
Egg custard - amazing - soft, rich, indulgent, delicious. I wish I had the right word to describe this indescribable food

If only I had brought cash and not needed to borrow some from a friend I would've gotten some moon cakes. Now I have to wait until I go back.

The woman behind the counter had somewhat understandable english and was mad at me for not knowing what i wanted. Woman, you have a freaking bakery with like 50 things and you want me to know what I want 2 mins in, with no people behind me? Made it fun tho.

TLDR - great bakery, don't overlook it. Get an egg custard (or maybe don't because most other egg custards will pale in comparision). Bring cash.
author: Henly K.

description: Why the raves over cellophane wrapped pastries that should be a dime a dozen at any Chinese bakery I don't know prices seemed average
author: Jim P.

description:
I love a steamed BBQ pork bun.  And this place did not disappoint.  

There was only one customer in front of me when I walked in so I was served fairly quickly.  I ordered a steamed bbq pork pun and a pineapple shape bun.  My total came to 2.30$.  I munched my lunch as I walked back to the Financial District and felt like I was in heaven.  The pork bun was so fluffy, so warm, so full of flavor.  And the pineapple bun is like eating the most delicious King's Hawaiian roll you have ever had (except even better because it has hint of pineapple!). Cash only.  Pork bun as big as my hand.  Can't wait to drop by again.
author: Joselyn P.

description:
Best bbq pork bun, ever. Steamed is ok, but baked is where it's at. 

Also, Bill Clinton ate here as a much younger man, which I suppose is cool. Still, worth coming for the bbq pork bun. Many other delectable treats to try as well.
author: Daniel M.

description: For dessert after your Chinese lunch/dinner, head over to this historic bakery. Coffee crunch cake was pretty good; each slice of cake comes with two fluffy layers sandwiched with coffee creme filling. The best/most unique characteristic of the cake is the coffee candy creme coating. I recommend pairing the cake with a glass of milk or tea, otherwise the cake might seem dry. I didn't get to try the mooncakes, but the beautiful boxes alone might make them worth the buy. Avoid the bags of Smackles -- more of a novelty snack than anything tasty.
author: Linny P.

description: I stop here every time I'm in San Francisco to get moon cakes, chocolate dipped fortune cookies and monster cookies, they're simply the best. Before I visited this place I had no idea what a moon cake even was but after my first bite I was instantly a fan, my favorite being the lotus and red/black bean filled. The only drawbacks to this place I can see is that it's a little pricey, but not too bad and that the place is sort of a mess, but the good food lets me see past that. All in all I'd definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants to try out some Chinese desserts.
author: Brad D.

description:
MMMM baked BBQ pork buns...

Make sure it's the BAKED ones!

Very filling and delicious!!!
author: Maria C.

description: Pretty good bakery if you know what to order - the egg tart and pork buns are pretty good. Their other pastries are toss-ups. The price is standard Chinatown pricing, which is nice. When I'm in the area, Eastern Bakery is where I stop by to get some of that Chinese bread action.
author: Judy S.

description:
Locals love this place for a reason.  It's wonderful!  But also be ready for a line.

I bought egg tarts, pineapple buns, the coffee cake, the lotus rice pancakes, and the steamed rice cake.  Everything was awesome.

The egg tarts are best at the golden gate bakery, which is close by, but this place is almost as good, and doesn't have the crazy lines like that place.  During my visit, the golden gate bakery was closed (owners are always on vacation), so I came here.
author: Lily F.

description: I had probably higher expectations than I should have, since my favourite Chinese bakeries are usually small hole in the wall types, so I was a bit disappointed with this. I liked the egg tart and the cream bun (not sure about the name), though they were both a bit dry. Not a fan of the moon cakes. Friendly staff though and a wider selection than what I tried, so I'll probably give it another try ;)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Lotus seed pancakes, moon cakes, sesame balls and tamales. All good here. Easy to locate a few steps away from the Chinatown gate on Grant Street. They are known for their coffee crunch cake but in my opinion, you should get a traditional Chinese pastry while you are here. The moon cakes come in different sizes and flavors and are very good.

Another favorite was the glutinous rice flour cake. Spongy, soft and only slightly sweet. A steal for $1.00. Sesame balls are huge. Picked up a sweet rice tamale with peanuts and green beans for tomorrow's breakfast. Hard to find vegetarian versions of these,  they are usually stuffed wih pork.
author: Ute L.

description:
Eastern Bakery in San Francisco on Grant Street is one of the oldest longest standing Chinese American bakeries.

Their signature cake is... THE COFFEE CRUNCH CAKE

They sell 'em by the slice for $4 (as of 2013) or by the full cake (8" @ $15), so you're better off buying a full sized cake unless you're on the go or just want to taste it.

They have other deserts, pastries, cookies, cakes, etc. here, including moon cakes.

It's in Chinatown, so is congested, and if you're not into walking and don't have good parking karma ('tho there's some local lots including Portsmouth Square), it may be difficult to get here conveniently.

However, whether you grew up on this desert, heard about it, or are now curious about it, it's one of those food items you have to try and taste since it's so unique.

I grew up on it, so in part there's a lot of nostalgia to the elated feeling I get when indulging in a slice of Coffee Crunch Cake.  That's my personal bias maybe.

The service is very friendly, and upon my last visit, it seemed like they're very welcoming to round eyed Westerners and tourists, which is nice to see in Chinatown. I've seen a lot of what appears to be non-locals patronize the bakery, so there must be a good solid viral word of mouth beyond the neighborhood and locals.

The place looks a bit run down, i.e. authentic, as it may have been in the 1940's, but is functional and fine, adding a bit of character and charm to the place.

I'd say this is one of, if not THE best bakery in Chinatown... again, I'm a 100% supporter of The Coffee Crunch Cake... all you need is a bottle of Belfast Cider to wash it down and you'll feel like you're in the 1970'-1980's...
author: Rick S.

description: Love this little bakery! The people that work here are so sweet and full of energy. I came in looking for regular dinner roll bread and was pleased to find that there was some fresh from the oven. I was swayed into trying their pineapple bread and I'm so happy I did! $1.00 shrimp chips, YES!
author: Shela D.

description: Eastern Bakery has the distinction of being the oldest Chinese bakery in North America.  It sort of looks like it too.  We came here for a quick bite of BBQ pork bun and custard egg tart.  The other place I went to that morning was closed for "vacation".  Most of these places in Chinatown are CASH ONLY, and Eastern Bakery is no exception.  The signs inside could use some updating and they still have the photos from when President Clinton visited and tried one of their illustrious moon cakes.  Despite the facade, their baked goods are tasty and cheap.  We had to wait for the egg tarts because they were still in the oven but we went ahead and had the baked BBQ pork bun.  It was just as I remembered from years ago.  The BBQ pork is brown in color lacking the festive red food coloring, but who wants more food dye in their lives anyway?  It tasted good and that's all that matters.  The egg tart was still warm from the oven and delicious.  The crust was crispy and flaky.  Service was okay.  3.5 stars rounded up.
author: Trina D.

description:
Best egg tarts in town! They're cheaper and tastier than the Golden Gate Bakery across the street. 
I also saw them deliver the pressed dough to Golden Gate Bakery, so you're probably getting the same taste for cheaper
author: Samantha A.

description: The pastries here are decent. I was a little disappointed with the pork buns and custard buns. I purchased the steamed buns and found them to have more bun and less filling than I have been used to and then I would like. However, the egg custard tarts made up for what the buns lacked! I know some people prefer them more eggy, but if you like the sweeter egg custard tarts, eastern bakery is the place to go. They were delicious little cups of custardy  goodness. I also tried their coconut custard buns. These are also good, particularly if you love coconut!
author: Alice S.

description:
Rice candy roll - solid, as good as it gets for this item. 

Smackies - light crispy not too sweet.
author: Jenny L.

description:
My review is solely for the wife winter melon cake aka 老婆饼. I was pretty disappointed by it because it lacked the typical flakey outer shell and the inside lacked something... Not sure what. But it wasn't there. Would not recommend this.

For $3.50, I was just a little underwhelmed and sad.

That being said, the woman who helped me with my order was extremely friendly and welcoming. Kudos for her.

If I find myself there again for some reason, maybe I'll try ordering something else.
author: Deanna C.

description: We've been coming here for over 30 years only for their Toffee Crunch Cake. I've never had anything else here but there's often a line. They speak both English and Chinese and provide efficient service. As usual, the cake was really good and everyone enjoyed it for my mom's birthday.
author: Jen L.

description:
It was late on a weeknight, and the SFO arrivals I had just picked up wanted to stop by Chinatown. This was one of the few places still open with dim sum. We didn't try any of the baked sweet goods.

The good: Steamed pork bau was a hit. We ordered more to take home. Also, it was nice that this place was open late and had some seating and a bathroom in the back.

The meh: Obviously this is more bakery than dim sum oriented. There weren't a lot of options beyond dumplings. The har gow was more dough than shrimp, and a little tough to eat at the end of the day even when reheated. Chicken mushroom steam bau also wasn't that great. 

Although there is seating, it's set among boxes and other supplies in the back, past the display counters up front. Very much a hole in the wall ambience.

Would I recommend? For dim sum, I have a few better options, but both close by six on a weeknight.
author: Sue V.

description:
This old time bakery has changed ownerships a few times as the original owners sold the business and retired in the late '70's, early '80's.  
This used to be a combination of bakery, soda fountain, and restaurant.  Lined with small booths and tables in the back, this was a Chinatown old timer (lo wah kue) hangout and often first westernized food experience for Chinese kids growing up there.  The right side of the store was a long counter that had single counter swivel seats (think "Back to the Future" - hey, Biff!) for the soda fountain (milk shake, floats anyone?).  Just look at the Coca Cola sign outside to confirm that old school feel.
The left side counter displays their assortment of pastries with individual servings in the front and whole cakes towards the rear.  My mom requested a coffee crunch cake for her birthday dinner and this is our family's place, though a more traditional version is found at Sweet Stop.  I often order the lemon crunch for a change of pace.  Rice crisps, cow ears, apple turnovers, and lemon tarts were my personal favorites during my formative years.  
They were also the main moon cake seller, having a small factory on the corner of Mason and Jackson streets, prior to the avalanche of imports from HK, Taiwan, and the PRC.
Sadly, except for the crunch cakes, most of their other offerings are just okay, hence the three stars.  
Thanks for the memories to the Lee family who founded this.  Which we could bring those old time  flavors back.
author: Mike C.

description: This place was packed the two times we went there but the service was still very fast.  The baked pork buns are awesome and the prices are insanely low. I think we fed our group of 4 for around 15 dollars (with leftovers). You'd be a fool to go here and not try one.  If you're ever in China town, I'd recommend stopping by here.  Also, I got a kick out of the several pictures they have of Bill Clinton when he stopped by in the 90's
author: Mark W.

description: Tried to go to Golden Gate bakery but the line was soooooo long. Should've just waited. The pastries here at Eastern are ok. I would give 3 stars but if there's one thing I can't stand, it's being taken advantage of. I get it, it's a random bakery in the middle of Chinatown and I'm not nor do I speak Chinese but I don't appreciate being ripped off. Was charged 150% the actual price. Fk that
author: Megumi A.

description: Lotus mooncake is pretty good. Their buns are also very good.  Apparently, President Bill Clinton has eaten here in 1996. Pretty cool.  Their bubble tea is good too.
author: K D.

description: Coffee crunch cake! The 8 inch ($20) feeds ~8, 10 inch ($30) feeds ~9-15 and the 12 inch ($41) feeds ~16-20 people. Great bakery for birthday cakes. If you call ahead, they can write a message on the cake.
author: Christine C.

description:
OMG! U have to try the citrus bun, one of the best pastries I've ever tasted! And I know what I'm talking about, I'm Mexican and we have panaderías (sweet bread shops) full of pan dulce  (sweet bread) everywhere. Lol 
Citrus Buns are the best!
author: Eddie V.

description:
I don't know what's so BAM about this place...

There are plenty of other options in Chinatown, and Eastern just didn't cut it for me. Their bread did look a few days old, and there was no fresh air flowing through the place. I stopped by here with a friend on a Sunday morning, and we were kind of put off that the only other people in here was a European family looking to buy their sweet cream bread. 

Being Taiwanese, my friend and I might have been too used to our typical Taiwanese bakeries like 85 Degrees and the sort, but Eastern was nothing special and the shop was not airy and light enough for us to find the stomach to purchase anything. Ah well.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Above average selection of baked goods and pastries, but not as much variety as you would typically see at a Chinese bakery.  One thing they do specialize in is mooncakes, which are pretty good.  Not quite as good as in Asia, but passable in SF (you should probably get one here if you've never tried one).  The egg yolk in the middle can take some getting used to, but overall mooncakes are calorie bombs that are worth the hit once a year!

I've had a few things from here - baked cha siu buns, one of their mooncakes, and a few other assorted pastries.  Everything was alright, but I've had better of each thing elsewhere.  The baked cha siu buns were a bit light on the cha siu as well.  They have a lot of history, as is apparent upon walking in, but I just wasn't that impressed.  Nothing's really pulling me back here as there are better places on Stockton a few blocks away.
author: Ben K.

description:
After being sorely disappointed they did not have any Smackles (cow ear cookies) at Mee Mee bakery, I was so happy they had them here!

Bow tie crispies were delicious as well!
author: Jade B.

description:
Don't let the initial looks scare you off because its a bit sketchy.  But if you are walking in Chinatown needing to feed lunch to four people you can't go wrong for $20.  Shu mai and silky shrimp is $2.25 each but the Pork buns are huge and as big as a sandwich.  

Be adventurous and have a dive experience, mamasan is nice.
author: Chris A.

description:
There are quite a few bakeries in SF Chinatown and I can think of two off the top of my head that are at least four stars. Therefore, this one gets three.

It is kinda dingy-looking but what matters more are the service and, of course, the baked goods.

The older woman behind the counter makes you feel rushed by frequently saying things like "What would you like?" Also, the man behind the counter tried pushing pork buns onto us. Just because my boyfriend and I are Chinese does not mean we automatically know what we want right as we enter the door; some people come with a specific purpose and some don't. Tourists may want the pork buns by default but we just... want... to... browse... so keep your pants on! 

The butter cream buns are light and tasty. They are also "oily" so you should pick them up with a napkin when eating them. The moon cakes are good too. The plain lotus or salted egg ones are my go-to moon cake flavors in general. The pineapple buns taste how you would expect; they don't disappoint.

I'll likely go back at some point to try out other pastries since the location is convenient when walking through Chinatown. Hopefully the owners will be less pushy.
author: Liana F.

description: Really good cakes ... I got my girls bday cake from here in December ... I don't eat sweets but my girl loved it.... Whipped frosting with strawberries.. I will recommend for cakes..
author: Len M.

description:
We kinda randomly came across this place waking through china town. What stopped us was the crown, and on closer notice we saw all these hand written notes plastered on the walls everything about how they are the only bakery in the US hat make their fillings right there are the store, pictures of president Clinton at their bakery, and other notes about how long they have been in business. One notes said something like they have been there before World War II. But beyond all of the attention grabbing display was all the goods. Very nicely displayed with names of the ingredients for people that are unfamiliar with the baked goods like me. You could just tell that everything was made there, from the way the pastry looked, from the smell of the bakery, and more importantly the way everything tasted. We literally tried everything on display and once we were done they kept bringing out fresh warm baked goodies. So we couldn't resist and tried that too.
Basically everything was delicious. I'm not a big fan of cakes or cookies and have never tried Chinese bakery before but I must say that this was a very pleasant start. And must try is there a cream filled and custard filled warm buns. The bakery owner and the employees were all very nice and directed us patiently to what everything is. They even gave us free samples to try. If I'm ever back in town I will make sure to stop by here again.
author: Farbod F.

description:
When I was a kid my mom bought me lotus melon cakes from Woo Chee Chong.  They were awesome with the sweet center and the flaky pastry outside.  It was cool visiting the store front and buying fresh goodies.  There was so much to choose from I just stuck with what I'm use to.  The recipe for the lotus melon cakes has changed a bit.  The shape is different and the flavors a bit different.  The cakes are still good.  I also tried a lotus moon cake.  It was pretty good.

It was great to see Eastern Bakery still baking goodies.  Not as awesome as when I was a kid but still better than many other places.
author: Soo H.

description:
Eastern Bakery is known for making fresh moon cakes year-round. I love how they offer mini size ones because just because you can eat a whole regular sized one doesn't mean you should. 

Mini Lotus Moon Cake - Wonderfully chewy and moist. It wasn't too sweet, and didn't leave me hating myself after finishing it. It definitely tasted better than the prepackaged ones I'm used to eating. 

Mini Sponge Cake - I ate this the next day and it was pretty dry. I'm not sure if I would've had a much better experience had I eaten it the day of. Based on the reviews I've read, perhaps the sponge cakes themselves just aren't that great.

CASH ONLY like most places in Chinatown. I will come back when mid-autumn festival rolls around!
author: Lucy N.

description: A little overpriced but they have nice and authentic baked goods and some Dim Sum items. Make sure to try the Lotus Mooncakes, they are like marzipan filled sweet rolls!!!
author: R T.

description:
I will forever be a fan of their coffee crunch cake. This cake was a staple at every one of my birthday parties growing up and I remember loving this cake ever since I was a little girl. I'm really not a big fan of asian styled cakes, as it is usually less sweet but this one is made with such perfection. The "icing on the cake" is the toffee pieces they put surrounding the outside. 

Just thinking about the cake makes me want to go right now and order a slice! You should go get one too!
author: Michelle C.

description:
A sad, slow demise for Eastern Bakery.  While growing up, this place was owned by a family who eventually sold it in the 1980's.  Before it changed hands, it was famous for locally made moon cakes with single and double egg yolks baked inside and packaged in their pretty blue, multi-colored boxes with a picture of the moon goddess on top.  I liked their packaged Smackles, a sort of flour based, thin, crunchy cookie.  This place was also the go to place for baked cookies and goods ordered in advance and in large quantities that families would share with friends and relatives for an engagement party.  

Not much of the current items taste like it used to anymore.  Even the Smackles taste like it has too much flour in it. We went in to see if there was anything we would be interested in trying again and nothing looked attractive and we didn't even see any cakes in the display cases.  The place is so run down now, hasn't been remodeled at all after all these decades.
author: Ry T.

description: Coffee Crunch Cake, melon cakes, and Buddha Cookies (a cookie that is only the crust of their moon cakes).  The recipe for the noodle puff cakes has changed over the years...not quite as delicious as I remember from my childhood.  Oh yes, and if you need an Apple pie that is not too sweet...this is the place.  Eastern Bakery is a San Francisco institution.
author: H W.

description:
I was looking for the standard Chinatown walking tour and one of the recommended stops was Eastern Bakery.   There's definitely a cultural difference when it comes to customer service in China Town.   I get the impression they're barking at you to hurry up your order (which may or may not be the intention).   With that said I purchased one butter cream bun, a couple chocolate covered fortune cookies, and a golden lotus moon cake.   I wish they gave me napkins after I paid for the items but once I got back to my room, I noshed on the butter cream bun (YUM....may have to go back just for that) and one of the chocolate fortune cookies.   The combo of the cookie and chocolate is always a winner...and my fortune...

"You are contemplative and analytical by nature." (IN BED)

So true...woo hoo!

Honestly I'm sure it's a luck of the draw that Eastern Bakery was the chosen one on the  map tour but it served its purpose well.
author: Eric G.

description:
I initially stopped by this place to grab a BBQ pork bun for lunch as I strolled around Chinatown doing a little geocaching.  From its tired and worn-out appearance, and the fact that there were no customers during the lunch hour, I was a little hesitant and skeptical about this place, but I thought I'd give it a try.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The bun was soft and just the right sweetness.  The pork didn't have that typical bright red color and had a looser consistency, but the flavor was excellent with a hint of onion.  Filled me up for $1.10.

I came back later to pick up an egg custard for an egg custard cage match among five different Chinatown bakeries.  Much to my surprise, this was the top choice of my entire family.  The crust is very flaky and surprisingly crisp in texture, perhaps a little sweeter than expected but still very nice.  The custard had a slightly firmer texture - not as creamy as some other places - and had just the right balance of sweetness and egginess.

So this place appears to be our bakery of choice - for now.  There are still a few others that deserve their place at the tasting table.
author: Lee L.

description:
I LOVE desserts, heck I would order desserts before the main course sometimes but honestly I am not a fan of Asian desserts because they're not rich/sweet enough however, this past Saturday's visit to this bakery made me a fan.  

I was at the store next door looking at woks and steamers.  I cook and bake so I am always on a hunt for more cookware and bakeware.  After leaving the shop, I walked by what I have never seen before - chocolate covered fortune cookies and chocolate covered moon cakes!  Granted, I have bought fortune cookies from the grocery store and made chocolate ganache and dipped it at home but I have never seen it live in person at a store before.  I was stoked.  The 5 stars is for creativity!  

To my right were more enticing decadents but what caught my was the chocolate covered moon cakes.  Moon cakes are expensive; a box of 4 can range between $15-$20.  I saw individual ones being sold for $4-$6.  Hell no, I might as well get a box for myself then but I am seriously trying to eat healthier.  I have the San Jose Rock and Roll Half Marathon in October, the 5k Turkey Trot on Thanksgiving Day, Tough Mudder in Lake Tahoe, and the other runs to help benefit foundations for leukemia, diabetes, breast cancer, and heart disease.  This is the year where I will overcome my intimidation and just do it.  Plus, I'm conversing w/ a guy that doesn't eat fried foods, burgers, and sweets.  What do you call that?  Good influence!

The lady surprisingly speaks English though not well enough to hold a conversation but good enough to know what I'm ordering and to count back my change.  Cash only and they have a dine-in area as well though cleanliness is questionable, after my first bite, I was in awe.  

- chocolate covered fortune cookies $1 each or $1.75 for 2 
- chocolate covered black or red bean moon cakes $1.95 each or $3 for 2 

BTW- there are fortunes inside the fortune cookie.  My daughter warned me but as always, I don't listen.  I took a big ass bite and what do you know, I almost ate my fortune.  By the time I spit it out, I wasn't able to read it... I was seriously sad for a few seconds.  The fortune cookie was delicious... crunchy and semi-sweet... the chocolate covered black bean moon cakes was out of this world. 

I might visit here and Fort Mason again this weekend *hearts*
author: Tram N.

description:
Items Selected:

Egg Custard
Sesame Bun with Black Bean Paste
Coffee Crunch Cake

Impressed as I was by Golden Gate Bakery a visit to Eastern Bakery seemed like a good followup during lunch on the last day of the conference...unfortunately the combination of a soggy, luke warm Egg Custard, oily and meagerly filled sesame buns, and a clerk that ranks high in the running for least friendly of all time marred the one item that truly shined - a coffee crunch cake with four spongy yellow layers divided by light espresso tinged cream and a crunchy toffee topping that not only served as textural variance but also added a hint of needed sweetness without overwhelming the otherwise subtle nuances of the dish.
author: Michael U.

description:
Growing up Cantonese in the Monterey Bay area in the 1970s, my family and I used to have to drive up to SF Chinatown to buy groceries, baked goods, and such; this was before the South Bay was populated with so many Asians.

Eastern Bakery is an institution, and as with other old-school places, are going by the way-side because of the over-saturation and poliferation of other options. You see, way-back-when, these institutions were old stand-bys because ethnic cuisine was far and few in-between - even in Chinatown. 

In my own words, options were narrow, "focused", and good at what they did.

So, I walked on by here today to see what they were like still. Traditionally, they were never considered a hole-in-the-wall, but I actually thought that the current aesthetics were worse. The tables looked grubby, and the seating area was wrought with open storage and boxes, and the place looked like they just didn't care for it anymore. 

I was hungry, then skeptical, as I scanned the cases. Quite frankly, nothing looked appetizing or fresh. Some of the items were saran-wrapped, and this is a red flag for me. 

The only thing that I really wanted was a "butter cream bun," of which I am a connaisseur - it's the one item I try at different places.

Quite frankly, I was still skeptical, cuz the butter cream didn't look like it was freshly squeezed from the pastry bag (i.e. it looked more like a blob that had been sitting there for hours, rather than the usual designs that you see had you just squirted the cream through the pastry bag nozzle).

I also ordered coffee, and the total came out to roughly $2.46. I HATE being disappointed, even when it's a dollar or two spent. Luckily the coffee was pretty OK, but the bun tasted as if it had been in the refrigerator for at least a day. It wasn't soft, and had that firm texture that you get from the cold. The one thing positive is that it was coated with a decent amount of toasted coconut. I didn't bother eating the cream; I slammed the coffee - and left.

What a shame. I'm not sure why this place gets an average of 4-stars here; I wouldn't bother coming back.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Got a bunch of moonackes from them today for Mid-Autumn Festival. I tried the mini red bean and lotus and both were tasty. The pastry is thin and the fillings are not too sweet, just the way I like them. The mooncakes here, and pastries in general, are definitely more Chao Jow/Cantonese style. I got some winter melon cakes as well, thinking they are the same as the ones from Taiwan and was completely thrown off by the filling. These are much sweeter with larger pieces of winter melon and I did not like them. So if that's not what you're into, then you might not love them. But overall a good spot to get your Chinese pastries fix!
author: Nana L.

description: I love Eastern Bakery. My Family has been buying our cakes there since I was 5yrs old. Now I'm 38 yrs old & get my Birthday cakes there for my 2 sons. There cakes are so fresh. We love the Strawberry & Coffee Crunch cakes.I will recommend anyone who wants a delicious cake to try Eastern Bakery. You will not be disappointed.
author: Mimi415 O.

description: The place is a little run down. But the BBQ pork buns were really amazing. Also try the chicken combination bun.
author: Soumyadeep G.

description:
I tried the pork bun (which was fresh out of the oven), the Siu Mai, and the potstickers.  All were delicious.  

The pork bun is FILLED with delicious pork, and no fake red food coloring.

The Siu Mai was yummy, flavorfull, and really big.

The potstickers are THE BIGGEST POTSTICKERS I have ever seen!  They're rather oily, if that's a turnoff for you look elsewhere on the huge menu.

Finally, I finished with a cream puff thingy, that was ok, I think i need to go back for the sesame balls...

The best part is the whole meal was like $6!
author: Ross F.

description: Eastern Bakery has been serving my family for years. When my family comes to SF they order hopia to take back to San Diego. If we are craving it and aren't in SF we order it via mail. Down side is they only take cash. So today I needed more cash because I failed to bring enough and the only ATM across the street was out of order. So unfortunately  my order was cut short due to cash only. Oh well next time.
author: JP P.

description:
There's good reason this establishment has been open since 1942. I always stop by here if I'm visiting Chinatown with out of town guests but, even better last New Years Day, they were open and the smell of fresh baked goods was pouring into the street. WE HAD TO STOP! Out jumped me and my girlfriend while hubby did laps with the car around the block. Our mission: Sesame balls.

These things come PIPING HOT out of the oven. Crisp outsides, flavorful sesame seeds, and wonderful bean insides. So delicious and hot and mouth watering wonderfulness. The Sesame Balls are at a level to which all other Sesame Balls are measured. THAT GOOD!

What's great is that when you're waiting, they have some baked good as samples you can try. The moon cakes are delicious too and so are the egg tarts.

But the Sesame Balls are the winner!
author: Vivian A.

description: We were recommended this place by a mutual friend. Very well done on all 3 dishes we ordered. Quality, ingredients and presentation are acceptable. They do not use excessive oil for cooking. They use good long grain rice for fried rice which is a little dry but still ok. Will return next trip here in town.
author: Monarch T.

description: Everything here is super super sweet. I personally didn't like it at all. Not worth the hype and overrated.
author: Anna H.

description:
I was planning to go to Golden Gate Bakery, but they were closed for vacation and I had already promised my friends I would be bringing them back egg tarts :/  So I was left to trust my Yelp-trained senses to find Chinese baked goods.  I landed at Eastern Bakery, which I found out after the fact to have 4 stars!  Lesson of the day: Yelp-trained senses + Canto upbringing = killer radar for Chinese food

As authentic as a Chinese bakery gets.  First of all, it has an impressive history in its claim as the oldest bakery in Chinatown, as well as photographs of Bill Clinton's visit.  The storefront looks like a hole-in-the-wall at first glance, but you realize that the traditional Chinese architecture coupled with the modest red and yellow awning are telltale signs of its long-standing history--it has no need for any flashy decor.  Even the striking simplicity of the name "Eastern Bakery" reflect the authenticity as something translated directly from Chinese.  (Seriously, I'm sick of places with wannabe catchy names like golden dragon lotus house or whatever.)

I think it's family owned, and the lady who helped me was very friendly.  As I was pondering what to get, she was helpful in making a lot of suggestions without sounding pushy.  They sell a variety of Chinese as well as American baked goods.  It's pretty cheap, and for most items you get a small discount if you buy 3 or 4.  

I got the sponge cake at 3 for $4, which I noticed smelled very good as I was walking home.  I realized halfway though that I forgot to get something for myself.  However I was told that the sponge cake was very tasty.  Seeing that they were fairly big but all 3 pastries were finished in their entirety by 3 girls, I think it's safe to conclude approval.

(Yelp, please don't get bad at me for this semi-vicarious review!  I have a lot to say despite the fact that I didn't actually eat anything.)
author: Edna C.

description: Probably the oldest bakery in chinatown and best coffee crunch cake in the world.
author: Vince L.

description:
I remember coming to this San Francisco bakery when I was real young.  My parents will never go home without stopping by this place to buy their coconut puffs.  In addition, they make good don tats (egg custards), pineapple bun, butter bun, and char siu baos (bbq pork buns).  I think this place kind of rubbed off on me too. Their bakery menu is always fresh.  You could smell the bread aroma the second you walk in. All is still reasonably priced.

If you go in the mornings, you will encounter a lot of elders sitting inside drinking coffee and having breakfast.  Most will be reading the morning newspapers or talking to their fellow elders. So, if you wait or want to sit inside to eat... good luck! 
Just go after they leave when it's around 10:00 a.m. 

Walking in there brings back a lot of memories. I remember walking inside with my parents and siblings back then, and wanting my mom to buy everything in site. Everything still smells the same, looks the same, and feels the same. Gosh, only if they painted the pink walls and frame the picture that probably the owner took with President Clinton would be awesome. 

The presentation is not there.  Everything just looks scattered, and some of the cakes are not even covered.  Who know if an insect landed and feasted on it... it's still sold anyhow. haha.

I guess this is the only place that I think may be excused from the modern bakery presentation.  There is nothing to show, just buy and eat. 

May God Bless their business with many wonderful years to come.
author: ED L.

description: The black beans moon cake was rancid not eatable! Sticky cookies fried wonton too sweet also not eatable!
author: Sue D.

description:
They have pineapple buns. I'm sold.

Oh, it's $0.75 cents for one or a dozen for $8.

Thanks for having a freshly baked pineapple bun ready for me, EB. See you next time I'm in town.
author: Sarah C.

description:
As we passed through the entryway to San Francisco's Chinatown, my eye caught something extremely tantalizing. I noted a blonde tourist  walking along with a baked good in hand that was stuffed with a cream filling. Judging by her smile and the enthusiasm in which she was licking it, my mission became very clear: before leaving Chinatown, I would have one of those damn things. 

I visited several different bakeries, carefully perusing their glass cases for this prized dessert, but I didn't finally locate what I was after until I walked into Eastern Bakery, one of our final stops of the morning. Three Buttercream Buns were bellowing out my name. I immediately began devouring one right in the store. Delicious. The bun itself is brushed with something akin to sugar water, then lightly dusted with coconut flakes. It's light and airy, and the filling, oh the filling! Sweet and creamy, a sheer pleasure to consume! It was the best $.75 I spent all day. Knowing that one of those would surely not be enough to satisfy my yearnings, I opted to purchase two more for the road. Well, not quite for the road, but rather I ended up consuming them in the hotel bed that night. 

My timing at Eastern Bakery was impeccable. Had I arrived just an hour later, those buttercream buns may have been purchased by some other inconsiderate patrons. 

I want more buttercream buns. Now.
author: Gary R.

description: Pretty disappointed with my coffee crunch cake.  It was $5 for a really small slice, which is outrageously expensive considering how it was nothing fancy.  It's just thin layers of cake with coffee cream in between and with crystallized rock sugar on top.  Certain layers were more dry than others and the coffee cream was pretty strong.  I guess coffee flavored cakes just aren't my thing.
author: Samantha C.

description: The best pork buns on this side of the Pacific.    Other awesome baked goods in the case too -  but did I mention the great pork buns?  Especially good hot out of the oven!
author: Peter K.

description: Maybe it just had to do with the time of day we went, but I honestly didn't get that touristy vibe that many people seemed to have felt. The cocktail buns are honestly to die for. We were in San Francisco for four day and went to Eastern Bakery 3 out of the 4 days that we were there. I'm kicking myself because I said I would try the coffee crunch cake before I left, but I never had the chance. Trying to see if they'll ship that along with the cocktail buns!
author: Shane H.

description:
Maybe it's just that by the time I ate my goodies from here I was on a Greyhound bus and starving, but the lotus moon cake I picked up from Eastern Bakery really hit the spot.

The chocolate-covered wintermelon moon cake I ate on site was less delicious and more of a novelty.  It seemed to be kind of thrown together, with the winter melon all on one side and the rest of the filling on the other, and the whole thing just achingly sweet and stringy.

I have to give them props though for being the only business on the tourist street of Chinatown (Grant) with a public restroom.  Granted, the walls were literally smeared with a questionable substance and there was a (hilarious, in context) sign about anyone who used it feeling obligated to buy pastries so they could keep the restroom clean: ha...ha.  But seriously, where do the rest of the places expect the tourists to go?!
author: Hannah E.

description:
I always like to start with the positives.
PROS:
The treats we ordered were absolutely DELISH! My daughter had a custard tart pastry and while I wasn't hungry, they offered me some fresh-out-of-the-oven coconut sweet bread thing for 85¢. The bread was a pretty good size and sooo freaking good! OMGoodness! I will be going to Chinatown , here in Vegas, just to see if I can find it again. Oh so good! 
CONS:
They made 2 cups of coffee while we waited. Though the coffee was good too, the cups were super small, which made me feel like I was getting ripped off. As for the ambience, DO NOT LET IT SCARE YOU. What's a bunch of cardboard boxes when you're eating the best sweet bread EVER?
NEXT TIME:
I'm so mad I didn't know about their pork buns. Pork buns are me and my daughter's faves. I will definitely have to try them next time we're in town.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Not a fan of the "not sure where the line begins and ends" concept, but this is definitely the place for moon cakes. No other moon cakes compare (and we've tried many other brands). Usually we get lotus seed with no yolks, but Dad always wants a lotus seed with double yolk. The contrast of sweet and salty with their delicious, soft crust is pure perfection.  I'm also a huge fan of the melon wives cakes, but everyone else in the family is all about the moon cake!
author: Allie C.

description: This bakery is cash only. I only had $2 on me, but to my surprise there's more than one item I could afford, so I picked a butter cream bun and an egg tart. And OMG, they both taste SO GOOD!!! I think I'm addicted to it already...
author: Kailin X.

description:
stopped by here for a quick snack when walking around Chinatown. My friend got me the pineapple bun, and it was simple and delicious. It brought back old childhood memories of eating a similar baked good when I was a kid. 

Simple and well executed.
author: Sung K.

description: Beautiful day in SF with the family! We strolled through the Haight and then on to China town. After checking out many cool shops in China town we stumbled upon this delightful treat. The thought of a yummy pork bun steered me straight in! I wasn't disappointed! I had the BBQ pork bun and my niece had the chicken bun. The bun was INCREDIBLE!! The soft yeasty flavor melted in my mouth. The owners were incredibly friendly and cheerful to is. The best part... The buns were only $1.25!!!
author: Christina M.

description:
The dim sum is dried up and old. 
The pineapple buns are the only thing worth buying. I think that this is typical for food in China town.
author: Greg H.

description: Arrgh. The place we intended to get cheap dim sum from closed before we got there, so we ended up just eating at some random place that was nearby. I wish I could say it was here, but no, it wasn't: it was a sitdown place whose dim sum was quite mediocre and rather expensive. Exactly as we expected, once we'd *finished* eating dinner there we discovered this place and kicked ourselves, because this place has all kinds of dim sum, all really tasty looking, and just completely bonkers cheap. We got a custard tart (killer good), and a couple of buns, a chicken and a sausage. Given that the buns were like a dollar each, I thought they'd be tiny, but nope, they were enormous. Enormous, delicious and ready to order and eat immediately. I'm coming back here next time, and am now pissed at yelp that this bakery isn't listed under "dim sum" even though they have piles of dim sum here. :(
author: Adam F.

description: You cannot complete the Chinatown experiencing without coming here! They had freshly baked coconut buns for 96 cents. A-M-A-Z-I-N-G
author: Yocelyn S.

description: We love stopping here whenever we are in the city. It's not the cleanest of places but what is in Chinatown?! The steamed BBQ pork buns are the best and we also love the sesame black bean buns. It is cash only so be prepared!
author: Heather T.

description:
I was walking through Chinatown, trying to find a place for a good snack, and happened to walk past Eastern Bakery as I saw it pop up on yelp. That's a sign!

We ordered the Chinese Tamale (couldn't been worse), a baked and a steamed pork bun (both delicious), a black bean bun (light, sweet, yum), and a sausage bun (my favorite of the day), and were totally satisfied. Our total? $7. WHAT? How is it possibly that cheap?

Seriously, though, that sausage bun was so good. I've had Chinese sausage before and not cared for it, but this was oily in the right ways and just... yes. Yes. I'd take one right now. Someone please deliver one to me.
author: Amber G.

description: I'm a fan of their cream buns, pineapple buns (especially when they're hot out of the oven), moon cakes (similar to hopia for the Filipinos out there), and most especially, their coffee crunch cake! Yes, go to this Chinese bakery for a slice for coffee crunch cake. It's delicious, light, just sweet enough, and has a great coffee flavor to it. This is a great quality bakery and a Chinatown standard, so you won't go wrong. Enjoy!
author: Edwina D.

description: 3.5 stars but rounding up to 4 since everyone I know seems to LOVE Coffee Crunch Cake ($15.75, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eastern-bakery-san-francisco?select=wRN_w5Qhz8djDGM1ZFADCw#lFUsltzJeDeCaqoWx1PUjQ). However, it doesn't really do it for me for some reason. I like coffee, and desserts with coffee in them, but I haven't fallen in love with this cake. I think it has something to do with the really sticky coffee flavored toffee crunch that is stuck to the icing all around the cake, since I don't like the taste of it. However, the cake inside is always moist and fluffy, and the icing is also light and airy and not too sweet. I think I would like the cake more without the coffee crunch. In any case, that just means more for everyone else to eat. I actually prefer the Coffee Crunch Cake from Yasukochi's in Japantown since it's not as sticky sweet.
author: Amy D.

description:
My favorite sesame balls of ALL TIME.  Like crack, they are.  The bowties were also fried, sweet goodness.  I went to this bakery at least 4 times while I was in San Francisco. And, it's so cheap!

The gruff cashier, also the best.  People should embrace her, not hate her. Seriously, people.

Good stuff (except not for my cholesterol).
author: Krista N.

description: coffee crunch cake! Enough said.  You should order a whole cake for $15 we ordered a slice and drove it home, and the hubby is super said we didn't buy him a whole cake to eat. I heard their moon cakes are the best, but I'm not a fan.
author: Janet D.

description:
I know, I know. I come from the new wave version of Chintatown in LA, but I can't pass up a chance to give SF Chinatown a try. Pastries and anything sweet is my weakness. We hit Chinatown pretty late during the day, so we were lucky that Eastern Bakery was open until 8 pm! 

We got the following:

- Steamed BBQ pork bun
- Egg tarts
- Wifey cake (lao po bing)
- Chocolate covered lotus mooncake
- sachima, which I translate to killing riding horse

But *recommend* the following:
- EGG TARTS
- steamed BBQ bun

The reason?

- wifey cake was too sweet. The filling still retains small chunks of the melon. I brought extra home and everyone agreed it was pretty sweet for a lao po bing. and it was $3.50 each T_T.
- chocolate covered mooncake was 1/4 of a mooncake. It's a novelty to try but nothing fantastic. Also, it does taste better than it looks as the chocolate part doesn't look very presentable.
- the sachima was pretty compacted, so the texture wasn't loose and flakey like some places. pretty good.
- steamed bbq pork bun had bbq pork that had relatively few fatty parts, wasn't bright red, and the bun was very soft. pretty huge size too.
-egg tart was nice and flakey and buttery. the custard part wasn't super sweet. the entire tart was a nice thick size, not small or thin at other places that make it.

Parking may be hard to find (and meters run 8 minutes per quarter) so definitely bus it if you can. Cash only so bring enough bills. Look out for the photo there that showed Bill Clinton stopping by this bakery.
author: Grace C.

description: I bought some Lao Puo cakes.  I have to say that I am not impressed at all.  They are not soft and by no means authentic.  I won't go back.  For some real Chinese snack and dessert, I will drive to the suburb for some real nice ones.
author: Jiayin L.

description: Just walk in and get a Cocktail Roll. Sweet bread with sugary center. You're welcome!
author: Mitch H.

description:
Cheap and super good! Much less crowded than Golden Gate bakery, and open when Golden Gate was mysteriously closed because they went on vacation.

There are egg tarts but they aren't on display, so don't panic! I came with 2 other friends, and got 6 egg tarts and 3 pineapple buns. We got our egg tarts piping hot, straight out of the oven.

They were so amazing. My friends couldn't help but burn their mouths. I had a more level head and ate mine slowly. The puffed crust is awesome. My friends mentioned that the filling could be more... creamy maybe? I didn't really care. It was very eggy, warm, and not too soft and not too hard.

I ate the pineapple buns later for breakfast. Pretty good for pineapple buns. Maybe they could have used more topping. I like them when they are soft and are totally covered in a thick layer of topping. Both the egg tarts and the pineapple buns held up pretty well in the fridge, even for 2 days.
author: Michael W.

description:
The bf and I were wandering around Chinatown and decided to see what this bakery had in store.

It's definitely a mom-and-pop, hole-in-the-wall type of establishment. Not the cleanest inside, but that didn't matter because the baked goods looked decent. I wanted to try their pineapple bun, but they were all sold out. So, the bf got an egg tart and I had a chocolate covered fortune cookie and we spent less than $2. 

I unfortunately didn't like the fortune cookie at all. The chocolate had a bitter after taste even after asking the guy if it was dark chocolate and he said it was milk chocolate. I won't be getting that again. The bf thought his egg tart was good and flaky, while I wasn't really impressed. I need to go to Golden Gate Bakery to try their egg tart...

I feel like this place is known for their moon cakes and coffee crunch cake, both of which I'm not interested in trying. But, we'll see. 

Customer service is whatever. The older lady seemed pushy. The guy was a lot nicer. 

FYI: CASH ONLY!
author: Fallon P.

description: Yum yum yum. Stop here when in china town. Ask the owner what's hot and he will recommend you what just came out of the oven or a must try!!!! I really like the place. Nothing fancy but definitely delish for Chinese bakery. If you are looking for a coffee sit down this is not the place. But if you want to experience a different type of bakery. Then. This is it.
author: Paola C.

description: I always come here whenever I'm in Chinatown because they have the best butter buns ever! I've been coming here for years and it's always been 75 cents. I'm picky about my buns. Good deal, great buns!
author: Olivia C.

description:
What a great find! I was in SF for the first time last week, and during my layover decided to check out Yelp for some helpful hints since I was going to be there for a only a few days.

Be prepared to not know what a lot of things are, but if you're open to trying them, you'll be pleasantly surprised. My friends and I opted for a few cookies and the moon cakes filled with lotus and black/red bean and were thoroughly contented with our choices.

A great place to score something sweet during your stroll around Chinatown.
author: Alyssa N.

description:
My special friend bought me a birthday cake from this place
It was the coffee crumb cake with toffee toppings
Quite honestly the best cake I have ever had
Ate the whole thing (yes the whole thing) in 3 days
Cake was soft and fluffy on the inside, crunchy and savory on the outside. Just the right balance of sweet and salty. Not nauseatingly rich but not distastefully un-flavorful, just perfect. 
Will be visiting this place in person soon
author: Bowen J.

description: Purchased a few egg tarts bean cake. Egg tarts were ok but the bean cake was really dry and tastes old.  Was looking forward to trying these but was not totally satisfied with so so items.
author: Aiden S.

description: ok said I wouldn't be buying from them anymore. did it again ! this time they were closed for a week so who could hold cakes that long ? well it was ok my kids said. so that was good .so my husband went to buy one today a chocolate one he said they had to go downstairs and get it so maybe it would be ok ... WRONG ! the cream was fresh but the cake part was old and hard as a rock ! we tried it .we had to throw it out ! I see your best bet is to order one and not a common size to insure it is not one that is lying around for days !!!
author: Nellie J.

description: Omg! Best pork buns I've ever had! They are huge and only $1.35 each! They even have these other ones that are baked that are delicious too (can't remember what they were called though. And they have huge delicious sponge cake pieces that are also yummy. If you are every I Chinatown, I would definitely recommend stopping in this place. :)
author: WilliamandCrystal G.

description: Great place...wonderful steamed buns...especially liked the cocktail buns. Good egg custard tarts and lotus seed pastries of various stripes...great red bean buns.
author: Mary Beth L.

description: At their suggestion, we tried the fresh-from-the-oven, cocktail bun. I would give anything to go back for more! I will never forget how delicious that bun was. Sweet coconut filling surrounded by warm bread. Good thing calories and carbs don't count while you're on vacation!
author: Chris N.

description: Best custard! Hot out of the oven. Silky. Amazing. It is a classic in SF Chinatown. They have a large assortment of many typical pastries expected in Chinatown bakery. I'm sure it has changed over the years but I've always enjoyed stopping in for a custard or twelve. Very inexpensive treats while trekking through Chinatown. It's totally worth the wait for a fresh batch right out of the oven. Just ask and they will fire up a batch.
author: Gregory H.

description:
I read an article, 11 Best Pork Buns.  One of the places in Chinatown was out of the pork buns at 11:30am, so we went to Eastern Bakery because they were also on the list! 

Whoa... these are the worst pork buns I've ever had.  So little meat filling and if you like booze, they had a boozy taste!!  The person that wrote the article has no taste!!! 

We will keep getting the coffee crunch cake and honey bow-ties but the rest forget it!!
author: M. K.

description: Came here to get some mooncakes and pastries since Golden Gate Bakery was closed. The pastries were surprisingly good, though the mooncake can't beat the ones at GGB. Definitely a good alternative if you're too lazy to wait in the long line at GGB!
author: Christina N.

description: Centrally located in Chinatown, this can easily be your one stop shop for Asian baked goods. They have a huge selection where pretty much anyone can find something that they would like. I simply got a chocolate chip cookie (more like chocolate chunks rather than chips) and it was very good. It's difficult to tell from appearance, but the cookie tasted very fresh (I ate it a couple of days after purchasing) and it had a great texture. I prefer cookies that are soft as compared to crunchy and it was nice and soft and had the perfect amount of chocolate chunks. I was the only customer in the bakery at the time so I was able to pick my cookie and pay in less than two minutes.
author: Michael G.

description:
Simple. They don't care about their customers.

Came in at 7:30pm and asked for baked BBQ pork buns in Cantonese. Owner lady says yes we still have them and I asked for two of them and also a cocktail bun.

Paid my mere $2.95 and waited for the lady to put my products in a bag. Left the place and came to discover that she gave me the steamed BBQ pork buns. I walked back and asked her how come they are the steamed ones...she said they ran out of the baked ones.

At first I thought okay, I already paid for it. I peeled a piece off as I walked towards my car and it was cold, stale, and disgusting. 

Not only did I feel cheated, it wasn't even worth it to begin with. Shame on them for trying to get rid of their products by lying to people. It's not even about the money...it's the principle of not doing business correctly.
author: Kenny T.

description: Delicious moon cakes! Softest moon cakes I've ever had. The pork bun was amazing as well, nice and warm.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
Because of all the yelp reviews, I went to get a piece of the coffee crunch cake.  The toffee pieces were way too sweet for me.  The cake was so airy, it was like eating nothing. Eating the cake is like eating only icing and candy.  I wouldn't get the cake again.  

Also, I asked for a fork. The old lady gave me a really scratched up plastic fork.... I tossed the fork as soon as I could. 

We also got a coconut bun.  It was also just meh.
author: C Q.

description: Had the buttery cream bun(?) and thought it was pretty good. My friends had their dim sum and the non-chinese friend said they were good but my chinese friend didn't like them. So i guess if you're not a dim sum connoisseur it seems decent :)
author: Suzy K.

description: Dim sum are overpriced. 3 siu Mai should be about 2.1 for 2.8. Quality is same as the cheaper places ones
author: misa w.

description:
A friend took me to this little place when I was going to briefly live in San Francisco. After the first bite of their BBQ pork bun, I was totally hooked. I love how the bun's dough is sticky, soft and feels great in your mouth. It compliments the stuffing of it so well. I frequented this place so much and I make a stop every time I visit SF.

I knocked a star off because the service could be a bit friendlier. The woman just sort of rushes you and I'm always so happy whenever I enter the bakery. I wish the kindness was returned. However, maybe she's just focused and tries to rush because the line tends to get long pretty quickly.
author: Lisa G.

description: Not great on costumer service. But the bomb for their goodies. I had the chocolate coconut Macaroons. You want 10 of those. Super soft and flavorful and buttery.
author: Prusha S.

description: Tiny little hole in the wall bakery with the most amazing food. Try the baked or steamed pork buns.
author: Candace E.

description:
Decent option. 

This place was alright - definitely very authentic. We had the egg custards, which didn't impress us to the degree of other yelpers, but they were good.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Exploring chinese food can be intimidating, but not here! Extremely friendly and helpful staff and delicious pastries to boot. Try the Chinese donut, bbq pork steamed buns or coconut steam buns!
author: M. D.

description: I was so happy to find traditional moon cakes in SF. They tasted fresh and authentic. We also purchased snow skin moon cakes but they don't seem the same as what we can get in Singapore and Hong Kong.
author: Sonia K.

description: Got our TIKOY (sticky new year rice cake) brown sugar flavor and the coconut flavored one! We also bought their famous black bean moon cake and coconut moon cake. This is your typical Chinese bakery. Once you get inside, you will have that vibe that would take you to CHINA.
author: Cece G.

description:
This place is fantastic - the steamed pork buns are just amazing... As I sit on my couch here in Los Angeles writing this review I can't stop thinking about them buns.... So so good. 

Also apparently Bill Clinton has been there too and we all know he like big buns... Fantastic spot...  I'm bummed I did not try the coffee.
author: J T.

description: Great Chinese bakery.  I come for lunch and get the Zongzi (glutinous rice stuffed with different fillings, wrapped large flat leaves and steamed).  They are delicious, filling, and inexpensive.  Add a cup of tea and you're set!  Also, the steamed pork bun is very good.  They also have many different moon cakes and pastries.  Chocolate-dipped coconut macaroons are fantastic.  The owners are friendly.
author: J E.

description:
I work 1 block away and whenever I feeling like a pork-bun kind of morning. I will take the chance of being late to grab a couple pork buns. 

Their buns are massive (hehe). 

For a small asian girl like me, I can eat one for breakfast and one for lunch and call it a day! I believe there are 0.85 per. It is usually pretty dead in the morning, so it is a definitely an in and out kind of thing. If the asian ladies are feeling kinda sweet, they will grab one hot and fresh from the oven. ^_^
author: Phuong V.

description: My parents got their wedding cake here over 30 years ago. Now apparently, they're known for mooncakes and they were pretty yummy. I'm a sucker for the honey glazed butterflies and they had plenty of other goodies too. Great prices and friendly service!
author: Mel L.

description: They have a wide array of items at reasonable prices... while it was nice sampling a ton of them, I was mostly unimpressed. It is definitely geared at tourists. Pretty standard in general, although I did think their version of a Lotus Mooncake was fantastic!
author: Andrya S.

description: The black bean cakes and moon cakes are old... it's so dry and crumby. Will not recommend to friends.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Went here on the suggestion of a co-worker in search of some good lotus buns, and this place did not disappoint. They had a multitude of pastries on display in cases when you walk in and everything was well labeled enough that we could figure out what it was we wanted.

The lady helping us was very nice, and when she noticed we were ordering things with coconut in it, suggested a coconut bun to us which was pure freaking heaven! I will be going back for more of those for sure!

We ended up with a TON of pastries to last us for a few days and only spent 20 bucks! The prices are amazing. They only take cash, but that is okay. This place is a must visit and so worth it.
author: Tommy G.

description: When in sf, Always gotta get fresh egg custard, rice cake & sesame balls. If u want 3 dozen like we do, u must call ahead of time. We've been coming to this bakery for years. Always consistently good!
author: Kellie Y.

description: What a gem! This is a fantastic little bakery located on grand Avenue in Chinatown, San Francisco.
author: Jen V.

description: Yessssssssss. That's all that is needed to say. Just come here and get the baked pork buns. That is all.
author: Daniel T.

description:
I went here a few years ago not knowing that their coffee crunch cake is super famous! Finally I came back a few days ago to try it.

The coffee crunch is a bit too sweet for my teeth, but the cake tastes pretty good, even without the coffee crunch.

Definitely an interesting bakery to venture to, especially for tourists.
author: Novalina N.

description: The coffee crunch cake is awesome!  Our addition to the wedding cake was more popular than the main because of this wonderful confection!
author: Chris C.

description: Um... wow.  So the service leaves something to be desired and its really not clear how to get some of the items they sell... but the food was delicious.  After experiencing Asian cakes in Texas I was hesitant to even try this place.  But, I'm glad I did... this was some of the best stuff I've had.  Overall, the prices are a little high (but it is California... i guess), but I've never been so satisfied from Chinese baked goods.  I can't wait to give this place another go... one day.
author: Alan S.

description:
The Eastern Bakery is a cute little Chinese bakery located in the heart of China town.

The first thing I noticed when I walked in, was that there were several large photographs of President Clinton eating there.  There is also a sign on one of the photos saying "Eastern Bakery is the oldest bakery in Chinatown.  Since 1924!  We were here before the great depression, the bay bridges, World War II, etc."  So, that was pretty cool.

They have a large selection of traditional Chinese baked goodies.  Be prepared for some very aggressive upselling going on there.  Expect it if you don't order mass quantities or the large cakes.  It just adds to the experience.

I ordered up a Lotus Cake.  How many?!?!  Just one... so, I received a bit of flak for that as well as a very aggressive "suggestion" to buy some custard tarts as well.

It was fun and I would be interested in trying more of their pastries.
author: Eric H.

description:
I wasn't overly impressed with the food here. I think since its closer to the Chinatown gates it is a little more touristy. I tried their baked pork bao, a steam pork bao, sesame ball, and a mellon cookie. I was disappointed by the baos, theirs were a little more old school style that had a strong taste of rice wine and the flavor profile was more savory than sweet. Often bbq pork baos have a good balance of both sweet and savory. The steam bao was not fluffy and light, but a little on the denser side. 

My favorite was the sesame ball, they are huge and filled with a red bean paste. The texture was not overly chewy but had a good bite. The shell was covered with sesame and was not overly sweet, but had a good hint of brown sugar.
author: Vay V.

description: At first, this seems like a typical Chinatown bakery - crowded with little seating, a long counter of options, and not the most appealing exterior. The unusual thing is that they have so many things covered in chocolate - moon cakes, fortune cookies, etc all in bite sized pieces.  They also have your usual dim sum items and breads.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Thank goodness that someone speaks English here! You can actually order on the phone. After countless calls around different Chinese bakeries, Eastern Bakery didn't hang up on me. 

If you are ordering for a large party, 84 dollars will get you enough food for 60 people. We even had some left overs. 

What I ordered: 
4 dozen - Sesame Balls 
4 dozen - Shrimp Dumplings
3 dozen - Veggie Buns

The sesame balls and veggie buns can be split in half, but I don't suggest cutting the shrimp dumplings.  The food will be warm for your pick-up. Make sure if you need a receipt, you ask for it after you pay, because they won't remember.
author: Moua L.

description:
OMG, Yelpers, you failed me. I know there is no really good dim sum place in Chinatown, but I happened to have the taste for it while walking around the area. So I consulted Yelp hoping to find an OK place and this place showed up with 4 stars. So with my blind trust of fellow yelpers, I walked inside, though I should have trusted my instinct and left. Anyways, I ordered shrimp dumplings, which is my tester for dim sum restaurants. This is a dish that is at every dim sum restaurant and if a place can't do good shrimp dumplings, you can forget about other dishes. In addition, I ordered shumai and pan-fried dumplings. The owner yelled my order in Cantonese through some intercom. "Well," I thought "at least she is speaking the right dialect." I was led to sit at one of those tables at the back. The tables were dirty and there was some leftover from the previous guests. There were random boxes and stuff in this area. "Chaotic like many Chinese restaurants. Maybe this place is really authentic and good?" the optimist in me still hoped. 

Then the food came. Shrimp dumplings and shumai looked quite stale. I would believe that they were left over from days ago and were just reheated. The fried dumplings were huge and much of it was dough. The owner brought the food over and a plastic folk. I was puzzled. Isn't this a Chinese restaurant? Didn't I ordered in Chinese? What made her think I need a folk to eat my food? So I asked for chopsticks. She simply said that she didn't have any. I had to laugh. Then I asked for some Chinese vinegar which usual comes with fried dumplings and she again said she didn't have any. Now this is a total joke. Well, since the food was cheap and I was hungry, I tried to food. Just as I suspected, it was horribly bad. Easily the worst dim sum I have ever tried. 

To be fair, I bought a mooncake on the way out, and that was good. Maybe come to this place for their baked goods, but never, I say never venture to eat dim sum here.
author: Ally W.

description:
Came in for the strawberry shortcake. 
Supposedly it is the best. 
I wouldn't know tho. I bought it. 
But I had my hands full and was juggling bags of crap. 
So I set it down on top of a trashcan, readjusted my carrying situation. 
And proceeded to walk off without it. Meh. 
A homeless gentleman probably liked it.

What I did love about this place is the service.
That lady is the best. I was waiting for them to grab something. Might have been pineapple buns? I like those. 
Anyways...I am standing there and she ran out of change. 
I tell her I have change and give her twenty in change. She says thank you. 
I get my lunch and cakes and stuff. Pay up and she didn't give me any change. 
She told me to wait until she gets more change. 
I think she likes me so I let her keep it.

Another time, I was waiting for some fresh pork buns? I like those.
When a family of Vikings with heavy ass accents walks in and is trying to order. 
She totally ignores the head Viking and asks me if I am with them.
I did a double take looking both ways and ask her,
"Is it because I am 6'6" with blonde hair and blue eyes?"
She then tells me to tell her what they are saying. 
She must like me.

Last time I was in there. Ordered up, got my bag, and paid the nice lady.
Then the oddest oddity happened.  
She grabbed my hand, opened it, put the change in my palm, closed my hand, and smiled.
Now I know she likes me.
Swooooooooooooooooooooooooooonnn!!!

I like the pork buns and the lady,
the lady a little more than the pork buns.
I still like the bakeries in Oakland better.
/runs.
author: Rossi H.

description:
Eastern Bakery was my only stop in Chinatown on my recent trip to SF. It was Sunday and the sun was going down at 4:30ish in the afternoon. I desperately wanted to visit this place before my flight that evening. Thank goodness that Eastern was still open. Unlike Golden Gate Bakery which was closed for vacation.

Eastern has a lot of Chinese goodies to choose from. They have items like egg tarts, cakes, even lo mai gai (sticky rice in wrapper). But the main star of the show are their mooncakes, which are apparently highly praised. I picked up a rose black bean ($4.25) and wintermelon mooncake ($5.45). 

While that seems pricey for a couple of bites, they are definitely worth it. Plus, I like the variety available here. If you are a fan of mooncake, Eastern deserves a visit when in SF.
author: Jon L.

description: The egg custard tart here is by far the best! Custard was lightly sweet with no overpowering egg taste. Crust was nice and flaky. If you happen to get a batch right out of the oven, even better! Nice and warm and the custard still jiggly. Mmm mmm mmm! I'd say even better than Golden Gate Bakery and cheaper too!
author: Tripps F.

description:
I LOVE the jin dui here. It is always fresh, crispy, and not thick and chewy like other places. Plus they're bigger than my fist! Can't lose there. 
Their chicken bao, which I've tried recently, are also pretty good. The filling is a bit different; it consisted of pieces of chicken with chopped up veggie and mushroom, with a piece of lop chong (chinese sausage) and a sliver of boiled egg. That and some gravy like sauce that kept the bao from sucking the moisture out of your mouth.
The veggie/pork bao, however, is another story. At about 4-5 inches wide, the filling was a pathetic melon ball sized scoop of veggie, pork, and mushroom. I was embarassed to have bought it for my bf's parents.
Overall, however, all the goodies are really cheap and (almost) everything was good, so I can't complain.
author: Karen C.

description: Our favorite place in San Francisco!   The steamed buns, Chinese donuts, and cocktail buns are amazing, and for $5 we were both stuffed and happy.  So happy we went back the next day.  Can't wait to return next time we're in SF.
author: The L.

description: The food was good, but what I especially liked is the picture they had of the trigonometric unit circle complete with sine and cosine values of special angles. Really made learning fun!
author: Tom G.

description: Coffee Crunch Cake! Sometimes you will get a fresh one or a day old one. It's a gamble
author: Tasha L.

description: warning: cash only. Assortment of tasty moon cakes, cookies, and buns. Lotus cakes are interesting but sticky! good for a quick yummy snack while strolling around chinatown.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Very few things stay as good as you remembered from when you were a child. After not having one of their moon cakes for years, I broke down and bought a box for this year's Mid Autumn Festival. Its distinct taste is exactly the same and as good as I remembered as a child. 

The shop itself has a very mom and pop antiquated feel. If you are the type that likes squeaky clean shop presentations, this place might not be for you.
