The folks behind the counter were obviously well versed in dealing with touristy types and tried to push various products on us. However they were very pleasant and not rude at all.
author: Clayton Y.

description:
Great pastries, but needs updates to the interior of the place. Has not changed the look since I can remember (at least 15 years). I normally go for the Buddha cookies and Wintermelon cakes. The buddha cookies are something that is not too well known, but I think they are a lot of fun to eat. 

President Obama needs to visit this place so they can update their picture with President Clinton.
author: Matt L.

description: You can't beat the prices and quality of this bakery. The mooncakes are exceptional. Any time I come to San Francisco I make sure I stop by.
author: Majesta Z.

description: Not very clean. My bubble tea was only kind of cold. Service was mediocre and I got a stomachs following my visit.
author: Lucy D.

description:
A standing example of how most chinese food in Chinatown is horrible. The steamed pork bun was worse than anything in the frozen section of 99 Ranch. It was obviously days old, sitting in the steamer. The skin was dry with a weird consistency, reminiscent of my 88 year old grandmother.

Even the western themed food such as the famous coffee cake was extremely pedestrian. It was overly sweet and the toffee pieces got stuck everywhere in my teeth. 

The point to take away from all this? Don't judge Chinese food from your visit to Chinatown please. =)
author: Henry W.

description: Old school style in SF Chinatown. I love love love their banana rice cake. The also sell moon cakes and fortune cookies.
author: Spencer L.

description:
I've purchased cakes here plenty of times and can't believe i haven't written a review.

Coffee Crunch, Chocolate, & Strawberry cakes are yummy! I've had their ha gao, shiu mai, and cha siu bao, dimsum and it's OK.

Service is usually OK just make sure you know what you want...

CASH ONLY

funny story..
I was there picking up a 1/4 sheet coffee crunch ($36.50) for my bf's birthday and following my transaction, 

another customer said (very annoyingly might i add) "i want something salty, do you have anything salty"

worker motioned over to the dim sum list

then the customer repeated herself "i want something salty"

worker motioned again and said "maybe a pork bun?"

the customer said again "i want something salty, everything in the window looks sweet."

worker said "i guess we don't have what you're looking for, maybe go to another store." and pointed her towards union square.

LOL that was really entertaining to watch.

Following that, the Guai Lo I was with had lots of questions such as "the pineapple shaped bun, does it have pineapple?" to which the lady said 'no pineapple, it's just the shape" and then i asked my friend "do you know what you want?" and she said 'i have more questions." i said "this is not a place for questions. choose something or let's get outta here"

I'm not saying that they have bad service from this story, i'm trying to say "figure stuff out BEFORE asking them for what you want.. take a risk and try something new OR research it online b/c if i got the same questions as the server was asked, i'd be very annoyed.

PS i'm Guai Lo.
author: J-nine I.

description: Stopped here to buy snacks. I was the first customer. It was deserted. Now I know why. The sponge cake was yesterday's. Old and stale. The dim sum and pork buns were fresh but did not taste that good at all. I threw all that away. The woman at the counter is so irritated that I didn't dare ask for a fresh sponge cake or a refund.   The best thing was the sesame ball.  The cookies were stale too. What a disappointment
author: Sarah S.

description:
It doesn't matter how old this bakery is or if they are formerly known for coffee crumb cake and mooncakes.

With the exception of mooncakes, most of the coreline products are downright fugly, and are horrible representations of Southern Chinese/Cantonese style western baked goods and pastries, and pale imitations of what bakeries in Hong Kong would sell. Even the baos and buns looked like they survived a nuclear attack (and I don't mean a microwave ding ding machine, as they would refer to it in Cantonese...yes "ding" is a verb, meaning to micronuke...and "ding" can also refer to Nissan Demae instant noodles...yes the slanguage is gloriou$). Yes I know it's Chinatown and this place is stuck in time, like Sam Wo or Dick Lee's dicky dim sum buffet, but still.

It's like the latest James Bond movie....only the theme song was stellar. Only got the bad boy look, but literally a dearth of high tech gadgets, no bells no whistles.

For true Hong Kong style bakery....Kee Wah is a bright shining example. Too bad they're too focused on Southern California, with three out of the way locations in SF Bay Area (the Cupertino one being quite possibly the best of the lot). Eastern Bakery is known for moon cakes? Errrr try the ones at Golden Gate Bakery, or Kee Wah. Or the standard puff pastry exterior no preservative ones from Cooking Papa (seasonal).

But look at the other bakeries....as old as the others are, including Golden Gate Bakery, the competition puts way more effort in presentation and keeping up with quality. Chinese people put a lot of emphasis on color, quality, smell, and taste...it's called eating with all the senses. Fugly affects 90%!

Perfectly fine for tourists, but definitely not my style.
author: Ken K.

description: So yummy! Crispy sesame red bean balls and big juicy shumai! Absolutely love this shop!
author: Brittany L.

description: Try the pineapple shaped bun. It would be perfect with some hot chocolate. We tried and liked the coconut moon cake also. It is filled with a not-too-sweet coconut filling that has nuts also. But we LOVED the pineapple bun.
author: Josh R.

description: Been here several times over the years, and I always feel like there's a Chinese grandma in the back room making all of these cool little things in the back.  There probably is!  I love the display up front, which shows you all the different things they make so you can see what they look like on the inside and out.  Nice for those of us clueless folks.
author: Allie A.

description:
30+ years later, it's still the same goodness.

As a kid, my dad would take us here to buy a coffee crunch cake - Sponge cake smothered with mocha frosting and broken up pieces of candied coffee on the top and sides.  It's hard to believe that it's just as good 30 years later.  Wife and I ordered a slice of coffee crunch cake and a couple of black bean cake pastries.  So good!
author: Rainier V.

description: I have been here a lot over the years.  This is the cousin of Golden Gate Bakery; it is owned by the brother of the owner of Golden Gate.  I like Golden Gate a bit better, but this is pretty good, filling a void weather you stop in just passing by or want to avoid the lines at Golden Gate around Chinese Newyear as in last Saturday.  The moon cakes are fresh with a soft exterior & creamy interior of lotus seed paste & lotus seeds.  The egg custard tarts are served warm & have a pretty good flaky crust & smooth custard.  The almond cookies are fresh, crispy, & almondy.  Of course, you cannot go wrong with the various spounge cakes & other varieties of moon cakes including black bean paste, red bean paste, yellow bean paste, & creative ones like winter milon & mixed nut.  For those in the mood for American fare, they have chocolate cookies & other American things, but are mostly Chinese.  The prices are reasonable & the service while brisk, is friendly.  The prices are reasonable.  So, for some good Chinese & American baked goods at reasonable price in a no frills bare bones atmosphere, Eastern Bakery cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description:
Y'know, "Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull" could have been a better film if they just replaced that piece of foggy quartz from Pier One with a custard tart from Eastern Bakery. Now that is something worth kicking Cate Blanchett's ass from here to Minsk. After all, walking through Chinatown can be quite a life-threatening adventure, too...ever been to Sam Wo's?

But you don't have to worry about diarrhea...much. All the standard Chinese sweets are here in an ancient-looking storefront with the most dilapidated sign in San Francisco. You can get a little custard tart and a nice slab of sticky rice for less than $4...not bad if you can afford the calories. I can't because I'll be in training for the next installment in the series..."Indiana Jones and the Synagogue of the Custard Tarts". I have Barbra Streisand lined up to sing the title song..."Oy! I Should Just Put Those Things on My Hips...Oh I Did".

By the way, in the centuries-old battle between Eastern Bakery and Golden Gate Bakery as to who offers the best custard tart, the answer is....AAAAHHHHHH! The alien incinerated my brain! ...I hate when that happens.

SWEETS - 3.5 stars...hmmm, good...well, the tart, that is
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...Chinatown rundown
SERVICE - 3 stars...just point at what you want...it's easier
TOTAL - 3 stars...I think I'd still go to Golden Gate Bakery before I go Eastern, but if there's a line....
author: Ed U.

description:
Egg tarts egg tarts egg tarts! My friends and I were in town and randomly came upon this place and saw these huge egg tarts! We ordered at least 2 dozen ourselves to indulge upon ourselves. And by far It's possibly the best egg tarts i've had!

The egg tart is big and the pastry around it is crispy and light. The tart in the middle is sweet and not overpowering. The egg wasn't too distinct but it was prominent enough that you know it's made out of egg but sweet enough to know it's a dessert. 

Will get more when i'm back in San Francisco!
author: Sam H.

description: this is an old school Chinese bakery on Grant Street in San Francisco. I'm not sure why some of the best Chinese places that I've ever been come across as dumps but this one sure qualifies. That being said it also meets the other part namely that the food is just excellent. This place is been around as long as I can remember. Don't be put off by the fact that everything seems to be written in Chinese. The staff will help you and you will have a fantastic experience. Just come hungry.
author: Duane H.

description: Took 2 hour trip on BART ride and walk on Saturday to Eastern Bakery and bought 3 boxes of moon cakes costing over $76. They take only cash, and when I got home and opened the boxes, they were mold inside the individually wrapped cakes! Been buying moon cakes there every year for many years. Guess this will be my last year.
author: Jeff M.

description: Coffee Crunch cake is our family tradition for birthdays, anniversaries and and celebration! So good! So special!
author: Sharon S.

description: Overall it was ok. The egg tart was good as was the Chinese donut (a sesame ball).  The coconut filled bread was excellent.  I want more.
author: Jessica E.

description: Boba tea could've been better, only thing I'm reviewing on. Their sweets looked good. Only cash.
author: Luis L.

description:
Chinese Entrepreneurial Lady #1: "We need to find a way to SELL THESE MOONCAKES to all the white people. They don't seem to like them very much. What can we do?"

Chinese Entrepreneurial Lady #2: "I know, we will DIP THEM IN CHOCOLATE"

Success!
author: Lauren M.

description: Really good pineapple buns and steamed cake. Both were light and fluffy! Also have egg tarts and moon cakes but I was too full from lunch to try anything else.
author: S. S.

description:
The place is a bit divey, very cool- apparently Bill Clinton went here? There's photos everywhere, it's adorable. Eastern Bakery super authentic and the owners are friendly.
The BBQ pork bun is literally the greatest thing on earth. Seriously, try it. I felt like I could've eaten a thousand.
author: Laura G.

description:
This is the only bakery shop in the bay area where i can find "dan san", which is my favorite, along with "ma tsai". thumbs up!

My favorite bakery in Chinatown: AA Bakery (for egg tart), Napoleon (for ma tsai), Eastern Bakery (dan san and ma tsai) and Wa Li (buns and egg tart).
author: Ashley C.

description:
OMG, I can't believe I had such a bad experience here. We stopped by one morning looking for a quick snack before heading out to Tomales Bay. We just walked, walked, walked and stumbled upon this bakery because there was a huge long line of people. Well, they were tourists because they went inside, looked around, ooh-ed and aah-ed and filed back out and started taking pictures out in front. So I suggested us getting a BBQ pork bun. I was going to go with steamed, but when she opened the display case to the baked ones, the bf and I got the same thing for $1/each. Then I saw the fried sesame balls filled with red bean paste and got one of those as a sweet treat for 75 cents. We took our brown bag and each took a bite. 

I was a little confused because there was no sweet porky goodness. The meat was light brown and had a sour taste to it. I had to take another bite to find out what was going on. The bf and I looked at each other and I said I was going to throw mine away. I think he finished his, but it's only because we were starving. All I could think of was, "I hope I don't end up puking this up later today." 

So I turned to the last thing in my bag which was the fried sesame ball because how could you screw that up right? Well, when I bit into it, a whoosh of air came out and it deflated. I didn't taste anything so I look at it and it was all empty with a sad little ball of red bean paste literally rolling around inside the shell. It was a huge ball, but it was a misrepresentation of what was inside. Which was a bunch of air. This was the worst meal of the weekend. I still cringe thinking about that pork - ick, it just gives me the heebie jeebies. I didn't get sick, but good grief, I want my $2.75 back!! Cash only, of course.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description: Someone brought in a 1/4 sheet coffee crunch cake at work.  Since the cake was big, you know it's fresh.  Cake was beautifully decorated and it was light and good. It also wasn't cloyingly sweet.  If you like it sweeter, go to Yasukochi's Sweet Stop. If you don't like it too sweet, get one here!
author: Wendy H.

description: Stopped by here since I thought Golden Gate was closed today, and this bakery has similar treats that are delicious! It's a little chaotic inside, there were only two workers this afternoon. I pointed out what I wanted...I really wanted dan tat (custard egg tarts) but they looked moldy in the showcase. I chose the chocolate sponge cake rolls with cream and the lemon sponge triangle along with regular sponge cakes. They threw them all in three separate small paper bags and my friend who ordered the same thing got everything in a box! That made me laugh, but it didn't matter, it all gets mushed up once it hits your tummy anyway!
author: Day M.

description:
This was the bakery I would visit while growing up and I would order the bow tie cookies covered the Karo corn syrup.

I bought some egg custards, Lotus coconut cookies and Lotus white bean cookies for the office.

When I said I bought these from Chinatown, someone asked "Chinatown Chinatown????"

Huh?

Well some if there items were a first experience for some, and I had a hard time explaining about the white bean in the Lotus cookies, but they tried it and liked it.
author: Brandon W.

description:
According to the Eastern Bakery itself, this is the oldest Asian bakery in San Francisco. Awesome!

I got the egg tart 4 for $4 deal. The egg tarts were really good! I do wish they were a bit sweeter, but perhaps that's just because I'm more used to Portuguese egg tarts.

At the time I thought this bakery was decent, albeit not as clean as I'd hoped. If you're in the area, though, I'd recommend Golden Gate Bakery over this one- especially if you want egg tarts!
author: Lucy C.

description: Pineapple bun had slight crunch which was great. Lotus cake had good texture but was limited on flavor. Know what you want to order, for the wait staff want to serve you quickly. Pleasant surprise.
author: Lauren H.

description: Came here for the egg custards, but they were a little too sweet for me. The custard was good, but I wish the crust was flakier. I was let down for supposedly one of the best bakeries in San Francisco.
author: Audry H.

description:
We ended up at Eastern Bakery after lunch, because Golden Gate was shut. I really wanted to see what all these moon pies and egg tarts were all about. I don't know if I was unlucky and went to the wrong place to try them, or if they are authentic and just not to my liking. 

Either way, the egg tart was tasty (like a custard tart) but too eggy for my liking and the moon pie/ cake was basically a red bean tart. I was quite disappointed. Someone in our party ordered a slice of the Coffee Crunch Cake and that was excellent. Who would have guessed that China Town sells the best Coffee Crunch Cake. It was Eastern Bakery's only redemption.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Do not go here to buy a can of soda.
It will cost you $1.25.
Go for a walk towards Broadway.
Head up and over towards Stockton ST.
Visit the local Walgreens 
and pay normal prices and not tourist prices.
I bought Arizona Iced Teas on sale for 2 for $1 dollar.
Don't abuse Tourists with extortion prices.
Shame on you.
author: Winston W.

description: Custard Tart, Rice Cake & Lotus Moon Cake here is so Delish! Very friendly! Been here twice! The Rice Cakes here are ginormous... Worth it!
author: Anna J.

description:
pros...have been coming here for decades now, even when i was a kid some 43 years ago my parents would go here for hard to find desserts and pastries.  as we lived in San Diego, where the chinese community is not nearly as big, we had to made due with the few asian bakeries way back when.  

so when here just a few weeks ago and was a bit disappointed in the bakery.  but they did still have most of my favorites...hopia (as we filipinos call the flaky yellow or black bean or winter mellon filling pastries), moon cakes, butterflies (giant wonton skins deep friend and then coated in sugar syrup), coffee cakes, chinese donuts, sweet peanut wontons, and a whole bunch more stuff.  

service was always "chinese", which meant it was fast, efficient, but not always done with a smile.  the place was  noisy and always something going on in the back.  someone packing something, or making boxes, or pulling something out the back.  

and more recently you can see the giant and fading picture of president clinton's visit to chinatowns oldest running bakery.  and the whole story of him coming in and talking to everyone and meeting with people for over an hour and eating.  of course we couldn't leave out eating, can we.  

anyways, good stuff.  i always like to take home some of the baked goodies from here.  as they are very had to find now.  we used to be able to go the local Woo Chee Chong, way back in the 1980's and buy the pre packaged 6 pack of the hopia, but now it seems both are a distant memory. 

cons...the place just looks run down and falling apart.  the place seems to have lost just a bit of the liveliness and action it once had.  there was nobody in the back of the bakery doing anything.  the people in the front seemed older and tired and just not interested in helping people.  the whole place just seemed a bit worn out.  but the baked items still taste good enough.  

i heard from my friend Linda W, that there are other chinese bakeries to go to.  but i still really like this place, and as long as i keep coming to San Fran, i will still go here.  now that's not saying i won't go to other places, but i will always leave a little place for memories sake.
author: Joel G.

description:
AT 8:30 PM, WE MADE IT IN TIME AND GOT THE LAST EGG CUSTARD TART (DAN TA), SCORE!!!

When we finally arrived in SF, we immediately went to Chinatown and called Golden Gate Bakery and found they were on vacation for 2 weeks, but they recommended their sister store Eastern Bakery, which I'm glad they did because  their egg custard tart was pretty tasty!

It was the partner in crime's first time having one, and he loved every bite.
author: Hanna L.

description: I have been particularly fond of this bakery since discovering it in the movie Big Trouble in Little China. Unfortunately the years have not been kind to it its upkeep overlooked. The products don't seem up to snuff like the old days I remember, as evidenced by dry mochi, greasy wife cake, and too sugary melon candy.
author: Eric M.

description:
After a hard work out at the gym (around 330ish), I scounged around the financial district for some delicious food that can fulfill my taste buds. I walked past every "healthy" restaurant and all of them were CLOSED!

I didn't have any specific cravings, and no budget. I just wanted some DANG FOOD! As I walked past every closed store in the Financial District I reached Grant which I knew my variety of food choices has narrowed down to Chinese bakerys. 

I remembered that the Eastern Bakery is one of the oldest bakerys in Chinatown. And because of that they're definitely delicious, right? Don't expect too much though. Yes, it looks run down and they definitely need an interior makeover, but their environment keeps the tradition. My eyes swiftly examined the pastries behind the glass and I noticed most of it was covered in chocolate (eh, sorry, not really into it) but I saw some tourist outside that was munching on the chocolate cookies and they kept screaming that it was delicious!

I really wanted to sink my teeth into a tiny sponge cake which was 2 for $1 and it was yummy! Not too sweet and extremely soft. The cake just litterally came off the paper so I didn't have to rip it off with my fingers, heh!

Then I looked around some more and saw some "loh poa bang" or they call it "very melon wife cake". I've tried so much of these in my life and this does not compare. This was HUGE and heavy and sweet. The crust was so soft and it just fell of (sadly) but it was still too good so I had to pick out of the bottom of the bag. The filling? So good! This is a definite MUST TRY!

My friend told me about their cake here-- he says its quite popular!

I'm definitely coming here to try more pastries next time!
author: Linda K.

description:
Yo, Yelping Peeps!

I am not afraid to admit that I will be 53 years old coming up in February 2008.  But hey- heads up Yelp!  Yelp needs to re-label the true name of this well-reknown bakery right now in order to stop double and triple adding reviews!

Far Eastern Bakery is the true name this bakery was called long before remembering as a three year old . . . Yes-this bakery has been at the same location WAY before I was born!  

This family-owned bakery has consistently made a plethora of assorted Dim Sum all these years without fail.  These fond memories frequenting this bakery of all my years on this side of the planet enjoying this bakery's delights, I have passed down to my two daughters, Joy and Kristina when they were infants.

I used to feed both Joy and Kris these sweet rice cakes as a baby food snack . . . yeah-it was really fun getting their small hands goopy with the gelatinous rice cakes shoving the sweet desert into their super petite mouths.

As the years pass by, it has become increasingly difficult to find street parking, so I may buy my Dim Sum.  I have resorted to taking the bus and walking to this bakery's location.  

                                          My Soap Box Ranting . . .

Using the Cable Cars sucks nowadays because I remember paying 5 cents to ride this mode of transportation throughout the city!  Now, it cost like what-$6.00 to ride the Cable Car, so I can go shopping in Chinatown?  

Ya gotta give me a break!  O=:-O  The Cable Car prices are hurting true San Franciscans pocketbooks!  It is already increasingly difficult schlepping all our shopping bags on foot after shopping in Chinatown!  Our budgets are strained when San Franciscans are forced to dole out $6 bucks a crack to go shopping in Chinatown!

Yo, Gavin!  Are you awake?  Change the fare for locals, Plumpjack DUDE!

Look . . . When I was a poor, starving student attending Academy of Art College on Sutter Street back on the 80's, I used to take the Cable Car to Far Eastern Bakery.  I was able to afford buying one steamed Chow Siu Bow for 50 cents.  

Eating at Far Eastern Bakery was an awesome lunch for me . . . Please keep in mind that was when the Cable Car was an affordable, fast, convenient mode of transportation to get to Chinatown in a hurry.

Now, forgeddabouddit going to my favority bakery during the day!  I find that going to the bakery after 6 PM is the best way to get my Dim Sum without too much of a hassle finding parking . . . 

Best of all, completely avoiding the hassle of groveling for change from passerbys and force-feeding that blasted meter, too!  Schweet!

Zip in, zip out with my Dim Sum and that's all I want from Chinatown.  Now, I am happy chowing down on my Dim Sum in my car parked directly across the street from the Far Eastern Bakery before taking off over the Golden Gate Bridge heading home!

                                                     -30-30-
author: Shirley M. J.

description: The warm coconut buns are sooo delicious! A must have with milk tea or coffee  it's inexpensive and a good snack for on the go while shopping throughout Chinatown
author: Angelica L.

description:
MOONCAKES! thank you, double yolk bean paste / lotus paste / winter melon. they were delicious and reminded me of home. 

fun fact: europeans are not a fan of salty egg yolk in sweets, nor the red bean paste. but really enjoyed winter melon despite bizarre texture.
author: Fiona S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were walking through Chinatown today and saw the sesame balls in the windows. Given that they're my favorite, I asked if we could pick up two for a snack and share them over at the park nearby.

Best decision ever! They were super cheap at $1.50 total and delicious. I don't care if the shop looks run down or if its a tourist trap, those sesame balls took me back. So good.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
I judge Asian bakeries by the quality of their cocktail buns.  Eastern Bakery doesn't disappoint.  Their cocktail bun is super soft and bread is just the right amount of sweetness.  I like the flavor of the filling...sugary coconut goodness!!  My brother tried the egg custard and he loved it.  I think he must have eaten three or four.  

Aside from the typical pastries and breads, they also sell cakes, cookies, and tons of other goodies.  We had just eaten lunch so we limited ourselves to the cocktail buns and egg custards.  I can't wait to come back and try some other things.  We were watching the people around us, and everything they were ordering looked good!
author: Melisa C.

description:
Very good baked Pork Bun - 8/10. Not as good as at Lung Fung.

Very good Cocktail Bun - 8/10. Better than Lung Fung, but not as good as King Bakery on Mission.

Very good Croissant, but sweeter than it needed to be - 7/10.
author: Joe G.

description:
This was my fourth stop in my quest for egg tarts in SF Chinatown. There were only three customers in the store, which was surprising seeing that the other bakeries were quite packed. However, it took them much longer to serve me than expected. The egg tart was actually mediocre and quite unsatisfactory. There was a strong taste of something not egg, and had this strange aftertaste.

$1.10 per egg tart, $6 per half dozen, $11 per dozen.
author: Jason T.

description: 5 stars for the delicious cocktail buns which have been a family favorite for 20 years but there is a certain "Chinatown" charm to the bakery and it's worn down look. But don't let that keep you away, this place is a true diamond in the rough.
author: Tierney S.

description: I've been eating from this place since I was 7 now I'm 70 and I still come here to buy the best the city (SF) Chinese bakery.  There is none better in the USA
author: Sam S.

description: Great spot for moon cakes and warm coconut buns!
author: Gopi V.

description: This place is okay. The service really really is terrible though that I have to mark it down 1 star. The melon cakes are really good and at a great price.  I like the creme buns as well which is good.  Yeah the lady was very pushy and rude I felt like.  ANyways food a 4 star, service a 1 star.
author: Keven W.

description:
Doesn't look too sanitary, but it's Chinatown? Can I even give them an excuse? 

Well, I am just here to say that you MUST try the Coffee Crunch Cake - even if you do not like coffee! It is that good. It's $12.50 for an 8-inch cake. TOTALLY worth it! They make it fresh for you everyday.
author: Jess W.

description:
I came in here for the first time today, during the Moon Festival, with my brother. He had been here previously, but it was my first go-around, as I was definitely curious by the signs about how this bakery had the best steamed and baked pork buns around. Also, they apparently are the only place in the U.S. to create the filling for moon cakes on their own, which is supposed to be a very labor-intensive process. If you ever come here, you will be greeted with giant pictures of Clinton patronizing this establishment. How odd, heh.

The owners/workers are super nice and capable of speaking in many languages, so there was no issue ordering despite it being an authentic Chinese bakery with many European items that have taken a Chinese-pastry twist. My brother decided to order three steamed (the only way to go really) pork buns. They go for a dollar a piece, which we thought was expensive until the massive baos were brought out piping hot from a steamer in the back of the bakery.

The bao itself is really good in terms the flour used. It's not melt-in-your-mouth soft, but it has a very interesting spongy texture which normally does not characterize steamed baos. The bbq pork was very interesting. It was not heavily sauced in that glossy, MSG-laden, neon-red tint that most Chinese places use as "flavor." PLUS for Eastern Bakery. The meat was also not overly salty, tough, or fatty. It really was a quality filling in the bun. The only downside to this place is that the baked goods are quite expensive for quality that you can more or less find in many other bakeries for a better price.
author: Danny C.

description:
This place is for sure not as good as Golden Gate Bakery. I wish I'd took a picture of the egg tart. It should not even be put in the case for sale. The custard was too white and dull with lots of air bubbles on top. I mean A LOTS! My egg custards looks way better than that.

With that said, I didn't get any egg custard tart. I got something else from the case and call it a day. It also doesn't look very clean.

I don't think I'll go back again. If you want good egg custards go to Golden Gate Bakery and wait in line!
author: Vivi C.

description:
I came here since Golden Gate is on vacation. Mom ordered a bunch of moon cakes but didn't taste. Waiting to get home and try them out. Not sure how long their good for.

Did order the coffee crunch cake. Didn't know it was an actual cake. Had to ask to half it. Basically a Heath bar with coffee cake. It was just okay. 

Might update my rating after tasting the moon cake. According to the store info, this place is the only place to make moon cakes in US. We'll see...
author: Virgo L.

description:
Rice squares, Smackles (Cow Ears) and their sponge cupcakes = DELICIOUS!  

This has always been my go-to spot for Chinese bakery goods whenever we come to Chinatown.  The three items above are my favorites there!  Rice squares are best when freshly made and the honey is still gushing and oozing out of every crevice.

If you've never had Smackles, you MUST TRY.  It is the Chinese version of American chips except that they're sweet, not savory.  I could eat through a whole bag in one sitting!  They are deep fried 

Sponge cupcakes...  fluffy, moist and just the perfect amount of sweetness.  They're not your typical American frosting type of cupcake but they really hit the spot when you're feening for something sweet and flavorful.  You also must like the taste of egg batter... haha

They have tons of photos up of when President Clinton came to visit... I would say it's a great Chinatown historic spot to hit when you come to visit!
author: Sandy L.

description: EVERY time we go to San Francisco we have to stop in here. The lotus cakes are amazing and make it worth the trip. I really need to try more items, but I am seriously addicted to the lotus cakes.
author: William M.

description:
My life would not be complete with out this bakery. The coffee crunch is mind blowing. Yeah, the ladies aren't so nice but you're not going all the way to Chinatown for a cute little old lady who barely speaks English, you're there for the cake!! Instead of buying it by the slice, I end up getting the half cake... More for me to share.. Wink wink. 

The candy is rich in coffee flavor and nice and crunchy. The cake is amazing because it's Chinese sponge cake.. How can you not love Chinese sponge cake.... Ohhhh so light and fluffy! Lastly, the frosting is an amazing coffee and vanilla frosting.. Ohhh the layers of goodness. 

You're missing out if you haven't had this cake!!
author: Minie J.

description:
Coffee Crunch Cake and the small melon cakes is the best thing about this place.  I wish they sold the cake by the slice so people who just want to try the cake can have a taste versus buying the whole thing, but $12 for a whole cake is a pretty good deal.  

I am a fan of the coffee crunch cake. Delicious.
author: Shannon L.

description:
$1.65 for dinner..hard to beat. In fact, i couldn't even finish everything. I ordered the veggie and chicken bun, but made the mistake of looking at the innards of the chicken bun. I began to wonder what sort of 'meat' had been baked into the sweet little bun. It sort of resembled dog intestine/pigeon guts/rat tail. I immediately became nauseous and threw away the other half of my snack. 

but it was only $1.65 so I can't complain.
author: Steph G.

description: The "dim sum" is pretty gross. But the sweets are good. I feel like this place is kind of living off the reputation of its past. Should really clean it up too.
author: W E.

description:
Forget Golden Gate one, it is always busy anyway...

Eastern Bakery is the less known one ( by visitors and lore I guess)  shabby looking bakery - do not be deceived by the outdated and overcrowded decor of the interior and exterior though. 
I can actually walk in there without waiting for 5 hours ( especially if I am on my lunch break....) 
-  if you are brave try their moon cakes, I could care less in general for egg tarts, crunch cakes and other shenanigans, but the mini Lotus-seed moon cake is what I find to be good, nice size and not too sweet.
Take the one from the back of the tray  ;-) , if it is soft to the touch you know it is fresh - usually placed on a metal tray atop of the counter/glass case.
author: M. M. K.

description:
At first, this place seems like a tourist trap as it always seems to lure in a crowd of visitors on weekends in its Chinatown central location on Grant Avenue. However, as a native San Franciscan, I can assure you it will please you!

Eastern Bakery is a cute, tiny little shop selling every Chinese delicacy from mooncakes to bowties to sesame balls to wedding cakes! They're window display in the front just makes you salivate and make you want everything! The people who work here are super friendly and attentive. Please note though that like many other little shops in Chinatown, cash only!

I recently tried their Coffee Crunch Cake and fell in love! I usually pick up a similar Coffee Crunch Cake at Yasukochi's in Japantown but unfortunately it was closed on the day I came when I needed one for a party I was attending. I remembered that Eastern Bakery had the same cake so I headed on over to Chinatown and there it was. First of all, I must say, Eastern has the cake at a stellar price of less than $13 for the entire cake, $9 for half the cake, and $3 per slice. Yasukochi's sells their whole cake for over $20. I think Eastern's cake was a LITTLE bit smaller, but definitely worth the cheaper price. Anyway, I brought the cake to the party and everyone, including myself, loved it! It was super moist, had enough but not too much frosting, not incredibly sweet, PERFECTION!
author: Emily A.

description: Best steamed pork buns ever- huge & full of yummy seasoned pork chunks. The moon cakes are to die for and I had to back and get another sesame ball bc their red bean paste is the nicest consistency and not too sweet. Oh and it's cheap! Don't hesitate to buy lots you won't regret it!
author: Siobhan B.

description: Coconut hot rolls are so good!! Only place we went to twice during our trip
author: Lilly V.

description: Their steamed and baked porn buns are amazing, filled with bbq meat. I get a box of these to go everytime I pay a visit to San Francisco.
author: Nam B.

description: This place has the best old lady cookies, okay that is what it is called in Chinese.  The outside is flaky and moist the inside is a lotus filling and it has some crunch.  It is so yummy yummy yum!
author: Toma C.

description: Been comin here since I was a kiddo.. Still awesome. I pretty much love everything they have here. The red bean filled sesame balls are ahhhhmaaazing. We also got a chocolate covered fortune cookie. I love that they have different size bags filled with goodies. Not to mention coolers with delicious vitasoy brand box drinks to quench your thirst!!
author: JL S.

description: Love the pork and cocktail buns here. I also got coconut candy and it was delicious!
author: Virginia M.

description:
Egg tarts!

Also, I know this is rude, but if you see a lot of white tourists here, feel free to realize that lines are for suckers, shoulder past them, find the next available clerk, and order. 

Seriously, I know it looks like a line, but really what is happening is that one person is looking at what is available, and other people assume that there is a line and start lining up when there really isn't a line. 

If you are Asian, you should half expect tourists to ask you for recommendations. I think they think all Asians there are Chinese and "grew up eating this stuff". Or at least, that's what they told me and my boyfriend.

Yea, the place looks dirty. Who cares though. We all know that dirty, old, run down places have been there for YEARS for a reason. I'm not going to turn up my nose to good eats just because the floor is dirty. I don't eat off the floor.
author: Hayne P.

description:
I was looking at some old pictures the other night and saw several of my pops around food. My dad always got dim sum take-out from the long-since-closed Wing Wah in Oakland C-town, and for his desserts, he really liked Eastern Bakery in SF.

I get quite impulsive...

So I grabbed my wallet and ran over to Eastern Bakery and bought two of their moon cakes. This bakery makes them year-round, and they are about as good as I can remember.

They are flaky and crusty on the outside with the right amount of moist lotus-bean sweet on the inside. I usually get two (single duck yolk, and no-yolk plain). 

These are a far-cry from the mass-produced and hermetically-sealed variety.
author: Derek N.

description:
Sometimes I'll walk home from work up Commercial just so I can walk by and get a whiff of them baking. I went in yesterday since its my favorite time of year - Mooncake Festival!
The ladies working speak English. I sorta wish they only spoke Chinese, it would make ordering more fun. But I suppose this is Chinatown and English is necessary for the tourists. 
I ordered a mung bean cake & a mini mooncake. I will have to go back for more mooncakes next week. They were both so good. I don't think you can go wrong here.

CASH ONLY.
author: Sara P.

description: Came across the place and the was instantly smitten from the atmosphere. It had that old school vintage setting. The old lady who works the front is quick and friendly. I got a mini lotus moon cake. It was so and so. They also have chocolate covered fortune cookies which were to my surprise quite delicious. Cheap and wide variety of Chinese pastries
author: Virginia Y.

description:
This place has been around for many, many decades, and I'll bet it hasn't changed a bit - except for the desktop computer along the back wall.  What a dump.  I think they used to serve meals in the back of the restaurant, but no more.  That's probably because their bakery is so successful, they decided to concentrate on baked goods.  

Eastern Bakery is the place to get thick, fried noodles that are covered in a clear, sugary syrup.  The noodles are then cut up into large cubes.  I believe you would call these "sak kay ma" in Cantonese.  Not only is there nothing like it, there's really nowhere else in Chinatown that sells anything as good as this version of this dessert.  

A lot of the other Chinese bakeries carry the same goods as Eastern Bakery, just not as for long.  

Another interesting item here is their version of a doughnut.  It's huge and a bit too greasy, but it is tasty.
author: Doctor G.

description: Fresh baked bao and delicious moon cakes are the main draws for me. The service wasn't friendly but it was efficient and the baked goods are always good.
author: Greg M.

description:
I had read such great reviews about this place, and decided to make a lunch time trek through ChinaTown to pick up some yummy chinese goodies!

I was hyping myself up, until I walked inside.  Then I saw it---

BUGS.  Yes, bugs on the cookies :(  Bugs on pastries too (they looked like fruit flies).   :(:(:(

I lost all appetite after that... I couldn't even try to be adventurous and buy anything from ChinaTown.  I went to Batter Bakery instead for a Sand Angel.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
Ahh yes, it's that time of the year again. Time to start stocking up on those decadent cholesterol filled MOON CAKES :) Some like the salty egg yolk filling but I prefer to have more sweet filling than the egg yolk center. Check out their website for their variety of moon cakes! It also mentions a 10% discount on moon cakes if you mention "Fall09".

But the real reason i come here? COFFEE CRUNCH CAKE!

A cake so light and fluffy, with a faint coffee flavored cream filling, and covered in crushed pieces of toffee! My favorite three "C's": Coffee, Cream, Candy - all in one!! 

I'm really not into fighting the crowds at Chinatown but for dessert I make the trip. Perfect ending to my family's labor day weekend gathering!
author: Samantha L.

description:
2 words: BUO LO. Or Pineapple Bun. 

Upon walking in, I wasn't sure how legit or tasty bread from this bakery would be compared to other bakeries in Chinatown. But I was extremely impressed-- bread was incredibly warm and crisp, cheap, and this place is famous (as seen in articles and photos along the wall)!! I LOVE pineapple buns, and would have to say that these are one of the best I've had in the states!

After taking my first bite, I wished I had bought more! Definitely coming here again the next time I'm in SF!!
author: Esther H.

description:
Everything looked good. We opted for some friend peanut butter and coconut thing + butterfly cookie.

the first thing: eh, OK, needed more coconut and was kinda dry.
the butterfly cookie: OMG SO GOOD!

average them out to 4 stars.

And I loved the personality of the worker lady!
author: Conrad B.

description: Coconut buns are the best I've ever had. I always stop in for one when I'm in town. You can also order and they ship anywhere in the US. Gotta check this place out.
author: Susan C.

description:
When I go to Eastern Bakery, I usually order:

Strawberry Shortcake: Their strawberry shortcake is comparable to that of Sunset Bakery and Victor's. The cake is really moist and light which I enjoy. (Tip: If you want them to write "happy birthday," on the cake, they take out all the decorative strawberries on top. So I say screw the happy birthday writing, get one of those candles/plastic signs that says it and KEEP all the strawberries instead!)

Coffee Crunch Cake: This is a yellow cake base with coffee flavored cream and toffee bits packed on all over. This is the reason why I go to Eastern Bakery. It's soooo much cheaper compared to the bakery in Japantown. For around only $12,  I can have this whole cake to myself! Everytime I bring this cake to parties, I always get asked where I bought it and sometimes, I wish people didn't ask me so I can keep this delicious secret to myself. 

The only negative aspect about this bakery is that there are always pigeons flying into the entrance of the bakery. Pigeons flying near your head...pigeons roaming around on the floor......ew....But I will sacrifice to get my coffee crunch cake!
author: Julia K.

description: Craved for egg tart and golden gate bakery was closed. so i yelped and found this place. The egg tart was too sweet to my taste, but the texture was good. Also tried their shrimp dumplings and buns. The shrimp dumpling skin was too thick....buns were ok. Not sure I'll ever go back.
author: Claire L.

description:
Ugh, such a disappointment.  And I mean by way of Chinese bakeries in general, not for this place in and of itself.  But I chose this place given there were good yelp reviews...which were proved wrong...

So I don't have easy access to Chinese bakeries where I live and decided to get a spread of goodies.  I ordered the ling moong gao (sponge cake with lemon filling), jian dui (sesame ball), lo paw bang (melon cake), hueng jiu gao (banana rolls.  aka rice candy rolls apparently, from what I can see others are calling it on yelp), and the daan tat (egg tart).  Granted I came here on an early Thursday afternoon and it wasn't packed, but was I expecting the little old lady to sell me expired pastries?  No.  I love lemon so I ordered the lemon cake, which in a couple of hours I had come to find that it had black specks all over it, which meant...dun dun dun...MOLD.  that huge piece of cake had mold throughout.  Thanks, lady.  So I tossed that entirely in the garbage, hoping that even if a homeless person picked it out of the garbage, that he/she wouldn't eat it because I'd never want anyone to knowingly ingest mold.  So I moved onto the egg tart which was decent, nothing mind-blowing.  I had passed by Golden Gate Bakery a few times over the course of a three days, but it was never open - otherwise, I would've waited to get the egg tart from there.  Everything else was good, though my favorite Chinese pastry by far is the hueng jiu gao.  Imagine my disappointment when I had two pieces left, only two days after I bought it, to find that too, had grown mold.  The green kind.  So really the only memorable thing this place gave me was both black and green mold.  To sum up, I was grossed out.

There's a reason why it's known as the oldest Chinese bakery.  Because it sells old and expired pastries.  I'm just glad I didn't order more because the little old lady kept saying in English, "you want this one?  It tastes good" to my fiancé, but he thankfully, didn't give into her.  Probably helps that he doesn't like Chinese pastries to begin with, but still.
author: Steph L.

description: The moon cakes here are amazing.  Not only do they have traditional moon cakes but they have chocolate covered as well.  The prices are a little expensive but we'll worth it.
author: Dani H.

description:
Coconut buns!!!

We stumbled in here after dinner at R&Gs, enticed by the chocolate covered fortune cookies. I asked the man behind the counter what he suggested, and after listing his top sellers that didn't interest me, I rephrased my question, 
"what is your favorite thing here?" 

He smiled, stepped out of the counter and walked to a warming station, where three of the most delicious warm comfort bread rested. 
"Coconut buns," he said as he handed me two of them in a brown paper bag. 

I placed my nose in the open end of the bag and had instant euphoria from warm buttery bread and sweet  coconut smells. Somehow, the smell leads straight to dopamine receptors in the brain, so I snorted it again. 

Needless to say, we came back the next day early in the morning. I won't go on about the rude lady that morning, their unkempt place, or birds on the floor. I will say, however, it was all worth it for warm coconut buns that I held close to me on that cold morning. It warmed me from the inside out. The bread is airy, while the inside is a hot buttery coconut filling that is not to sweet and has just the right texture. I am going to have to find an acceptable recipe to replicate this since I live in Texas. I enjoyed this so much more than the breads at Tartine.
author: Monica R.

description: The best little Asian bakery I have been to so far. Things were a little on the pricy side, but it was well worth it. Ask for the pork buns, they are incredible!!
author: Cory C.

description: Best Coffee Crunch Cake. Only bakery that I know that makes it the way I like it. Everytime I go to SF, I always stop at this bakery and buy 2-12" round (one for myself and one for my mom).
author: Jen A.

description:
If you go during Chinese New Year, plan to wait in a very long line.  

This is one of those places that I always have to go to, my friend and I went every year when we went to the New Year Parade.  

The BBQ Pork Buns are inexpensive and yummy and so are the bowtie sticky yummy goodness cookies, you have to have them.
author: Colleen J.

description:
My mom comes here to get me jin dui (sesame ball with red bean paste)!

For 75 cents you can get a huge one! So warm and tasty and just the right amount of crisp. Yum!
author: Melissa T.

description: Savory: $1.10 for (chicken and pork) buns--pretty good, $2.10 for three shrimp har gaos--not that good.
author: Maximillian M.

description: The best coffee crunch cake in the world.  Eastern Bakery also features many other delectable items.  They have nicest staff too.  We have been huge fans of this bakery for decades.
author: marci h.

description:
Know the best when it comes to those cow ear cookies...Smackles.  That's OG right here.  I got fooled into getting some fugazi, knock-off "Snackers" which come in a similar looking bag from somewhere else and something was just off about them till I looked at the bag.  I was sadface.  Not the same.

Wanna get me to do something?  Dangle a bag of these in front of me.  Cheap thrills baby.
author: Glen G.

description: Love their Coffe crunch cake and their green bean pastry. Definitely will be back for another one of that cake
author: Linna S.

description:
Food-wise, this review is strictly for the red/black bean mooncakes. 

I've been to Eastern Bakery a couple of times. Compared to Golden Gate Bakery, it has the following positive attributes: (1) it's cheaper, (2) it's open later, (3) I've never had to wait in line, and (4) it's a closer walk for me. 

That being said, the mooncakes are smaller, less fresh, and not quite as flavorful as the ones at Golden Gate. Take it as you will.

The quality difference is noticeable but won't deter me if Golden Gate is closed and I'm craving a mooncake.
author: Alyssa W.

description: This place has definitely seen better days. Despite the old and kinda dingy appearance, they continue to churn out some of the best baked goods around at decent prices. Endless variety of moon cakes, delectable coffee crunch cake for all you sweet tooths out there, and makes the biggest and tastiest deep-fried sesame ball, I've ever had. Mostly Chinese based pastries available here, but they do a decent job with the American pastries as well: Sugar donuts, chocolate chip cookies, palmier cookies, etc.
author: Danielle O.

description: Great little locals-only bakery in the middle of the tourist district.  Can't go wrong with the moon cake, egg tart or coffee crunch cake.  Just stay away from the moon cake with yolk unless you know what you're doing--it's cake with salty fermented egg in the middle.
author: John M.

description:
I love this place! I had the chocolate fortune cookie, the chocolate cookie monster, and the chinese donut (sesame ball). The moon cakes look beautiful, although I haven't had one. They boast that their moon cakes are the only ones with fillings made in the United States. 

Other reviewers have complained about service and tourist orientation, but the service has been fine whenever I've been there, and as for the tourists -- duh, it's Chinatown.
author: Michael B.

description:
Coffee crunch cake.  That's what you need to know and what you need to get.  It's pricey (a few bucks or so) but the crunchy part of this cake is more addicting than black tar heroin.  Or so I have read.

The steamed pork buns are also very good but make sure to get the cake.
author: Craig W.

description:
Eastern Bakery is probably the oldest and most well known Chinese bakery in SF Chinatown.  They have a few hard to find Chinese bakery items like chocolate moon cakes and fried bow ties here.  Our hero can't say he wasn't pleased with their dollar pork buns either.  They're pretty filling and cheap, which is always a good combo.

They're cheap, but not the cheapest.  There's another bakery West of them on Stockton a few blocks North that's a bit cheaper and of comparable quality that probably just gets less notice because it's not on the main Chinatown strip.

PROS:
- Cheap.
- Good pork buns.
- They've got some unique twists on Chinese bakery items available.

CONS:
- Not much for customer service.
- Located on a one way street where parking can be a pain.
author: Albert W.

description:
Both the steamed & baked pork bun were disgusting! 

The dough tasted sweet, there was too much dough & barely any filling!
The filling was gristly & made us skeptical of what type of meat was used.
author: Nicole E.

description:
In Chinatown and need a quick snack?  Come to Eastern Bakery!


Eastern Bakery is supposedly the oldest bakery in Chinatown.  They have both sweets and savories and they are all good. 

 If I need a quick lunch I'll pick up one or two of their steamed buns; they have pork, chinese sausage, and the "chicken" (it's actually a mix of chicken, sausage, and a few other things).  The pork is reliably good; the chicken is sometimes great, other times dreadful.  Buns are cheap and you can fill your belly for only a couple bucks.

Their sweets are great but I don't get  them too often (trying to eat somewhat healthy...)  Their custard tarts are great; I'm a huge fan.  Their cookies, moon pies, and other random things are great too but the custard is always my first choice and I'm bummed when their sold out (which happens fairly often).

Service?  It's okay; sometimes they're real quick but not always.  One time I was in a hurry, their was no other customers there and the lady had her back turned doing something.  I waited, coughed a few times, even said "excuse me" but she didn't turn around.  I left after about 2 minutes empty handed...

Overall this place is great; definitely worth checking out!
author: D D.

description:
Came in on Sunday May 27th, 2012 and ordered the vegetarian dim sum. It was overall ok compared to other venues in the china town vicinity. A little pricier than Clement Street - $2.10 vs $1.50 to $1.60, however, portions were bigger but no soy sauce in sight.

Otherwise, the bakery items had a line like always and appeared to be quite tasty. This place has a following and great items - but it appeared i just didnt order the right one.
author: Brian D.

description:
We popped in here to grab some pastries for a friend back home in San Antonio at his request. This is an old, shabby, disorganized Chinese bakery. It's exactly what I expected in SF Chinatown. There were SO MANY THINGS TO EAT!  

I was overwhelmed by the awesomeness and grabbed a fist sized sesame seed covered donut filled with red bean paste even though we were on our way to dinner. This delicious monster was less than one dollar-for reals! It was slightly greasy, nice and crunchy, the right amount of chewy awesomeness one would expect in this delight. I refrained from buying a whole box and sitting on the curb to eat them--it was a hard thing to do. 

mmmmmm!
author: Theresa H.

description: Had dim sum only... Nothing really all that spectacular and nothing to write home about. I've actually had better frozen dim sum from the market. It was also a bit sketch the way some older lady appeared with your order in a paper bag with all your dim sum dumped in chaotically from the back.
author: S C.

description:
What a DIVE!!!!  It's cluttered, it's dirty, it's an absolute mess!  It looks like a 12 year old boys closet!  It's fabulous because it is exactly what I expected from an old bakery in the middle of Chinatown!  It was rounded out perfectly by the grumpy, frumpy, motherly lady that helped (for lack of a better word) us.

We got a steamed sweet BBQ pork bun and split it as we journeyed through Chinatown toward Little Italy and ultimately Pier 39 on a gorgeous July morning.  Not what most would consider breakfast but hey, it was our culinary adventure, not yours!

The bun was perfection, soft but not mushy, moist but not wet, dry but not dried out.  The pork was tasty with just enough sauce to be moist but not messy, tasteful without being overpowering.  My husband ate while walking, without benefit of napkin or plate, and did not get any on his shirt... Very impressive!  But wait, the best part is that this yummy treat, that 1/2 of covered my hand, was a whopping dollar, out the door. Yes, A SINGLE DOLLAR BILL will get you this BBQ pork bun!

We also tried a piece of chocolate covered coconut moon pie.  Momma declared that it was not a moon pie and I had to listen to her tell me the contents of a freakin' East Coast style moon pie as if I didn't know.  I had to explain that this was a gen-U-ine Chinese moon pie but she still turned her nose up.  My husband liked it but said it should have had marshmallow in it... He's a big fan of pinwheels and must have been craving one at the time we did our tasting... But I liked it and when it isn't ten million degrees out I will be ordering a whole pie.  Yummers!  This cost fifty cents... Even better!
author: Allie R.

description: Had the almond cookies.  A good value for an excellent tasting cookie.  Check it out!  Everything looked good and they were constantly baking and bringing more items out-- even on a Sunday afternoon!
author: Tad H.

description: The char siu baos were good, and the butterfly cookies were stellar, but I'm pretty sure the little old Chinese lady who manned the counter was a) miffed that I didn't speak Chinese and b) that my boyfriend was white.  Also, we got here around 8:45 in the morning, and many of the cases were empty and things we wanted weren't ready yet (daan tart in particular).
author: Sara C.

description: Lots of cakes and pastries to chose from. We bought some bread and buns to snack on at the hotel and they didn't last long.
author: Jill C.

description: Almond cookies are addicting and delicious!  Buttery goodness. I bet you won't be able to eat just one. Good thing they sell them by the bag! :) Lots of yummy options here!
author: Liliana B.

description:
Meh.  Expected a lot given this is one of the oldest SF Chinese bakeries in town.  Old does not equal great.  Even compared to some Calgary bakeries it didn't compare.  Which isn't saying much.
Almond cookie ok.  Bow ties very sweet and the oil seemed a bit old.  The "sly kei mai" looked great but we had to throw it away as it tasted nasty and rancid.  Sponge cake reasonable. Haven't tried the moon cake that we bought yet but are hopeful that it will be good given that it is "freshly" made.
author: B W.

description:
Well, I know most everyone raves about Golden Gate Bakery.  But after bypassing that and heading here from a tip from another Chinese friend I was quite impressed.

The place stays open later than most Chinese bakeries but I would have to say their buns are amazingly fresh.  We went late after dinner here and bought some cocktail buns and also some sesame balls.

The cocktail buns were both some the largest I've had in the SF area.  The bread was very fresh and sweet, and the coconut almost crunchy (i.e. fresh) and extremely tasty.  The taste stood out without being tart, and was just great.

The sesame balls were still crunchy on the outside and yet soft and gooey on the inside.  You can tell it is made well as the sesame seeds aren't stuck to the outside in oil, but almost look like they are just baked on.  That is a sign they are made well (bakeries that don't make these as well make them so that they collapse from the spherical shape and the sesame seeds look like they've been soaked in oil).

The only reason they don't get 5 stars is the prices are a bit higher than other places in Chinatown and say New Chinatown in Inner Richmond.  Otherwise service is fast and everything else great.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
5 stars for the best coffee crunch cake ever.

I don't have much love for Chinatown. When I was a kid, I'd end up there only a couple times a year, and it usually made for a pretty traumatic experience. Most of what I remember is old Cantonese ladies running over my feet with their carts and jabbering at me, and my grandma hollering, both in English and Cantonese, that I only understood English so they should save their breaths. Not happy memories. However, my grandpa would make the trek to Chinatown every other week (we lived out in the Bayview, and then South City, so we didn't have good Chinese bakeries nearby) and he'd come home with a big pink cardboard box full of Eastern Bakery goodies like bak tong goh (steamed sweetened rice cake), buns, sesame balls, egg custard tarts, doughnuts, and jelly rolls. If we were lucky, there'd be a coffee crunch cake or a strawberry cake. He had a serious sweet tooth.

Now that my grandpa is no longer with us, I have to make the trek over to Eastern Bakery if I want coffee crunch cake. That means I don't always get to satisfy my cravings, but if I did, I'd probably be 200 lbs, because I ALWAYS want Eastern's coffee crunch cake. It's a light, spongy cake with airy cream and crunchy bits of coffee candy. It's the best. My friend and I went there last week and got half of a coffee crunch cake for about $9. We should have splurged and gotten the entire cake for $12, because when we got back to his apartment, we polished that thing off in less than 10 minutes.

Anyhow, Eastern also has other items that are really good, at least if you stick with the tried and true, and don't go for the semi-traditional items which have inexplicably been covered with chocolate. If you're picky and don't want them to place the food in a brown paper bag, all you have to do is order a lot of items so that they have to put all your stuff in a pink cardboard box =)  Go for the sugar donuts, the fluffy yellow cupcakes that aren't at all like regular American cupcakes, sesame balls and some buns. If you're adventurous, they make a really good century egg pastry. Oh, and you'll need another box for that lovely coffee crunch cake.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Bought some snacks/pastries there last Friday and everything was stale!

4 custard tarts - crust was hard/crumbly on all
2 sponge cakes - dried out and hard
1 melon cake - bottom crust was rock-like.

Don't waste your time, go 1 block up to Golden Gate bakery.
author: Paul F.

description:
Maybe I tried the wrong items or I came on a bad day, but I was NOT pleased with the pastry.

Their egg tart wasn't flaky enough for me, and I've definitely had better egg tarts elsewhere. Their pineapple bun was a disappointment too! I was definitely not pleased with my experience here.

Giving it 2 stars because the service was good, but other than that, I doubt I will come back here again!
author: Carol L.

description:
This review is for one product only--the coconut macaroons.  Those are the only things I ever get from Eastern Bakery, and I love them.  Way to branch out, I know.  The staff is ornery and the cleanliness questionable, but those macaroons are a delight--crunchy on the outside with the exterior giving way quickly to soft baked goodness inside.  One of these days I will try something else there.  

Right around the corner on Commercial is a Banksy stencil work protected by a clear plastic sheet which is worth a look.
author: Aaron S.

description: Don't let the outside fool you.  I would go out of my way every time I'm in San Francisco JUST to get one of their chocolate-dipped macaroons.  To die for!
author: Amber H.

description: This place was happy to sell us stale coconut macaroons, we're talkin' door-stop stale. Couldn't eat'em, threw'em away. Walk down the street to the Golden Gate Bakery. The line out the door says it all......
author: Elaine S.

description: I love this place.  I have been going here for years, and it is so tasty.  They have a lot of moon cakes to choose from and dim sum choices.  They have great almond cookies.  The thing I always go for is the chinese pancake with the lotus paste.  I went today and devoured one.  This review is overdue.  The place is cluttered, and unorganized, but I think this is part of the charm.  I will always go here when I am in the area.  It is fun.
author: Lisa M.

description: An authentic bakery serves delicious Chinese sweets... The lotus filled Chinese cookie was sweet and unique.
author: Yifat S.

description: The oldest bakery in the U. S.  And it's obvious. Cluttered and dirty inside. Cashier wasn't friendly and was clipping her fingernails behind the counter, yuck. Waited fifteen minutes for bubble tea. The pastries are tasty but I'm sure I could have found something better.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The bbq pork bun (char siu bao) is NOT authentic (Cantonese). The outside is good - it's baked instead of steamed, so there's a nice crispy glaze.  But the meat inside is sweet, and has a light brownish sauce, instead of the nice red bbq sauce that I was expecting.

On a side note, this is supposedly the oldest bakery in Chinatown (since 1924).
author: Jeanne L.

description: Scored some cheap pastries here after a fancy dinner around Union Square.  Nice selection and friendly folks behind the counter.
author: Bill H.

description: By the way, chocolate-covered mooncake tastes DISGUSTING.
author: Tori S.

description: I don't know why this place has four stars on yelp. As a Chinese I know there are much better bakeries in chinatown and this place does not have tasty food nor good prices. It is over priced because it is in the tourist street, and the cake taste so bad as if I'm eating raw eggs. It is all about the location.
author: Diana L.

description: This is a great historic bakery in Chinatown.  Their lotus filled wife cakes are amazing!  They have a big selection of moon cakes too.  Maybe next time.
author: Erin S.

description: Very long wait for just ok food.  Do not expect any service, it is non existent here!  Very rude desk staff!
author: Tom K.

description: Yes I know the mooncake season is well over. Do you know this bakery actually sells them year round? Their bean paste mooncake is unlike others I have had. The skin was crisper and the fillings were drier. These goodies broke all the 'rules' and yet still taste delicious. It is a nice change from all the overly greasy mooncakes. Perhaps I would order some later this year as my special Christmas treat. I still prefer Golden Gate or AA Bakery but Eastern is a nice alternative.
author: Mona W.

description:
A tourist favorite "hole in the wall"bakery for fortune cookies and other pastries. This bakery has a lone lethal hidden treasure. It is the Coffee-Crunch Cake.

This cake,which contains spoonge cake covered with mocha-flavored whipped-cream and sprinkled with bits of toffee, cost $2.75 a slice. Or you can buy the whole cake for $11.00. It is a damn good deal for a set!

This cake is a 5 star item,so you should try it. Other than that, the bakery items and ambience are below-average.
author: Matt G.

description:
Some of my fondest childhood memories are my dad double parked in a ChinaTown alley and the two of us making a mad dash to Eastern Bakery for a pink box full of siopao (pork filled steamed buns). He used to tell me this is your grandma's favorite bakery. Now, I'm a mom, its my turn to take my kids to Eastern Bakery. I park legally though. Just like my father, I tell my kids, "This is your great-grandmother's favorite bakery." 

Everything is yummy. I've yet to try something I didn't like. 

The only downside to this place is fighting through the crowds of tourist to get to it. (Which probably explains my dad's parking choice). I'm even more cranky if I have to wait in line with the tourist. Who never seem to know what they want to order until the cranky old chinese lady yells "Next"  then I've gotta wait ten thousand years listening to a barrage of questions, "What's this?" and "Umm, can I..." Seriously folks,  they wrote short descriptions next to each item they sell. Ya'll had plenty of time to read them while you waited for your turn. 

When its finally my turn, the cranky chinese lady recognizes me, she asks me how many "steam pork buns?", "You want rice cakes? How many?" And for a few seconds her cranky demeanor disappears when she takes my son's chocolate chip cookie order. Its funny, I live in Sacramento and yet she recognizes me as a regular. I never go to the city without swinging by to grab my driving snacks. 

Can't wait to go again. Which maybe tomorrow... who knows what hunting adventures my tummy and tongue demand of me...
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Oh! Eastern Bakery! How I love thee. I've been coming here for well over a year and a half, ever since I first moved to the city and took my first stroll through Chinatown as a confirmed San Franciscan. That first walk in introduced me to the "pineapple shaped bun" that has become and will forever be my most cherished discovery in this city. The top is sugary and crispy and the inside warm and soft. (Lyrics to a My Bloody Valentine song, no?) Even the rather abrupt and terse older woman behind the counter has softened as she's recognized my devotion: she now yells "Hello! Hi!" at me with a smile.

For now, forever, dear Eastern Bakery.
author: Mick S.

description:
Not a bad place for a bakery planted in the middle of the most touristy part of Chinatown. Not overpriced and more variety than the average bakery in Chinatown. I like! Definitely not the best though.

But I still give this place five stars simply for their coffee crumb cake. At $11.50 for a whole cake that actually tastes good, it's a steal!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: During all our family banquets, the dessert comes from here - coffee crunch cake!!  That is the number one thing I look forward to when going to these functions!
author: Kymberli C.

description: Love the pineapple shaped buns, and I go every time I make it to Chinatown!
author: K. D.

description:
Ode To Delicious $1 Pork Buns

Pork bun, so spongy
And filling. Barbequed meat;
Get in my mouth now.
author: Jennie K.

description: Amazeballs! Literally, the sesame balls here are amazing! Don't be satisfied with the ones you see displayed in the shop window, ask for the warm ones out of the back. It takes a few more minutes, but totally worth it. This us the reason I'm so happy each time my wife wants to walk through Chinatown in San Francisco.
author: Mark B.

description:
Serious WTH when I walked in. There were 3 pigeons that had strutted in from the street and one of them decided to leave and so flew right above my head as I sauntered in. I had some misgivings about this place but my greed for Asian baked goods overshadowed any of that. Golden Gate Bakery, a few doors down had a line snaking all over Chinatown I bet for their mooncake offerings and I didn't really see any other baked good salvation in the walking distance. 

This bakery is very frumpy, old and dare I say....dirty??? I mean, the 3 pigeons kind of sold me on that. The counter was being manned by one very unfriendly old lady. Usually I would be offended but she reminded me of every baker in Singapore (where I grew up) so it was weirdly comforting. 

I ordered a coffee crunch cake because I liked the way the "coffee crunch - whatever that was", looked on the cake. Seriously lip smacking good. I was devouring the whole thing and taking in that cheap buttercream and mocha flavoring and inhaling all that sponge cake. The "coffee crunch" that littered the top of the slick of cake was also drool worthy. I also ordered a lotus paste "bao" or steamed bun (vegan if you're OK with sugar). Soft, smooth, hot and the lotus paste was tasty. 

The bakery offered lots of variety and served mooncakes, wife cakes, custard buns as well as boba drinks.

Excellent baked goods, very reasonable prices and fast service make this a great choice in Chinatown. Unfortunately, the pigeon incident and the general disarray and dinginess of the place would make me think that there's a very likely chance that the food here isn't as clean as I would like to imagine it is. 3 stars because of that. They need a serious facelift and mopping/sweeping session.
author: Sing V.

description:
Apparently best bakery in China town? 

It was really busy when I went, it smell good. Everything looked good. 

I think, personally, I just didn't care for the moon cakes. However the smackels were very good and the overall atmosphere was very cute.
author: Danielle E.

description:
No.  Nononononononono... no.

Didn't realize this place was a tourist trap, so I did not approach this place all twinkly-eyed, I saw this place for what it was - gross, run down w/poor quality food and slow service.

Luckily there wasn't a huge line when we were there.  We ordered some dim sum, three bobas, and two cookies.  How they were SO confused w/our order, I'll never understand ... the girl taking our order kept asking us to repeat it and she'll still get it all wrong when we said it back to us... if you can't get it right the second time WRITE IT DOWN.  I was getting annoyed to the point where I was just going to write it down for her.. it wasn't that hard.  

We sat in the few tables in the back to wait for our boba and dim sum.  The dim sum came out first.. didn't look like they made it themselves..or anywhere nearby did.  Looked like overly processed fake dim sum, very very greasy and oily, and the meat inside looked like processed, shaped meat that was popped into some skin... I didn't even finish it... 

The boba was just ok, nothing fancy, too sweet.  There was very little boba in our drinks, so little, I was only able to grab it w/my straw when I was done w/the mlik tea, and there was a lot of boba residue I kept sipping up.

There were two photos that hung up showing Bill Clinton visited... my initial thought was I felt bad for the guy.. president of the united states and he couldn't get a decent meal in China Town... 

This was my first visit to a Tourist Trap in China town and it'll be my last...
author: Cynthia A.

description:
I tried two things here and two is at least 1 more than enough.  I wanted an egg tart and was charmed by the famous photos scattered all over the walls.  They were all out of them so I decided I would wait the 20 minutes it took to be the first to taste a fresh batch.  

While I was waiting, I decided to taste their sponge cake and it was awful.  I spit it out after the second bite (happening a lot lately - not sure why).  It was dry and tasteless.  I've rarely had a bad one at the bakeries in Chinatown but this one is awful.  

I should have known what to expect but I ended up waiting for the egg tart anyway.  The egg part was fine enough - smooth and creamy but the crust was thick and soggy.  Total disappointment.  It also cost me $1.10.  

Waste of money.  I love "old school" places but I'm guessing that this one has pretty much run its course.
author: Simon L.

description:
The first time Guri took me here, I was blown away. That was some of the freshest baked goods I have had in Chinatown. Sadly I would not find the place again for at least a year. 

Fast forward to a couple of weeks ago. My other favorite Chinatown spot is closed and I am in dire need of dinner. I make a random left down Grant and stumble across the shop again! 

I'm so happy to find this place again and an "OMG" comes to my lips before I order the combination chicken steamed bun ($1 tax included). 

From first to last bight of this steaming soft pillowy ball of goodness is filled w/ meat. This was not your mom's steamed combination bun, it was definitely well worth the buck. 

I have since gone back several times for lunch and this is definitely the thing to get there. I generally stay away from the sweets as I'm on a diet, but the bun is perfect for a light lunch. I will have to update this review once I try the other stuff, which looks really good too.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Thank you Fellow Yelpers!  I was walking around Chinatown and needed a snack.  I didn't want to ruin my dinner plans, but wanted to experience the flavor of Chinatown.  One quick handy search on Yelp and mama!  

I went for the $1 pork bun (I like my buns steamed thank you very much) and maybe it was eating it out of the tiny brown paper bag, but it was exceptional.  Sticky and savory in all the right ways.  

What I also liked is that someone after me ordered a chocolate chip cookie and wanted it softer, so they quickly heated it up for them.  Nice.

I bought a moon pie and can't wait to try it.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
I freakin' LOVE Eastern Bakery. My favorites are the Coffee Crunch Cake and their baked pork buns.  Go early so you can have some of their freshly baked items.  

I'm a double parking fool when I go to SF and I have to fulfill my cravings.
author: Alice R.

description:
I haven't sampled a ton of stuff here, mostly because I can't get past the Chinese Donuts-also known as Sesame balls. Crispy, chewy, sweet, but not too sweet, filling but not gluttonous-these are the perfect $.75 snack.  I have also had those lotus pancake things and those are also good, though a bit more greasy than I was expecting. God help me though, I love grease.

I wish this place stayed open for the post-bar scene and based on other reviews, I will be trying the pineapple buns soon.  Very soon.
author: Gaia M.

description:
Hands down the sugar cookie and steamed bun with custard were my favorites!

I'm not a fan of mooncakes so I did not bother to try them here. 

I'll definitely stop by when I'm in San Francisco again.

*CASH ONLY*
author: Alyssa A.

description:
A couple blocks down from Golden Gate Bakery and their infamous egg tartlets,
Pass the knick-knacky tourist shops,
right next to the pigeon alley (There's a lot of those),
in the heart of Chinatown
is EASTERN BAKERY.
Our scandalous ex-prez BILL CLINTON was here. Its true.
You'll see his big ass face the second you step through the door as they blew up pictures of him eating Eastern's mooncake and greeting all the Chinese folks who gazed at him like he was God.
But really, Billy should have been smashing his face all over the COFFEE CRUNCH CAKE!!! (instead of Ms. Lewinsky's cake)
