Its the one and only coffee crunch cake I've had and the best I'll say.
and I've been eating it since I was yay high.
Fluffy coffee buttercream encased between feathery light layers of yellow cake and not the typical dry Chinese sponge cake you're used to.. this one is different.
Hard toffee coffee candy pieces top it off..an instant toothache. So good it hurts. It hurts oh so bad. Gimme more!! 
All of it works and all of it for $12.50!!
You can barely get 2 slices of cake for $12.50 and here is a staple that works for potlucks, family dinners, birthdays, Xmases, work functions, or a FRIDAY night by yourself.
You cannot go wrong with this cake. 
SWEET TOOTH APPROVED!!!..
author: Angela W.

description:
Very good selection of baked goods -- but they do NOT list the Prices! They need to put the prices next to the baked goods AND on a list/Menu item list.

PLEASE have system. line for ordering! It's push and shove to get what you want. What about a "take a number and wait to be called" or just a line. Any line. 

You have to push other people out of the way to be able to order.

Put the prices of your baked good in the store window too.
author: John G.

description:
Goodness!  If you never knew about this place or tried any of their pastries or moon cakes you're missing out!  This particular day, we stopped by to pick up a Coffee Crunch Cake for hubs' birthday.

I was a bit intimidated to telephone them, so I sent an email regarding my order.  I promptly received a call back within 10 minutes confirming my order and time to pick up the cake.

On my hubs' 41st day in 2011, a 12" Coffee Crunch Cake cost $26.50, cash only.  On my hubs' 5th birthday a 12" probably only cost $13.00.  Yes, they've been here that long...possibly longer!

Be prepared to fling your friends and guests in to a sugar-fired frenzy.  Its that good!

I'm giving this place 4 stars because when they packaged the cake, the sides of the box pressed into the cake.  I was hoping that they'd put the into a bigger box to keep it "pretty".

If you're willing to venture into the heart of Chinatown to Eastern Bakery for this cake, be sure to call/email ahead.  The only difficulty you'll have is probably find street parking.

So, if you don't know...now you know!
author: Rochelle D.

description:
The wintermelon moon cake with the flaky crust is really good!! The crust has the flakiness of a puff pastry and the wintermelon is nice and smooth. My mom loves this product, and she has made me a fan!

We also tried the wintermelon moon cake without the yolk in the typical moon cake skin, but it wasn't as good. The wintermelon was really stringy due to the chunks of wintermelon. I wouldn't get this again.

The store has all sorts of moon cakes to purchase. You can easily go crazy and buy several varieties of moon cakes. 

Happy Moon Cake Eating!
author: Jackie S.

description:
This review is strictly for their coffee crunch cake.

It's good.  Really good.  I got a half sheet cake last weekend and it was devoured.  

I ordered ahead and it was really easy.  Also, the cakes are really inexpensive.  I am tempted to try their other cakes but I am so in love with the coffee crunch that I haven't yet been able to stray.

If possible try not to change your order--we had a bit of a mix up with my order since I tried to change the pick up date and instead they thought I wanted two cakes.  So just a word of caution.  They were pretty cool about it though.  even though i did feel like i got in trouble. That's ok though, because the cake is the hotness.  

I'll still come back :D

Oh yes and this place is CASH ONLY.
author: Lu E.

description:
65 cent Butter Creme Roll!  Big , fresh and delicious!    It was the first thing I tasted in San Francisco, and one of the reasons I have fallen hopelessly in love with the city.
Went back later in the day for a pork bun. Amazing.
author: Michelle S.

description: This bakery has been around for a long time. I wanted their famous coffee crunch cake for my mom's birthday and placed an order here. I made the mistake of getting writing on it because that took away the entire top layer of coffee crutch. They should have told me & I would have done something else since that's what makes the cake. Overall, the cake was ok. Sweet stop makes it better even though it costs twice as much.
author: May G.

description:
What a disappointment!  We had gone to Eastern Bakery about 4 months ago and the pastries were pretty good.  However, when we went this morning (Thursday) at about 9:30 am, the shop was empty!  We were somewhat leery about this, but we decided to buy some pastries anyway.

We got a couple of sponge cakes and they were stale!!!  I think they were left over from 1998 when President Bill Clinton visited the bakery.  We also tried a mooncake and it was actually pretty good.

I knew it was a bad sign when we walked into an emptyshop.  Next time, we'll try either Anna's Bakery or any of the other bakeries in Chinatown.  I'm sure they couldn't be any worst than Eastern Bakery...
author: Zoey W.

description: So yummy and cheap, I don't even know what to write!!!  The decor is awful - ignore it!
author: Liz B.

description: The worst chinese pastries I have ever eaten in my life.  Dry and flavorless.  I should have just lit a $5 bill on fire.  I would have gotten more enjoyment watching money burn.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Egg Custard Tart. NOM NOM NOM. I love egg tarts. I thought this one was okay, I like the flakey crust and the custard but I was a little annoyed and disappointed at the fact that my crust was crunchy... I'm not so sure I like a crunchy AND flakey crust. 

Lotus Paste with Egg Yolk Mooncake. Definitely one of the best mooncakes I've ever had (not including the icy versions though)! I liked how the lotus paste was smooth but not dry or oily. The egg yolk was a bit on the salty side but it was still good. 

The crunchy egg tart crust makes it 2 stars.
author: Constance C.

description: I got there when there was no line - incredible luck. Only 1 person in front of me but then all of a sudden, within minutes, there was a line out the door. Nice timing.
author: Faisal M.

description:
I've had dreams of these pork buns. 80 cents a piece and you can't go wrong. I snuck some back to a pork bunless part of the country. Luckily, there weren't any hungry TSA agents and my smuggling was successful. 

This is my go-to place the moment I reach Chinatown.
author: Dea A.

description: Came here because we had stopped in the area and I saw on yelped that it had pretty good reviews. It was kind of small to what I was expecting. Theres was this old chinese lady who just kept yelling "Can I help you?" From the reviews it seemed that the coffee crunch cake was really good. So my friend and I got one. I told her to get a slice because we did not know how it tasted. She thought it was not worth it since the slice was 4 dollars and you can get the whole cake for like $15.75. So we got the whole cake LOL. from the picture I thought it had toffee nuggets on top, but nope it was those hard asian coffee candy. what a bummer. They should put toffee instead. Anyways we tried the cake and ehh it was just whatever. It was not like OMG I got to have some more. Now I have this whole cake in my fridge just sitting there.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
fried sesame ball and butter cream bun... yum

try to get things when they're fresh though. super cheap prices and no tax.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Who knew the Chinese can make Coffee Crunch Cake?!

For $30 we were able to purchase a quarter sheet of their famously known Coffee Crunch Cake.  The cake was moist and light, equivalent to biting into a sweet cloud of air.  The frosting was unlike any Chinese cake frosting I've ever sampled, it was deliciously delicate with the right hint of sugary sweetness.

The sides were covered with the creamy frosting and sprinkled heavily with crunchy toffee bits.  The amalgamation of the strong coffee, luscious frosting and candied toffee pieces were enough to drive us all for seconds, and some even thirds.

I hate that I have a sweet tooth.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I'd like to start this review with an apology that has absolutely nothing to do with Eastern Bakery.  I've been very preoccupied of late with a variety of non-Yelp activities, so thank you to everyone who has sent me a note telling me to get back on the wagon and write some reviews.  I guess that a little hole-in-the-wall ethnic shop is an appropriate starting place, at least for those of you who know me!

The girlfriend and I spent a nice long weekend up in San Francisco, and while she was off having fun shopping and walking through art galleries, I was holed up in a coffee shop doing some work.  Fun for her, not so for myself.  But hey, you have to do what you have to do, right?

So I was walking home, and two realizations suddenly dawned upon me:
1) Wow, it's freaking freezing up here, why did I dress like an LA boy?
2) After four cups of coffee and breakfast only, it was time for a mid-afternoon snack.

As I was walking back to Embarcadero where we were staying, I saw the holy grail... aka the gates to Chinatown.  Word.  I'm sure I can find a snack beyond that big metal pillar gateway to the land of sodium and MSG.  As I passed along the endless row of culinary wonders, I couldn't decide what I felt like.  Peking ducks hanging in the windows?  No thanks, too much food for a snack.  Standard Americanized Chinese combo plates, choice of two plus chow mein or fried rice?  No thanks, I'm not looking for rat... er, Panda Express.

A little shop came into my sightlines, hmm looks interesting.  A big glass case with an extensive selection of various pastries?  Sold.  In I went.  Four crazy (and tiny) little Chinese ladies who don't speak a word of English?  My kind of place.

I ordered an enormous bao, and a Chinese doughnut.  "Wansebedyfi," the lady screamed at me.  "Excuse me?" was my response.  "WANSEBEDYFI," she yelled more loudly.  I guess it's like when Americans try speaking more slowly and loudly when someone has an accent, thinking that this will help them to understand the English language, even though it's a fundamental lacking in the individual's vocabulary that's actually causing the problem.  In short, I had no idea what she was saying, and since I figured it couldn't be very much, I gave her a ten dollar bill.  She disappeared behind the counter, which was taller than was she, and she came back with $8.25 in change.  Ah, she was saying "one seventy five."  Got it.  That cheap?  Extra tip for her.  So good.

Walked outside, and proceeded to grub as I walked back to the hotel.  First up the bao ($1.00).  This was excellent bao.  Usually you're looking at a small rice dough ball with a hint of sweet barbecued pork.  Not in this case.  This bao was monstrous, and it absolutely gushed pork.  Delicious pork.  Some of the best bao I've ever had.

The Chinese doughnut was also excellent.  Sesame seeds coating the outside, perfectly moist and delicious on the inside, with appropriately sweet red bean filling and just a hint of grease coating your lips after every bite.  Sound disgusting?  Try it and then tell me that.  A perfect dessert.

All in all, I'd have to go four stars for the experience.  I even brought my girlfriend back for dessert after dinner, although I can't remember what we got; it wasn't as good as what I had ordered earlier in the day, which causes my rating to drop to four stars.  The prices, however, are excellent, the bao is excellent, the doughnut is excellent, and if I lived in the vicinity I'd overdose on this barbecued pork bao goodness.  The next time I'm in SF and in Chinatown, I'll be back.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Darn Golden Gate bakery was on vacation again!

Since our mission was to get some pastries, we Yelped for another bakery and found this place.

Came in and ordered the usual stuff... Mooncake, egg tarts, and the wife cake.

Not bad at all... The pastries were the right sweetness (meaning not too sweet). We would definitely come here again since Golden Gate bakery seem to go on vacation way too often.
author: Dee Y.

description:
How in the hell does this place have 4 stars? Seriously???

I've been to Eastern Bakery twice; both times were because of late night walks through CTown. Eastern Bakery was the closest place around that could satisfy an intense drug addict craving for sugar. The last time I walked in and thought, "bake sale..." Really nothing looks really professional, it looks like stuff people made at home - could be good, could be gross, could be bland. 

Some of the treats are good but I think that overall it's hit and miss and accidental. For example - I love the almond caramel chocolate laceys but last time they were a little moist from condensation, which ruins the crunch of the treat. My husband got a chocolate covered fortune cookie, popped the whole thing in his mouth and ended up eating the paper fortune inside. Now maybe you can blame that on him but I'd assume that I could eat anything covered in chocolate all in one bite. Anyhoos, I didn't like the cookie anyway because the chocolate was cold and cold chocolate is not tasty. 

I do like the almond cookies although they taste a little oily. 

Worth a drop in if you're passing by. Nothing to go out of your way for.
author: Kiristen R.

description: stopped for for two moon cakes ($10.75) the day after autumn moon. baked fresh in house, fair price, good help, good taste.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
We were originally looking for the famous "Golden Gate Bakery", but because it was closed and had a sign saying "On vacation", we decided to walk around and find another asian bakery alternative.
Further down Grant, we landed at Eastern Bakery and it honestly was a very strong second.  The options are very broad ranging from pork buns, bean buns to dessert cookies.  We ordered over a dozen buns at a price well under 10 bucks and the buns were great for next day breakfast or a snack.
author: Roger T.

description: Obviously don't go here for the ambience or service- neither are impressive. But the super cheap and incredible Chinese food and pastries definitely make up for it.  My mom, sister and I went to China Town for the afternoon, and wanted a snack and this is the first place we saw.  After reading a few good reviews on Yelp, and seeing the awesome pics and very detailed information from President Clinton's visit, we thought it was trustworthy enough. We only got a snack- and obviously had to try the BBQ pork buns. They are $1, and HUGE! So fluffy and delicious, and really filling.  You could have a great lunch and a great dessert here for super cheap. Pastries also look amazing- a must stop during a visit to China Town.
author: Julia P.

description: I always stop by here when I'm in the area to satisfy my pork bun fix. Coconut macaroons, cream buns, chocolate covered fortune cookies and rice crispy treats also seem to find there way home with us too. Hanging over the counter, there's a  nice picture of Bill Clinton, taken during his visit there.
author: Scott F.

description: They make the best Coffee Crunch Cake.  We've been getting it here for the past 35 years...it's the best!
author: g s.

description:
First off let me make it clear the 5 stars are for the coffee crunch cake ONLY. I grew up eating this cake - birthdays, family get-togethers, etc. The coffee crunch cake still tastes the way it tasted when I was a kid. (Trust me that was many moons ago...) 

I've had other coffee crunch cakes and they just doesn't compare. I need that CRUNCH! The hard crunch candy that's on the cake tastes like coffee. It is just that good. The real whipped cream inside the cake also has a hint of coffee flavor which just makes every bite heavenly! I also love the fact that they use real whipped cream! (Personally I think that butter cream should be banished; it's lard with sugar....ugh) 

Now whenever I'm in Chinatown I'll go get a cake. I don't need a special occasion to indulge in one of the best coffee crunch cakes around. When mad mochi is "crunching", mad mochi turns into happy mochi! Happy crunching!
author: Cris H.

description: Why is everyone obsessed with this place? Yes their buns are hot but SO WHAT? They taste terrible! I had a black bean bun that had too much cinnamon aftertaste and a sponge cake that rested like a rock in the pit of my stomach. Definitely save your palette and take your wallet elsewhere.
author: Anu K.

description:
I was really excited to see these five-stars reviews. Then I went there finally today. 

I was really disappointed. First, everything here is much more expensive than regualr Chinese bakery stores. I tried the coffie crunch cake! Too Sweeeeeeeeeeet! I have to say it is for Americans not for Chinese. We don't have cake like this sweet. Also, I tried the Filled Puff Pastry. They mix sweet red bean or green bean withHUNDRED YEAR EGGS togeter !  I really don't think Id like to visit here again. But it is a really old Chinese-style building. I probably come here to take a photo next time!

But  I am glad they create Americanized Chinese Bakery to target all Americans or other people. This is important for Chinese food development.
author: Yufei G.

description: Eastern Bakery is the one thing in China Town that i really don't miss! The coffee crunch cake is to die for! It may come forward as a little too sweet, but really to me it's AMAZING!  How can you resist the crunchy toppings on the moist cake!? Since I was a kid, my family would order the cake all the time especially for family parties. I can honestly say, that this cake will be at my wedding reception. THUMBS UP FOR EASTERN BAKERY!
author: Briana H.

description: Had my first mooncake ever here (lotus-filled) and it was amazing. Soooo good. The pork bun, on the other hand? Just meh. I probably wouldn't get a pork bun here again - but who cares when everything else is so good? Got a sticky rice cake with like pork, duck, and peanuts, or something like that - woooow good (too many peanuts, though).
author: Amanda P.

description: I've heard about this place many times and actually have gotten their brand of mooncakes a few times. I was not impressed by this place. The worker did not understand english and she had loads of attitude on her. I got the egg tarts and pineapple buns. The egg tarts tasted like every other egg tart I've had and the pineapple buns were just subpar. I would probably not try it again and try golden bakery next time.
author: Steve N.

description:
$13 for a whole coffee crunch cake= SCORE! It's nothing like those coffee crunch cakes you find at Filipino restaurants like Red Ribbon. It's better.

I also love their giant sesame balls. They're hella cheap and hella big. All you need is one, and you're set!
author: Zherr-Anne A.

description:
Though I got ever-so-slightly grossed out by the "Cow's Ear Smackles" sign in the front window, I entered Eastern Bakery with a strong dessert pastry craving.

Eastern Bakery is, apparently, the oldest bakery in Chinatown.  Signs in the bakeshop say that it's been around since 1924, surviving the Great Depression and WWII.  Pretty impressive.

My mom, my friend, and I bought an assortment of sweet goodies, including chocolate-covered fortune cookies, palmiers, and a butter cream bun, and a few pork buns for lunch the next day.  Our big plastic bag of baked goods was only $6.70!  Amazingly cheap.

Not to mention, also amazingly good!  The butter cream bun -- I think that's what it was called, though, sadly, I have forgotten its exact name -- is the most fantastic salty-sweet thing I have ever tasted.  It's a large sweet bun sliced in half, with a light and buttery filling of whipped cream consistency.  Finely shaved coconut topped it all off.  Each bite was like an explosion of sweet, buttery goodness!  I've been dreaming about that filling ever since.  Best pastry EVER!

By the way, the Smackles are only shaped like cow's ears.  They're not actually made of cow's ears.
author: Nikki K.

description: I will make the trek, just to get some coffee cake and moon cake!  This place is legendary.  If you find yourself pass through Chinatown, this is a must.
author: Josephine W.

description: What happened??!!  In all my 50+ years of buying rice cakes here, I was very disappointed in the taste and quality.  They used to be very soft, shiney, filled with plenty of airpockets, bouncy, and had great flavor.  Just a few weeks ago, they were bland, dense, dry and flakey.  I come all the way from Contra Costa County to buys these and now I have to look elsewhere :(
author: Sherry T.

description:
Coffee Crunch is my favorite here!  I wouldn't get a coffee crunch cake anywhere else.  The coffee cake is very moist and fluffy, the coffee cream is sweetened just right, and the toffee crunch pieces outside and inside the cake give it a little kick!  Highly recommended here!  And it's pretty cheap too.

The fresh strawberry and whipped cream cake was OK... wasn't as spongy and moist as a usual Chinese bakery cake.  Don't get dim sum here either.
author: Mary Ann M.

description:
Whoever thinks this is a great bakery either lost their sense if taste or their sanity.

These were some of the worst pork steamed buns I've ever had and don't even get me started on the veggie buns!

The pigeons flying in to eat the sesame seeds from the floor did NOT help!
author: Alexis M.

description: coffee crunch cake. . . .i don't know why i only bought one slice. me and hubbz walked around the corner to taste the cake. and i wanted to walk back in and buy the rest of the cake. i also adore their custard tarts. but it's all about that coffee crunch cake.. if you don't see in in pastry window. just wait the extra 5 minutes for it. $4 a slice. i think it's worth it. . . .
author: Maureen M.

description: I stopped by during lunch on a Monday and it wasn't very busy. Ordered a black bean mooncake, a "pancake" with sugar fillings (so good!) and a piece of rice cake. My sweet tooth was very, very happy.
author: Summer S.

description: I stumbled across this bakery on my own walking through Chinatown.  What fun.  Since I didn't speak Chinese and the little ladies behind the counter had limited, if any, English skills, my afternoon snack was chosen by pointing at whatever item I wanted.  It helped that most items were labeled in English.  I loved the mini moon cake filled with lotus paste -- different than any ethnic pastry I've ever eaten.  The chocolate fortune cookie was so-so, but the Chinese tamale bound up in corn husks was awesome, delivered warm from the steamer.  Stop in, experiement and enjoy.
author: Will T.

description:
Dont let their mooncake boxes deceive you, they may not be as glam as other brands but they are.......
Hands down BEST moon cake ive ever eaten.  
Probably because they are pumped with pork lard. yum yum yum.

Be careful, because a LOT of chinese ppl will try to cut you in line! Just shove your way through and get as many boxes of moon cake you can!

I love their poster of Bill Clinton here.
author: kim w.

description: This was worth a stop after our not so great lunch.  We shared a slice of the coffee crumb cake while my daughter had one of the chocolate covered fortune cookies.  The cake was pretty good and packed a coffee punch at that.  The prices made the trip here all the better.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Today I took a lunch time adventure through Chinatown in search of cheap char siu bao or other delicious treats and I'd heard great things about Eastern Bakery so I decided to try it out.

The inside is larger than quite a few Chinese bakeries I frequent and they have quite a vast selection. The window display draws you in and the pictures of Bill Clinton's excursion into SF are a treat. I ordered the char siu bao (of course) which was quite big and still warm. They weren't tiny buns like you get at dim sum restaurants-- these were full sized bbq pork buns. I got a baked bun, but perhaps I should have gotten a steamed one instead...

There is so much filling in these it was surprising. I ordered a sesame ball in addition to it, but it was unnecessary and not the best I've had. It was greasy, but not overly so, and there was a huge air pocket in the ball making it appear much larger than it actually was...

The total price for my lunchtime excursion: $1.75 and I am quite contentedly full. $1 for the pork bun and 75 cents for the sesame ball. I would go without the later in the future, but the pork bun was delicious. Perhaps I will try the vegetable bun or the combination chicken bun next time to see if it lives up to the ones at Yong Kee http://www.yelp.com/biz/yong-kee-san-francisco#hrid:UraXjy3x3fLakqfOCz3cYg
author: Stephanie H.

description: On a recent trip here, these were legit:  cocktail bun, Chinese rice crispy treat ('sachima'), Chinese steamed white sugar cake (bái táng go).
author: Jenn C.

description:
Almond cookies and pineapple buns proved to be delicious and fresh. 

Staff was friendly. 

I can't really think of much else to say here. Give it a shot!
author: Randy G.

description:
I know nothing of Asian/Chinese bakeries...but I do know good service.  Despite the other reviews I've read, I've yet to experience poor service or quality of food here.  On the contrary, my three/four experiences that I've been here (most recently this past weekend), have all been great.  
The line always flows quickly and my wait is never more than 5 minutes to get waited on.  Additionally, I should note--I have only tried their baked goods that are pastry related (nothing with meat, pork, etc.) and I have never tried their boba/pearl milk teas either.  With that, I give them three stars.  Limited seating and very cramped location, which is never fun if you're claustrophobic.  Overall, a good experience every time!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmm....

I go here just for the steamed white rice cake that kinda that has sour taste to it. You know which one I mean? It's totally plain looking, but my GOD this place does a good job and even if they have none in the case, they will go make some for you and bring them to you in a paper bag. And when you eat it, it burns your hands and your tongue. Mmm..... I loooove that.

I haven't really had anything else here, so I can't say how good it is, but damn those rice cakes are awesome....
author: Reese W.

description: Difficult to find parking anywhere in China town. Came here for authentic Chinese pastries which were really good but oily. Service isn't great, the lady that was helping me forgot some of my pastries, luckily I checked the bag before heading out.
author: Kat B.

description:
Moon cakes.... why do people like these?  It must be one of those things you have to grow up eating in order to like.  If you have to get one and you've never had one before, do yourself a favor and get one without any salted duck yolks.

In retrospect, I wish I had checked Yelp and gotten something more Western-friendly like the coffee cake or pork buns.
author: Sarah C.

description:
For all those who likes sugar high. You need to try Coffee Crunch cake.
Super sweet and good.
author: k j.

description: Best pork bun I've had in my life. Egg tart was great too. Nice Chinese lady.
author: Terry B.

description:
Eastern Bakery is primarily known for their "moon cakes" which are given out to family and friends during the lunar new year celebration.

I grew up just around the corner from this Bakery and would come get a .25 cent yellow cup cake when I was growing up.  They also made great sugar donuts.  Although its been a while since I've eaten here, my mom still has the old tins from the old moon cakes!
author: Henry S.

description:
a one and a two and a ching chong potato

okay, no potatoes but there were shrimp dumplings, shark fin dumplings, and pork dumplings.  these were not good.  to be fair, though, there is no such thing as good takeout dim sum.  that's a fantasy.  the bf thought it was the best pork dumpling he has ever had.  he is living that fantasy.  i applaud his denial and question his taste in dim sum.  

but their pineapple buns were amazing.  none of that skimping on the top layer crust thing that Sheng Kee or Sogo might do.  this bun was well endowed.  

sadly, their cocktail bun was not as good... Victor's has a leg up on them with a better bun to filling ratio.  

I need to go back and try their other pastries...
author: Erika C.

description:
Tons of Asian bakery options for very limited amounts of money. The display cases make you want to try everything. 

I ordered some sort of bean paste "pancake" to go and it cost me $.70. The "pancake" was a steamed rice flour flattened circle with sweet bean paste in it. The texture was like mochi, and the bean paste was not too sweet. I ate my random purchase while walking through Chinatown, and happily ripped of part of the "pancake" to eat piece by piece. 

FYI's~ 
* The bakery claims to be one of the only places in the US that makes a certain Asian item 
* Sell hum bow and other items with protein and meat in them
author: Natalie W.

description:
MMmmmMmmMmm!!  Whenever I visit Chinatown, this is my pitstop for my Cha Shao Bao!! (steamed pork buns).  They're big!  Not those dinky dim sum sized ones.

The earlier in the day you come, the larger and fresher the selections are.  For my cha shao bao's they usually run out by 3 pm so get there early!
author: Michael P.

description: Stopped by for a BBQ Pork Bun and got a Sausage Bun too.  BBQ was okay... the filling was a brown color and a prefer the reddish color that comes with BBQ Pork.  It was okay but it would have been more enjoyable with karashi or hot yellow mustard.  The Sausage wasn't what we expected and I was not a fan of but I'm glad I tried it so I don't order it next time.  They offer chocolate dipped pieces of mooncake here which I thought was unique but I will have to try one next time I'm strolling by.
author: Shiho F.

description: I love this place. I love their crispitos. Fried cresents filled with sweet shredded coconut, sesame seeds and chunks of peanuts. A dozen for no more that 2 bucks. What a deal! I love their sesame balls when hot and fresh! They just melt in your mouth! The Staff is very blunt, "What you want?!" but I'm not there to chit chat anyways. Annnnnd plus one star for Ex-president Bill Clinton going there! ;)
author: Courtney M.

description: Next to Golden Gate Bakery, this is the second most popular bakery on Grant as it owns the largest selection of moon cakes, breads, cookies, macaroons and pastries in the entire SF Chinatown. As a major tourist attraction, it has a huge photo of Clinton's visit while he was president, and the storefront is often crowded with tourists lurking to use that particular street corner for a photo op. I always enjoy my freshly steamed lotus buns, pineapple buns, and cream buns for 65 cents each, and they go down nicely when I'm able to compliment them with a cup of boba from Sweethearts just down the street. Unfortunately this is not a sit down place since they never bothered to change the lighting and clean up the seating area. However, service is fast and friendly and the food is always consistent and fresh.
author: Daniel L.

description: They've been in business since 1929, they must be doing something right! Great pastries, almond cookies and finger foods! Definitely worth a visit! Delicious!
author: Ryan H.

description:
I do miss those days after Chinese school where I would walk pass by this place to go to my grandparent's apartment. This place has a certain charm.

+: Cheap cakes! The coffee crunch cake is good! A very moist spongy cake.

-: Hmm may be I do not have the sweet tooth that I had before, 'cause the cake was hella sweet!
author: Janet Z.

description: I usually hate egg tarts. however, when I tried their egg tarts, I ate 3 in one setting. Its not like usually egg tarts. it has a cream custard like center and the crust is flaky. its a must try here.
author: Phi D.

description:
One of my favorite spots in one of my favorite spots.............

SF CHINATOWN.

No BIG TROUBLE here.just BIG FLAVOR...(and Lo Pan was nowhere to be found...)

How can you not love a bakery Bill Clinton visited?  Get the chocolate coconut macaroon and be amazed..........

A M A Z E D.
author: Black X.

description: The shrimp in their har gow was dry & chewy, not juicy & flavorful like it should be. Utterly disappointing, so I threw it out since it was inedible. The siu mai was a bit dry too, but at least it was edible. Flavor was just ok.
author: L L.

description:
My last visit to San Francisco was about a year ago, and I still have intense and inexplicable cravings for the pork dumplings I ate here. My friend and I stumbled upon this place one afternoon, just up the street from our stay at the Hotel des Arts, and got sweets - creamy donuts and such - and pork buns (first time I'd ever had a pork bun...not sure how I managed to wait that long, but I'm a fan!).

Our last night in town, after concerts and drinking and fancy Chez Panisse and similar dinners, we were exhausted and wanted to chill in the hotel with takeout. We walked up to Eastern Bakery with the express purpose of ordering the dumplings I'd seen advertised for (I thnk) 3/$1.00. It was close to closing time, there was a young girl in there doing homework on her computer, and since I was starving, I ordered 6 dumplings, in addition to a bun and some dessert. I was expecting them to be the usual size of dumplings that come in orders of 5 or 6. I'm not sure if they always make them fresh, but they did for us. We waited at a table for quite some time, and actually heard the dumplings hit the oil for their finish.

When we got them, they were too hot to eat. When I unwrapped them at the hotel, sitting on the floor in front of the TV, they were STILL too hot to eat. But they were lovely. And HUGE. Almost as big as my cell phone (will post the photos later). They were they way I like them, boiled, then browned in hot oil. They were firm and perfectly chewy and didn't fall apart, and there was so much gingery pork inside (and no excess drippy water) that I think I may have swooned.

I live in the Atlanta area, and we have a fine selection of authentic Chinese restaurants on Buford Highway and elsewhere...but I haven't found anything to match my fantasy dumplings and crave them more often than I'd like to admit. Get some, yo!

Coffee crunch cake? Rock on. Next time...
author: Valerie B.

description:
I felt a little icky.  There was a sign designating how much you need to spend per half hour to sit at their tables (but there were only two).  And then there was a door right next to the restroom with a sign which read "Cost you $20.00 to use this room! This is not the Toilet!"  What.the.hell.is.that????   

When I was looking at the obnoxious sign I glanced to the right -- the kitchen.  Ehhhhh, no.

My husband ate pork egg rolls, my daughters ate a glazed donut and sugar cookie.  No one really liked anything they ate.  They are basically bakery conniseurs because they try a new one every week.  Obviously (since this is the oldest Chinese bakery in the United States) we were eating the wrong things.   

I did see the huge picture of President Clinton eating (moon cakes?).  I'll live vicariously through that picture.  It cracks me up.  Was it taken with the security camera??

We didn't spend enough per hour to sit at the tables but did anyway and no one said anything.  That was nice of them, I guess.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Their Coffee Crunch Cake is OMG delicious!  You can buy it by the slice, if you are on the weight watcher program.  Texture is a fluffy sponge cake with two layers filled with coffee-flavored cream and toffee-crunch sprinkles.  Some couples have even used this as their wedding cake!

Their baked pork buns are only OK. Huge but the filling is skimpy. 

Pluses:
+ Freshly made in the early morning.
+ A landmark of Chinatown, well-known for their moon cakes.
+ Some samples to try.
+ Great value.

Minuses:
- Dilapidated décor.
- Hard to find parking. 
- Tourists abound.
- Bill Clinton was here.

Tips:
* Try their winter melon moon cake and the "pineapple" bun (no pineapples in there). 
* You can try to park on the one-way street on Commercial.  
* If you are a movie buff, you may remember that this place was briefly shown in "Big Trouble in Little China" when the tour bus went through SF C-town.
* You can walk a few blocks to get the best custard tart at Golden Gate Bakery.
author: CT L.

description:
There are both sweet and savory treats in the oldest bakery in Chinatown and you would do fine by having a bit of each. I could not resist char siu bao and the pork dumplings along with the daan (egg custard tarts) and mooncakes since it is Lunar New Year after all.

Char siu bao was the size of my fist. There was a lot more of the bun than the pork but that was fine. The bbq pork was delicious and was not (gasp!) red. (That's a plus in my book.) The dumplings were huge - the biggest I've ever seen. They were a perfect mix of pork and veggies. They didn't even need any soy sauce to make them taste good.

As far as the egg custard and the moon cakes - the custard wasn't too eggy and the crust was flaky and buttery. I have yet to try the moon cake...will update after.

Glad I stumbled in here during my travels...will make it a point to come here again.
author: Lyn P.

description:
Stopped in here for the first time to see if they sell the wife cake.  Ever since I got  a taste of the wife cake from Golden Gate Bakery, I've been a fan.  Since Golden Gate Bakery was closed, I came into Eastern.  

I order some crispitos and a wife cake. Crispitos are crispy fried dough filled  with peanuts and coconut.  It was alright.  A wife cake is a traditional Chinese pastry with flaky and thin skin made with winter melon almond paste, sesame and pork lard, spiced with five spice powder (Chinese spice blend of fennel seed, star anise, licorice root and cloves).  I was disappointed to discover that their wife cake was super sweet.  I couldn't handle it.  I have bit of a sweet tooth, but not that BIG.  I will not buy the wife cake here again. I ended up just eating some of the outer flaky pastry and threw the rest away.
author: Michelle N.

description:
NOTE: I didn't get things that I would normally select at a bakery, like white rice cakes, pork buns, jin dui sesame balls and cookies among other things mainly because I'm fasting right now.  All of the things in the bakery look great.   

THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE THINGS THAT WE ORDERED.

We stopped in because the kids were craving dim sum dishes 6 hours after restaurants usually stop serving it.  Ordered har gau shrimp dumplings, siu mai, veggie bun, pineapple buns, a bag of hand made shrimp chips, and a sugar donut round.  The wife ate one or two of the har gau and I ate one too.  She commented on a lack of sensing the use of MSG which to me is a good thing.  However, I found a hair in mine and immediately stopped eating.  My daughter took one bite of hers and stopped, but enjoyed the shrimp chips.  My son absolutely loved his sugar coated donut round - go figure.  

Bottom line: That old lady behind the counter is a sweetheart, but I don't think we'll go back anytime soon.
author: Luis T.

description: My review is simply for how horrified I was at what a filthy place this was. I did not eat here.  I wandered down the cases, looked at the disgusting floor, haggard looking help and no way would I eat food from this place.  The high ratings surprises me, but I guess people will overlook filth for food. I won't.
author: Debby F.

description: I had the chocolate dipped lotus mooncake, monster cookie and some sort of peanut butter wonton. I'd come back here just for the lotus mooncake (choc dipped or not) anytime. Super sweet and melts in your mouth. Monster cookie is just a chocolate dipped chocolate chip cookie with M&M's on it. But it was good. The peanut butter wonton thing was ok, not my favorite. Everything was cheap and they get you in and out quickly. Just a tiny little place, worth stopping at.
author: Matt R.

description:
Sometimes I'm sitting at my desk and my stomach begins to growl so loudly that people in the office actually look around to see what all the "commotion" is.

Usually I play along and throw in a "what the hell was that?" just to keep the game going.  Anything to add a little humor to the day you know?

But eventually I take notice and do something about it.  I'll look into my pocket and find a button, a two-month old receipt and $2.87.  It's on these days that I go to Eastern Bakery.

Don't be intimidated by the abundance of all the yummy treats in the display case.  There are two that matter.  The pork buns and the pineapple shaped buns.

The pork buns are HUGE.  And they have the ever allusive baked pork bun.  It's like 90% bun and 10% pork.  BTW, I'm on an all carb diet.  And yes, ranch dressing is a carb.  (Also, how f'ing great is Mean Girls and why can't Linsday Lohan just make another decent movie?)

The pineapple-shaped bun is just a super sweet bun that vaguely resembles a pineapple.  Get it.

So I usually get two pork buns and a pineapple bun and pay an awesome $2.80.  Don't forget to leave the $.07 and a button as a tip!  (Ok, actually I totally advocate tipping.  SOME PEOPLE SURVIVE SOLELY ON TIPS ASSHOLES.)

Finally, these people have mastered the art of making  "thankyouhaveagooddaygoodbye"  a one-syllable word.  Word.
author: Evan L.

description: My grandma used to bring my brother and I here when we were little. The custard pie was a special treat when we visited SF. This place has so many awesome memories and when I moved to SF, the first thing I did was come here to get a custard pie. The place has not changed and it still has the custard pie of my dreams and many other yummy moon cakes and buns. I love this place, it is my go to Chinese bakery.
author: Naomi C.

description:
Mooncake box #6(no egg yoke) is the best... 
Dropped the wife off at the park and we circled around until she returned with two boxes of MOONCAKE...
My son and I can't get enough!!! 
1 box done in 2 days!!!
author: Charles C.

description:
I failed today.  Evan L. and I were sitting outside of Eastern Bakery, enjoying our warm delicious Steamed Chicken Buns, when I went to open my sparkling mineral water.  BIG MISTAKE.

Apparently Steamed Chicken Buns and sparkling mineral water do not mix.  The stupid mineral water EXPLODED all over me and all over half of Evan...the following conversation took place...people were staring...

Me:  OMG my steamed chicken bun!
Evan: I hate you.
Me:  Do you think my bun is ok?
Evan:  I hate you.
Me: Oh shit, I'm all wet.

Luckily my bun was ok, and even though it got wet, it was still delicious and warm and surprisingly not soggy.  I, on the other had, was soaked.  Also Evan forgave me when I offered to dry him off with my scarf...sorry Evan.

The workers here are kind of abrupt, but they just want to help you get in and out fast, I like that.  Definitely get the Baked Pork bun, it is huge and very good.  The Steamed Chicken Bun was also good, but the chicken to bun ratio not so good, it was like 80% bun.  I want more chicken!  The Egg Custard Tarts are also delicious and gigantic.  Steer clear of the moon cakes, they're pricey compared to the buns, and not as tasty.  

You can't beat the price, today I got 2 Baked Pork Buns, 2 Egg Custard Tarts and 1 Steamed Chicken bun and my total was a whooping $4.50.  What a deal.  For under $5 I had enough dim sum for 2 meals.  

Quantity over quality here for sure, but that's fine by me.  Everything is enormous and cheap and yet still manages to taste good.
author: Katherine C.

description: I have been going here for more than 15 years (during business trips to the Bay Area). It has a tremendous charm in person (a reminder of what Hong Kong bakeries were like in the 1990s before the UK gave it up). It is a warm, alive place: the opposite of cold formality. Everything is good here, but the mooncakes are simply out of this world. All my (Chinese) family love them, all the various kinds. Every year, I mail order 6 or 7 assorted boxes to give away at Harvest Festival time. Mostly lotus (my favorite), but also black bean, winter melon (yum yum), fruit & nut (my niece loves). STRONGLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Kirk D.

description:
this 5 star is for nostalgia, the old days when their mooncakes were king, before the imports flooded the u.s. and everyone had to cut quality to compete. 

kudos for you past achievements!

today, i can only enjoy you coffee and appie pie. today's mooncakes have too much cholestrole.
author: Victor G.

description:
3.5 stars for the Coffee Crunch cake- I would have rated it more, but the toffee bits get annoyingly stuck to my teeth everytime I have a slice.  And there's nothing less attractive than having to manually remove the toffee with your fingermails because they get stuck on like wet cement.  I have to eat the toffee slowly and separately from the rest of the cake, just so that I don't have toffee-covered molars.  

The cake itself is delicious- light, moist, and not too sweet.  The coffee-flavored frosting is great as well, full of coffee flavor without being overpowering.  The best part of the cake is the price- $11.50 for a whole cake!  Where else in the city are you going to be able to find a delicious cake for that low of a price?  Half cakes are more expensive at $8, while a slice will set you back $2.75.  

The extra half star is for their moon cakes, which are good, as well as the fact that they have this banana-flavored rice flour treat that I previously thought could be had only at Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Angela H.

description:
Well if Bill visited, it's gotta be good right? 

I guess Mr.Clinton knows his average bakery well. I think Eastern Bakery has kept a decent business throughout the years because of this special visit (really, go there, his face is blown up a million times large). 

I have been going here as a child and I think it is an average bakery. Nothing special to really rave about, but never disappointing. A great place to stop in to grab a snack while browsing around Chinatown. Sometimes it's just fun to walk in & buy something and giggle at the fact a former president was here. 

Ahh I can't complain! I came in and bought a giant seamed pork bun for roughly $1. Scarfed it down in 10 seconds, and reenergized for more aimless browsing around these streets. 

I'll be back to stare at Bill's 50 foot face....I mean more food!
author: Catherine O.

description:
When I was a kid, my grandma used to take the bus all the way to Chinatown just to get my cake.  Um, that's because my favorite cake as a kid was the coffee crunch cake.  Eastern Bakery was the only place that made it back then.

This was quite a feat, considering she lived all the way over by the Cow Palace and would take MUNI (15 Third - I think) to Eastern Bakery.  It would take her around 90-120 mins each way!  My poor little grandma, barely 4'11" carrying a huge rectangular candy-filled cake just for me.  She would have to carry the cake back on the bus and all the way home...cake in hand, crowded by all the stinky people on the bus that reeked of raw fish/tobacco/mothballs/alcohol/vomit/urine/ass.  

I guess the look of delight on a little chubster opening a box of her favorite cake, was her own reward.

Thank God, I moved on to Fresh Strawberry cake w/fresh whipped cream by the age of 7 (available anywhere) and only had coffee crunch 3 other times since.  

I really liked the cake...and I LOVE MY GRANDMA!  =)

I have to take one star off for the parking situation.  You have to go with someone so they can double park/park in the red zone/circle the block, so you can run in and grab your goodies.
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
I come here every time I go to Chinatown. I do not know of any other place that sells such scrumptious BBQ pork buns - an item I became obsessed with during my Anime phase in my early teens. (Maybe you don't remember, but pork buns were a regular hit on Sailor Moon. Thinking of that is making me want one RIGHT NOW). Anyway, back to the pork buns. The best part about them is the bun itself which has a hint of sweetness and, though nothing like the kind of magic you learn at Tartine, has a crispy intricacy to it that is lacking in the dry refrigerated buns you are likely to find at other haunts. For some reason, the bread also reminded me of the coconut buns at KING'S Bakery. Reminding m of KINGS is always a good idea.

The meat is not scary, which means a lot. I often don't like looking at the inside of these things, but the experience is totally not bad at Eastern Bakery. The pork looks fresh and gooey living in that hot bun. It has a light sweetness that compliments. It's a happy marriage if I do say so myself.

Also if you haven't already heard like a million times there are pix from Bill Clinton's visit all over the wall. How trippy dude.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Okay, I usually go here for the french donuts. NOTHING at all like the airy inconsequential french donuts that are sold elsewhere.  They are big, heavy and absolutely miraculously delicious. But last night when I went looking for their perfect french donuts, they were sold out (I'm assuming they still make them!)  So I ordered a regular glazed donut.  Incredible!  Ineffable!  With a yummy flavor that defies comparison to any other known foodstuff!  I hate to say it, but their donuts might be better than Bob's Donuts donuts!!!

So don't just stick to the coffee crunch cake and the Chinese items-- try the Western donuts at Eastern Bakery!  

They're the best things in the entire universe.
author: Robert C.

description: I stopped by this bakery today because I was too lazy to walk to Golden Gate Bakery, and because it was my first visit, I ordered a collection of items so I can get a good idea of what this place has to offer.  I think this place is great for tourists who think they are getting an authentic Chinese feel and can get small bags of fortune cookies, but other than that it's just meh.  Do not get the steamed vegetable buns.  Seriously, it's among the worst I have ever had.  The other stuff I got like Cocktail Bun, Egg Tarts, cookies, etc. were not bad, but I would probably place it in the second quartile, right below average, compared with other bakeries in Chinatown.
author: Dean L.

description: I come here specifically for the lotus flower moon cakes. I am obsessed with them and come here anytime I am even close to the area. I haven't found them nearly this good anywhere else in the entire state! I've had other things from here and they were amazing as well. A must see in san francisco!!
author: Sarah H.

description:
The winter melon moon cake is delicious.  I don't love moon cakes but I loved the winter melon moon cake.

Oh, and the pineapple bun has a thick layer of the top crust! That is the best part.
author: Wakako U.

description: One of the classic bakeries in Chinatown! Their cow ears are excellent, if you know what I'm talking about.
author: Joe Y.

description: I have been coming here since I was just a babe and now that I finally live in the city, sometimes I'll just pop in after work.  Steamed pork buns are where it's at (only $1.10! you have no idea how many times I've paid with scrounged up change), those and the egg custard deal.  also, there is a picture of bill clinton on the wall from when he visited, which is just awesome.
author: Ali C.

description:
Filthy, claustrophobic, must wait in long lines, fight indecisive tourists with their obnoxious accents who take too long to think, the samples they leave out for people (e.g. Smackles) absorb a fishy taste from the open air (how the hell does a bakery end up smelling like fish??), cash only and no ATM inside, the cashiers don't know much English and disputes over correct change ensue, and they rush you out...

Once it's your turn in the line, none of that matters any longer. The buns and cakes are authentic and delicious, AND dirt cheap! A baked pork bun for $0.80! You can buy nearly everything there in dozens. Stock up and buy in bulk to save yourself additional visits. And do try the coffee crunch cake too.

Neat facts: You can supposedly try a moon cake for free. This is supposedly the oldest bakery in all of San Francisco. The website is grossly misleading in that it's far more beautiful and cleaner than the actual place.
author: Clar L.

description:
I walk in and find signs claiming that they are the oldest Chinatown bakery (1924?) They have jumbo blow up pictures of when ex-president Clinton visited in 1996. Must mean something.

But the place is dirty and dingy, but their bow's are good. They seemed to have a great selection of moon cakes. 

Maybe I wasn't hungry, but I wasn't happy with what I got (chicken bun) but the gai may bow was steaming with coconutty sweet goodness
author: Janelle H.

description:
Came here last Saturday before my hiking trip to Angel Island with some friends. If you love sponge cake or if you want a baked Pork bun and some egg custards, here's a place to grab your bite to eat in the morning or for a snack. One of the oldest bakeries in Chinatown and can you believe it? It's still here!

Their cakes here are petite, well decorated and moderately priced but DEEE-licious. This place has some great service and you see more tourists in here than locals in the afternoon. lol
author: Jason C. J.

description: I'm so excited that I visited this bakery - the mecca of mooncakes.  Their mooncakes are shipped all over the U.S.  I'm from Chicago where these Eastern Bakery mooncakes sell out in our Chinatown a week or two before the Harvest Moon Festival holiday, so to be able to bring some home to my parents will be a real treat.  The bakery itself is kind of dingy, but the ladies speak some English, and all the signs are written in Chinese and English.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Went there for the coffee crunch cake.  I think it's $2.75 for a slice, $8 for half a cake, and $11 for whole.  Not bad, eh?
I bought a slice, ran home, brewed a cup of coffee; and was on coffee high for a while...

Them nice ladies make sugar, spice, and everything nice into a lot of varieties of cakes, bread, and everything sweet.  A lot of white people go there though, prolly just some tourists.  But hey, you know what everybody says, "When in doubt about which Chinese place to go,follow where the white people go."  I must say, this holds true for Eastern Bakery.  

The display case is in the front, and there are sitting areas in the back.  It might not be the nicest cafe style, but it certainly is pretty homie.  The ladies speak pretty good English though, so it's nice.  And they look like they're willing to help you, so it's double nice.  

Mebbe I'll try something else later, when I wanna get some sugar rush.
author: Erik C.

description:
this review is for the coffee crunch cake

we have been getting coffee crunch cakes here for many generations.

this is the most delicious coffee crunch cake ever!!!!

there is no competition!

pro: to die for coffee crunch cake!!

con:  parking or have someone circle the block a few times to buy the
         cake
         they're located in sf.
         i can only get my fix when i visit sf.
author: Kei ..

description:
I spent a buck fiddy & got myself one of those deeelicious deep friend sesame seed rice & bean balls AND a donut.

However, immediately after eating said deep-fried goodness, I could actually feel sharp shooting pains shooting between my stomach & my heart.

DAYUM that is some fine grease!
author: Pete J.

description:
Beware, the health inspector was there recently. It's filed on line. Bad health department inspection. Improper food handling, improper food storage. AND High risk with rodents, cockroaches, the works! I'll stay with Anna Bakery!

www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/FrameMainViolations.asp
for the report.
author: Christine E.

description:
We had their coffee crunch cake at work for a staff breakfast... omg, decadent for 8:30 in the moring! and delicious! We even had extra crunch available to add even more stuck-in-my-teeth pieces! I didn't see it but I picked a corner piece that already had extra crunch! yay! and I added more anyways! 

Can't wait to try more of their goods in the near future!
author: Christine C.

description:
I think this place is better than the more famous Golden Gate Bakery down the street.  There is less of a line, the store is cleaner, there are more people to help you, the prices are cheaper, and the goods taste better.  They are clear signs and prices.

I was so surprised by the great prices and the egg tart was warm and soft.  So delicous!  And I love that traditional asian goodies are less sweet.  Yum!
author: Julie R.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and decided to check this place out. I have never heard of it before, but the signs read that it is the oldest bakery in Chinatown, so of course I had to give it a try! I went for 2 steamed bbq pork buns. I forgot that I don't like steamed though. I should have went for the baked bbq bun. But the steamed bun was actually REALLY good. And only $2!!! Holy cow. You can have a yummy lunch for only $2!! 

It was cool to see all of the pictures behind the counter of what I assume to be the owner and famous people that have come into the shop while visiting San Francisco. And it was even cooler to see her still working in the store. She has aged, but she's still quick and feisty!
author: Jen D.

description:
One of the older bakeries in Chinatown, they are located on the "tourist" section of the Grant strip.  

They do a lot of things well but when I was a kid, I always remembered that they were famous for their "bowties".  Not the most popular or well known Chinese pastry but I guess I should recommend that to anyone who might be rolling by....
author: Mark W.

description:
Their coffee crunch cake is really fantastic --- if I could, I would eat it every day.  They deserve 5 stars for this.  Then I ate their shrimp chips and they had that old/stale/bad oily after taste --- 3 stars knocked off for that.  Then I remembered how beautiful that cake was --- the memory of that cake-y goodness hits it back up 2 stars --- for a total of 4 stars.

They have tons of mooncakes now.  I saw one on the shelf that had ham in it.  For real??  A Ham Mooncake?  What sort of craziness is going down in this place?

I love it.
author: Guava C.

description:
Whenever I'm in SF and need a cheap meal I will always head here for the $1.10 pork buns, no matter where in the city I am. Two of them fill me up easily and they are delicious - huge with a good amount of filling. The Pinapple-Shaped buns are pretty tasty as well. 

The unkept interior is part of the charm.
author: Emily R.

description:
We like this bakery because you can stand at the counter and say "I'll have that.. and that.. and a couple of those.." for 5 minutes straight and it all comes to $3. Or around that. But it's always surprisingly inexpensive.

I especially dig the chocolate-dipped treats. They have these chocolate dipped "wife cakes" filled with melon. Anyone know why they are called wife cakes? I sure don't. 

And finally, Bill Clinton stopped by a couple years ago for about 15 minutes and now his picture is blown up all over the walls.  That's how you know you're in the right spot.
author: Rachel H.

description: Delicious mooncake!! Delivered to my home, a gift from a great friend.
author: Myra T.

description: I had a steamed custard bun and my hubby had a steamed pork bun.  Both were okay, and at 75 cents, a good quick snack.  Evidently Bill Clinton visited this place at some points (they had pictures up).  It wasn't out of this world, but it wasn't awful either.
author: Roxana D.

description: Eastern Bakery has been my favorite maker of Moon Cakes since childhood.  So I had to drop by on my visit to SF.  I ordered a box of yellow lotus seed with one egg yolk, and a single white crusted white lotus seed mooncake (can't wait to try this new creation).  After arriving home that night, I gave them a try. The yellow lotus seed moon cake still has their delicious distinct taste I remember from years ago. They seemed just a little watered down however, as I heard they don't use lard anymore. =(  But nonetheless, these are still my favorite, even over Golden Gate and Kee Wah bakeries.
author: Linda W.

description:
I stopped in here to pick up a coffee crunch cake and let me tell you that that cake was off the hiiiiindges!  I was definitely diggin how moist and yummy it was --not to mention it was not at all overly sweet, it definitely hit the spot!  And for $12.50?!  How can you go wrong, where do you find cakes that cheap that taste this good? I also tried a pork bun and an egg custard which were also very good!  But I say the coffee crunch cake definitely wins my taste pallet.  

It looks like the moon cakes are pretty popular, I don't think I have ever had one in my life but seems like I will be coming back to have my first one ever =)
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
Oldest does not always mean best.

This is a classic case.  My idea of a bakery opens early with all the things you want ready to go.  Don't expect that here.  When I went in at 8AM all they had prepared were lotus cakes and mooncakes (probably prepared days before).  None of the traditional baked goods seemed ready.

I came back at 10 and finally they had a small amount of stuff ready.  Luckily it was the pineapple bun (NOTE to non-Chinese people: there is actually NO pineapple in a pineapple bun...it named that way because it looks that way) that I quickly purchased and went on my way.  The bread was actually very good as was the topping.
author: Brian M.

description:
i always go here because 1) they have pictures of bill clinton all around (i'm such a clinton fan) and 2) there are always people in here, so according to my ABC standards, it must be good!

recently i bought mooncakes from here to give out and everyone was impressed by the smoothness of the lotus paste and apparently they're famous (the story i heard was that the first year of marriage the groom is supposed to buy mooncakes for the wife's family and if he wants to make a real good impression, he'll order from THIS bakery months in advanced!).

they're a little pricey and a little rude to us non-chinese speakers but it's worth it.
author: Jasmine W.

description: egg tarts pale and bubble surface shows uneven surface. also small and more expensive  than other places. 4 for $4.50
author: T N.

description:
This place is close to work and it satisfies me if I'm having a craving for something sweet. Very cheap and I've not been disappointed, especially given how low the prices are. 

I won't say any more as other reviews have covered it, but good quick little spot if you're in the mood for a treat.
author: Anita B.

description:
Can't vouch for the pastries, but their salty Chinese tamales are pretty good!  My mom is from Taiwan, so the version she used to make for me when I was a kid is a little different, just salted pork, rice, & chestnuts.  I believe Eastern Bakery makes a Cantonese-style Chinese tamale (which would probably explain why they didn't understand my Mandarin term for tamale) that includes salted pork, Chinese sausage, salted egg, peanuts, & rice.  The salted egg initially threw me for a loop, but it's growing on me.

I buy these buy the 1/2 dozen & freeze them for quick meals.  For $2.75/tamale, it doesn't get much better than that!
author: Jenny M.

description:
OK, I'm giving you 5-stars just because you were the first place to whore the Black Bean Cake by the window as I walked by.

In the many years in the bay area, I haven't found these tasty suckers anywhere. Then again, I don't know where to really look other than your corner Ranch 99 or bakeries on Clement Row or Chinatown:Sunset Dist .

Was walking down the street, looked over, saw a sign that said "black bean cake" on a tray of them. I had to stop and see if these were the wonders I've been iso for so long.

I bought two.

I walked outside.

I took a bite in one.

YES. Its it.

As I gobbled up one, I contemplated going back in and buying some more. I held back and didn't go back for more.

This place doesn't make them as large as my east coast counterparts, but it's every bit as good.

I'll be back, you can see to that.

Oh yea, got some rice cakes too, they were screaming me to buy some.
author: qirk z.

description:
I used to love their steamed BBQ pork and chicken buns as an after-school snack, when I was a child.  So I tried it out now, as an adult.  

Unfortunately, I was disappointed.  The BBQ pork meat used to be nice and delicious, but it's now an unrecognizable brown mess.  The same goes for the chicken.  The steamed white bun also has a slight, strange taste.

I know what this place used to be like, and this is not what it used to be.
author: Bobo C.

description: A steamed lotus bun, a steamed Chinese sausage bun, a steamed pork bun and a bag of sesame cookies cost $7.  I've had better steamed buns but this is hands down the best value.  When the wallet is looking thin, this is the place to choose.
author: Roger H.

description: My kids and I went around dinner time. After reading about the coffee crunch cake I wanted one. When I got there, I noticed that there were no more being displayed in the counter. Then another customer asked me if I wanted to split one with her. She spoke to the two ladies at the counter in Chinese and found out that they can make a new one for us if we wanted to split it. So of course I said yes!! Since I wanted some mooncakes also, I went ahead and paid for my half and the mooncakes. After receiving my half the cake and was getting ready to head out, the customer came up to me and asked if I already paid for my half. After asking me some brief questions, she told me that I got "ripped off" by them because I paid $10, instead of $7.50. She told them she would be splitting the full price of the cake ($15). Without asking, this wonderful person then talked to them again in Chinese and I got $2.50 back. Wow, seriously, where did this lady come from, a guardian angel I did not know about?!?! :) Very impressed by the act of kindness from a stranger. The coffee crunch cake was delicious, but the mooncakes were really dry, had to toss them out :( Would have given 2 stars for the coffee crunch cake, but added another for the mystery lady. Thank you again!!!
author: Jen Z.

description:
The Dcor and ambiance is dated and not very modern or chic (if you prize that sort of thing, you may be disappointed). I like the dcor because it brings back fond memories when I was young and romping through the Chinatown of my home town. My first visit here the other day was on a strict mission of buying some moon cakes especially some snow (white) varieties. I was not disappointed by the variety or by the flavor. It was a little strange that each moon cake was individually wrapped at the counter (I am not used to this), but it does keep things sanitary and easy for packaging.

I did not get a chance to try their other pastries but I will visit again another day soon and we will see how that works out.
author: H L.

description:
I was born and raised in San Francisco. OK, seriously people....this is SF Chinatown. Hello....?  You want customer service? Go to Nordstrom's Cafe for cake and coffee. You want an "A" rating from the health department? Don't come here.

Since I was 5 years old, it has been my birthday tradition to have the Coffee Crunch Cake from EB.  It is still my favorite and now my soon to be 7 year wants CCC for his birthday each year.  It is light, not too sweet (with the exception of the candy itself which lends a nice balance) and NO, it's not a cheap buttercream frosting...it's whipped cream!!

EB does have THE best moon cakes - that is if you're into that kind of stuff. If you don't like moon cakes than no matter where you go, you won't like moon cakes.

Everything else is this bakery is only borderline edible. Whoever started the rumor that this place makes the best dim sum or steamed buns...was lying to you. 

You have to understand certain places have their "specialty" items.

You want out of this world egg custard tarts? Than brave the line to Golden Gate Bakery...that is if they're NOT on vacation.

You want excellent bbq pork buns? Then go to a bakery on Stockton st (I never knew the name of place).

You want the best baked BBQ pork bun? Go to Bakery Cafe on Noriega

Want good dim sum?  Try Ton Kiang on Geary or City View on Commercial

Before you go somewhere where people stand in line, it's a good idea to find out what everyone's buying there.
author: Keely P.

description:
The Chinese bakery by which to judge all others... The Eastern Bakery has become a "must" stop whenever I am anywhere in the vicinity of Chinatown. My husband loves the chocolate-covered moon cake, but I'm old-school---I love plain moon cake. The lotus is my favorite, though I've tried them all, and can't say enough! I also make sure to pick up the "salty Chinese tamales." I used to get these years ago in Little Saigon in San Jose, but the place closed long ago, and they were never as good as the Eastern Bakery version. I could live on these tasty packets of sticky rice and mixed meaty goodies, wrapped in banana leaf. 
Yeah, the place is a bit funky, but that's never stopped me. I intend to eventually try everything they make. Mmmm...
author: Jane B.

description:
I'm here for one thing only although it seems I should try other stuff - I love pineapple bun and wintermelon cake and both seem to get good reviews.  Oops, lost track...

Ok, I come here for their...almond jello!  Yes, people, almond jello in a plastic water cup no less!  It is SO good and the right consistency, not firm like you would expect in tea house w/ fruit cocktail but firm enough that it is not watery and each spoonful is soft tasty goodness. 

I think they only make one batch a day - basically a full tray of these goodness.  You can find them at the bottom shelf of the fridge - first one to the right as you walk in.  Each cup is saran wrapped.  I get 4-6 each time - one for the road (maybe 2) and rest to take home.  Oh, they are only $1 each.

They seem to carry some baked soul goods (cow ears, banana mochi roll...etc.) too but again I've been too focused to try other things.
author: Gloria H.

description: Oh hello little Bakery that could! You know the old saying don't judge a book by its cover...in this case DON'T! Go and visit the sweet old lady behind the counter because she is sweet and everything in this place is yummy! If you are looking for authentic items they have it. Fresh and ready to go.
author: Heide E.

description:
Yelp reviews alerted us to this place on our spring break visit to SF.  Our 10 yr old daughter had a major craving for BBQ pork buns that wouldn't be denied.

OMG their Baked BBQ Pork Buns are the size of a large saucer and to die for!  At $1 each they are a bargain too.  We got a dozen and our family of 4 finished those off in two days still hungry for more.  Now Eastern Bakery will be a regular pit stop every time we drive into the city.  Guess we'll have to try their pastries too.

Can't believe I've lived in Northern CA for all these years and didn't know about this place.  Thank you Yelp!

The bakery building doesn't stand out on Grant but is only a block away from the Portsmith parking garage in Chinatown.
author: Deb C.

description:
Eastern Bakery represents my first foray into moon cake, and really my first foray into Chinatown as a whole.  My boyfriend and I had diligently looked up street festivals and, finding we had already missed a whole lot of them, were stoked that the Autumn Moon Festival was approaching.  We knew nothing about this, but it sounded pretty good.  We were told that the Autumn Moon Festival was incomplete without the noshing of a moon cake.  Not one to leave things incomplete, we set about procuring this mystical wonder.

We heard Golden Gate Bakery was awesome.  It also had a ridiculous line.  We panicked, and then we saw Eastern Bakery - a quiet little gem amid so much chaos.  To be fair, it was doing good business.  But it was one of the few places into which we could actually squash ourselves, and so we did.  Like most places of its ilk it doesn't look like much, but I still find it really comforting.  There's comparatively a lot of space, enough room for a couple of tables in back, and I really like all the colors, both in the front window and the actual display case.

And ohhh, the moon cakes.  I have now had enough of them to know that Eastern Bakery really knows its stuff when it comes to moon cakes.  The thin, doughy outside is so light and chewy and delicious, and the fillings always feel so rich and creamy even though they, too, are as light as can be.  I think if it came down to moon cakes alone, I just might go to Eastern even if there weren't a line at Golden Gate.  I haven't had much else, but I also noticed they have fun little goodies like candied carrots and water chestnuts.  Those seemed like odd things to candy and made me think, "Huh?!" so naturally I got a bunch.  They're really good!  Water chestnuts make sense - they have such a subtle flavor as it is, they'd make an excellent palette for candying.  But the carrots get really sweet and chewy, too!  If you're up for a smaller snack than a moon cake, a bag of those candied carrots is pretty satisfying.

The service is really pretty good, and I can't say that I've ever been pushed, rushed, or otherwise yelled at.  Plus, they have a website, which is pretty unheard of for Chinese bakeries.  It makes me want to order bulk and send moon cakes to all my friends.  I will say of service, however, that I got better recommendations from an old man who was another customer, who happily rattled off what I should order and that Bill Clinton went to the Eastern Bakery, had I seen the picture.  He was pretty awesome, and I like that people like him are fixtures at places like Eastern Bakery.  I'll certainly be back to Eastern, and it's a good thing - it has been at least two weeks since I've had a moon cake.  I'm about ready to upgrade my status from "one yolk wonder" to "three yolk frenzy."  Eastern Bakery, here I come!
author: Becca S.

description: The coffee crunch cake is pretty good but im still a bigger fan of Yasukochi's Sweet Stop coffee crunch cake.  The cakes are both creamy and moist but the topping is just very different.
author: she q.

description:
Ordered 2 moon cakes from here... You know those pretty popular deserts that are filled with goodness (if you grew up eating them).

The place I usually go to when I'm in San Francisco was closed so I decided to go with another Yelp reviewer's comparison of the two. 

Fail. Not fresh. Saran Wrapped for what, a few days? Took it home in less than 24hours and felt like I was eating a ball of medicine and age.
author: mister b.

description:
I stopped over here last night since all the other bakeries on Stockton were close, this was after 7 PM. I was looking for some dessert (i.e. cakes, buns, etc...) when I saw that they had mooncakes. My favorite is the red bean paste w/ salted duck egg. I was so happy to see that they had a large one (the size of my palm) and asked the lady how much. 

$4.50 for just one!!!! That some overpriced cake either it was very good or they are ripping me off since the Moon Festival isn't till next month (August 15th on the lunar calender). So I bought one to test it out. 

I cut it into 8 pieces and shared it w/ my boyfriend. The red bean paste was dry and the salted duck egg was too salty and tasted a bit rotten. I wasn't sure how long ago they made the cakes but it didn't taste fresh at all. 

I recommend going someplace else for mooncakes. It is a good thing I tested out the cakes. I would not stop here next month to buy any cakes to give out to my family, best to try someplace else.
author: Nana R.

description: The only time me or my family come here is for their amazing coffee crunch cake.  We've been coming over here for over a decade now and it's still that good.  Cake is light and moist with whipped cream frosting, topped with coffee flavored toffee pieces.  To die for!  Bought a 1/4 sheet for less than $32!!!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Went at 9:15, 15 mins before closing time on Friday night and grabbed a slice of the famous coffee crunch cake.

Yeah...

So damn good. I was worried that since it was closing time that a slice would be dry and gross. But it was a moist and creamy.

$3 will bring you a nice slice of heaven.
author: Erika D.

description:
You pretty much only get it to go.  When I went they were sold out of pork buns. The people in front of me had ordered the day before, so I guess that's an option.

The sticky rice cake we got for new years' was hard.  But the chicken buns and egg tarts were great.
author: K. B.

description: This is a typical old-fashioned dim sum bakery in the oldest Chinatown around. It's good, it's cheap, it's fast, and it's usually crowded. A real no-nonsense place. Solid.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Only a hop, jump, and a skip away from Golden Gate Bakery is this gem.  The four stars, however, are mainly for their egg tarts.

I've tried their egg tarts, baked bbq pork buns and a Cantonese-style moon cake (puff pastry).

Egg tarts are the BEST I've ever had.  They melt in your mouth if you're lucky enough to get them straight out of the oven.  The crust crumbles at a touch and there is just the right amount of sweetness in the egg filling that requires me to eat a second tart.

The baked bbq bun was less delightful but at $1, you can't get a better deal for a quick breakfast.  The filling is fattier and sweeter than I prefer.

And finally, the puff pastry...definitely not to my taste but then again, I'm not Cantonese.  There was a strange mixture of ginger, thousand-year egg and bean paste encased in a flaky crust.  I couldn't finish it and at $2.75, it was my most expensive purchase at the bakery.  

If you get sick and tired of the long line at Golden Gate, come here for the tarts!
author: Carrie W.

description: I just left this place and had the butter cream bun. I have to tell ya it was delicious! I definitely recommend this place and the prices are incredible. 3 for $1.29...can't beat that.
author: Jason A.

description: I've been coming here since I wandered when I was new to the city years and years ago.  Fell in love with the coffee crunch cake and it's a yearly ritual to buy it for the holidays.  Their mooncakes are good as well.
author: Angelique B.

description:
The best baked pork buns ever!  When my sister comes to visit, she usually buys about 2 dozen and they are eaten up within a week.

Also try the bag of coconut, almond cookes, and pound cakes - all delicious and fresh.
author: Gina C.

description:
Some of the best Chinese comfort food in all of the United States.

Whenever my family and I are in San Francisco we order dozens of their pot stickers and steamed pork buns to bring back home with us.

Their pastries, cakes, etc are all spectacular and their made-to-order food is super good as well.

Priced very reasonably.
author: Michael B.

description: Wow, chocolate covered lotus seed mooncake tastes like marzipan.  Awesome!
author: Plato W.
