description: Been loving on their pork buns for many, many years now.  Best char siu bao in SF, as far as I am concerned.  They are $1 each and the size of a regular hamburger.  I also enjoy that the pork is actually pork colored and not some nasty overly sweet pink goo.
author: Julie T.

description: We were standing in line and the old Asian gentleman next to us said he's been coming here for decades. He said that the mung bean cakes are the best around. We bought two mung bean, two black bean and two lotus cakes. I like the black bean the best.
author: Chris L.

description: I come here every time I am in Chinatown, you just have to get rid of your loose change and get something! My favorites are the buttercream bun, coconut bun, and the chocolate covered mooncakes. The prices are amazing, especially for how big some things are. It's in a great area of Chinatown, and you have to love the Banksy art on the side of the building, I heard they let him do it.  It's a must-see/eat for Chinatown.
author: brittany r.

description: This place is a real hoot!  Right in the middle of Grant Street sets the oldest bakery in Chinatown and well worth a stop by.  They have a few tables in the back but it's what up front that counts.  Cases full of Chinese baked goods, sweet treats, savory treats, so treat yourself.  I had the "No Yolk Mixed Fruit & Nuts Mooncake (BànhThapCam)".  If you like Fruitcakes you will love this Chinese New Years delicacy.  Wow lots of goodies here!  They even do mail order, http://easternbakery.com/.
author: Gordon P.

description: The crunch cake was awesome and the chocolate covered fortune cookies were really rich.  All the products are clearly marked with the item and price.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Candace B.

description: Best Bakery in Chinatown. Every time I visit Chinatown I  come here for the Lotus cakes and sesame balls. I have tried lots of others but these 2 are my favorite. I have not had anything I didn't like here. They are quick service, friendly and there is a small area inside to eat. IF you don't believe me just take a look in the window and you will be hooked into going in, DELICIOUS!!
author: Kristen G.

description: Everything looked amazing. Had, on a recommendation, the baked pork buns. I didn't like them. They were sweet... I expect pork to be salty. This is, however, a personal failing. My boyfriend loved it. The macaroons, especially the ones dipped in chocolate, looked fantastic. Someone try them and, if they're as good as I think they are, send me one!
author: Beth K.

description: I like the chicken bun because it's actually an amalgam of mystery meat and ends up being amazingly filling (so that's already two surprises in one bun). The moon cake is site-specifically delicious--there are no flavor doppelgangers when it comes to moon cake. Plus Clinton loves it as evidenced by the photo documentation of his visit on the wall behind the counter.
author: Sam R.

description: Eastern Bakery--um, can you say, "Yum?" Well, get going. What are you waiting for? This place has some of the best Chinese baked goods around--and, yes, the price will make you go dancing in the streets. I love the egg custard tarts with a passion, friends. Hint: Get a few more than you think you really desire because these tarts will be fabulous with coffee the next morning. Trust me. Part of the fun of this place? Trying a couple of new and special pastries or buns each time that just look tasty. Be daring. Be delicious. Be at Eastern Bakery.
author: Shadi G.

description: I visit this bakery this past Saturday. Every time I go to Chinatown I must have this delicious BBQ Pork Baked Bun. So I decided to try this @ this particular bakery and OMG...it was DELISH! I should have bought some more to take back with me to Fresno but unfortunately, I didn't but now I know where to get this now!
author: Lily T.

description: I think this is the Oldest Bakery in SF.  It is also Bill Clinton's Favorite Chinese bakery because I look it up and there are pictures of him visiting the bakery inside eating pastries.  I brought the Chinese Pancake with bean paste inside I think are pretty good an not to sweet the hurts my fillings.  It cost only 60 cents.  I this place landmark to, but didn't look it up.
author: John F.

description: Went to Eastern Bakery again, last Saturday, it was absolutely PACKED. I didn't bother with the other baked goods, the steamed pork buns have my heart, LOVES IT!
author: Min K.

description: Worth the trip from Sacramento just for the coffee crunch cake.  Can't get it in Sac anymore.  It is to die for.  :You might be grossed out by pidgeons flying around in the store though.
author: Nancy W.

description: Nice lady working the front. This place is huge, i have never been here before and it always amazes me walking into a place in San Francisco, let alone Chinatown, and it being so big inside. This has to be the biggest bakery in the area. They didn't have custard buns, but i really only came to try the coffeecrunch cake that everyone has been raving about. I'm not a big fan of cake, the texture doesn't do it for me- however tiramisu was a childhood favorite of mine *probably because of the rum lol* This cake reminds me so much of it. The cake was not dry, but it was very light and airy/bouncy, almost like angel food but different. Creme is used instead of typical frosting- which makes it so heavenly and light. The coffeecrunch candy topping is like toffee but with coffee instead of butter. So...good. Has to be one of the best cakes i have ever fricken had. $3 a slice seemed abit much though, especially when the whole cake is $13. I got there before noon and there were only 3 slices left of this cake- so people were right, it goes so fast. Glad i tried this. I've never had coffeecrunch cake before and finding a place that could do it better than this would be near impossible. 5stars all the way
author: Brittainie B.

description: One word: BBQ Pork Buns (aka Char Su Bao) ! Get them hot and fresh here! I always come in and order a dozen of the steamed kind and bring them home. When the BF first saw them he said "Oh I've seen these in Anime shows and always wondered what those round white things they were eating were" .And now he eats half the box in one sitting. Every Chinese New Year we order a box and sit on the curb eating, watching the parade go by.  I adore this bakery!
author: Ella V.

description: Terrible tourist trap!  The food is the cheapest, worst quality.
author: Bucky M.

description:
DO come here for their Coffee Crunch Cake, but DO NOT come here if you're considering them for your wedding cake. I've been a big fan of their Coffee Crunch Cakes since my fiance turned me on to it. I've picked up a few cakes from here and each time the service was fine and they got the order and spelling correct. No issues there.

So, one evening I came in when it was pretty slow to speak to someone about ordering the Coffee Crunch Cake for my wedding. The lady in about her 40s-50s, who spoke perfect English, was behind the counter. I made a beeline for her since the other ladies didn't speak much English. She said they did do wedding cakes and then brought out these ratty, sticky, and dirty photo albums from the 90s. She then promptly left me and never came back to check on me. I thought she would take a seat across from me to ask me how many guests, what cake I wanted, answer any questions, etc. It was slow after all and there were already 2 staff members behind the counter. She went behind the counter and was on the phone for about 10 minutes. I asked her questions, but each time she would answer then walk away. One time, she didn't even stop to answer my question, but answered as she walked by. She wasn't rude, but she didn't care at all about my business and seemed exasperated even thought there was no one around! She didn't pay ANY attention to me and didn't seem the least bit interested in my order.

I reallllly wanted to say something to her, but decided to just complain on Yelp instead. I'm sure they don't care about their Yelp ratings since they're already pretty famous and have been around since the Depression. FYI: 200 guests, 3 tier cake with a sheetcake in the back, and delivery would've been about $500. It's definitely cheap, but since they don't need my business, I'll spend my money elsewhere (like Sunset Bakery, 5 tier cake for $295 + $45 delivery fee). Take that, Eastern Bakery!

Oh, Lo Po Bang aka Wife Cake was NOT good. It wasn't flaky and the filling was really hard. I'm not just saying that because they pissed me off either.
author: Freckles H.

description: Yummy! How is that for a start...I was in Chinatown and suddenly my friend and I needed something sweet so we headed to the Eastern Bakery. I'd never been here before but my friend had so I went on her recommendation. The Moon Cake was good (a little too sweet but still tasty). The bubble tea was out of this world good. I enjoyed every sip and kinda wished I had one now. If you are in China Town check this place out but be careful you may miss it. Its small and not flashy so you have to look for it! Price was great and the service was friendly and fast.
author: Lisa A.

description: Sticky rice and sesame seed ball both fabulous.
author: Maripet M.

description: Horrible bakery.  The staff  is rude and gives you the oldest cakes first...the cakes like lopobeng melon cakes green bean cakes are stale and  the price is twice what much better bakeries charge...only 50 cents and excellent melon cakes at Garden...1.25 here...yuck!  Gave it 3 tries but horrible all 3 times...
author: Cynthia Y.

description: When he was a kid my dad's family emigrated from China.  Though they ended up in San Diego, they first passed through San Francisco and visited Eastern Bakery.  After his life of privation in China, Eastern Bakery left such an impression on my dad that he dreamed of it for years and years afterward.  When we first visited San Francisco as a family, Dad recognized Eastern Bakery as we toured Chinatown and told my brother and me the story.  I can't pass by there now without thinking about how hard my family (and so many others) had it and what it took to achieve the life we now have.  It makes their delicious char siu bao, mini cheesecakes, and many moon cakes taste even better.
author: Lauren C.

description: Oh. My. God.  I finally had the Coffee Crunch Cake.  It is the SHIZZNIT.  My sister-in-law has been talking about this Coffee Crunch cake for ages now, but she wasn't sure which bakery it was from.  I asked around (on Yelp), and was directed to Eastern Bakery.  Boy was she happy on Christmas when she saw that cake sittin' there.  anyway, this cake is so delicious.  The place itself is a little sketchy (sketchy, in this instance, meaning sorta, kinda dirty), and it's a pain in the ass to get to.  Based on someone else's earlier review, I was a little worried the cake wouldn't be fresh, but it was fine.  I swear I could have eaten the whole thing, except I could feel my teeth rotting from all the sticky-sweet bits of toffee, so i refrained.  Too bad i sent the rest of it home w/my sis-in-law...i could really go for a piece right now.
author: Eileen H.

description: so we went to this bakery in chinatown and asked for some red bean bun to take home. Not only did they not give us the right item, they forgot to give us the butter cream buns we asked for too! They are so busy talking to other people and not helping out the right person who are in line! I guess if you're not Chinese, you don't get the right type of service!
author: Allan F.

description: This place is billed as the oldest bakery in SF (I forget if it's the City or just Chinatown).  The interior is a little dated, but the tourists (and locals) still stop in through here...and with good reason it's good.  They have all sorts of Chinese baked cookies (melon filled, bean paste filled) and pastries (baked pork buns, egg custards), as well as cakes.  Their cakes are not the typical dense monstrosities you find at other bakeries.  They seem to use a sponge-like batter.  Their chocolate 'sponge' cake is lite and topped with real whipped cream.  My personal favorite is their Coffee Crunch Cake which uses a light 'sponge' cake as its layers, filled with coffee flavored whipped cream, and toffee crunch sprinkles.  I don't know any other bakery that makes this.  Guaranteed to satisfy your sweet tooth.  You're going to need some milk to go with this.
author: JeFF T.

description:
I am still on a quest to find the best apple pie since Sun Wah Kue went out of business when I was growing up near Chinatown in the late 50's - 60's. After reading all the yelp reviews and since Bill Clinton paid them a visit, I decided to buy one of their apple pies to try. BIG MISTAKE!!! The pie was awful and had a peculiar afte rtaste that I suspect was lard. That's just a guess but whatever it was, it made me toss the pie out after eating a single slice.  Please be reminded that this review applies only to their apple pies.

So my search continues....
author: John C.

description: It's all about the Coffee Crunch Cake! I had the coffee crunch cake for my wedding cake and it was a hit! Everyone at the wedding couldn't get enough of the cake! We had 220 guests and enough cake for 300. At the end of the wedding, there was no more cake left! Eastern Bakery is a great place to go for great buns and cakes! The staff there are pretty friendly, but you can get ignored if you go there on weekends and don't speak Chinese too well.
author: Annie L.

description: So it's a touch cramped and maybe not the nicest looking place, but come on.  Have you tried the bbq pork buns? Heaven.  Steamed, baked, whatever ... just get them.  Pronto.
author: Jenifer V.

description: I love Smackles because they are lip-smackingly delicious.  Smackles ("ngow yee daw" aka cow ears in Cantonese) are one of my all-time favorite junk food items, and as far as I know, they can only be found at Eastern Bakery.  I have no idea how their actual baked goods are (apparently Bill Clinton approves, as they've had this old and yellowed photo on the storefront for ages to prove it) because I only come here for Smackles.  Of all the cow ears (not to be interpreted as real cow ears) I've eaten, these are one of the best.  Crispy, thin, slightly sweet and slightly salty, and addicting.  And kinda greasy too, but what junk food is not greasy?  I used to have a roommate in SD whose family loves Smackles and to reciprocate their generosity for always inviting me over for home-cooked Chinese dinners, I would always buy a few of these orange bags of Smackles for them whenever I visited home.  At $3 a bag, not at all expensive!
author: Diane L.

description: ok my mistake not the other one.. This is the bakery, for me, has the best pineapple bun.  Found this place coz my friend's mom really needed to use the bathroom.  First I only bought 1 pineapple bun but when i got home, and tried it.... mannn... i wish I bought more.  So deelish... the bread is really good dipping partner with coffee... hahahaahhaa yes...
author: jdyn l.

description: Mm.. I love this place. Always very friendly people. Great big photos of Bill Clinton, who ate there 10 years ago. "It was like a short, but exciting party!!" says the sign. Free "Smackles - the vegetable one" samples. Awesome sponge cake, cocktail bun, bak fung go (don't know how to write it in English.. like a wet translucent spongy rice cake).. dan tat (custard tart) is not that good though. Also this place is cheap. Oh yeah, try the CRISPITOS - crispy fried dough with peanuts and coconut inside. Mmm mmm transfat!
author: O K.

description:
You never know.
 I do not like chewy chocolate chip cookies or crispy ones. I like dense, bready chocolate chip cookies. 
Xmas night I walked by this filthy bakery after eating a giant, cheap meal at a filthy Chinese place nearby. Though I live only blocks from Chinatown, I never considered going there to eat. Everyone knows you go to the  Avenues for Chinese food, right? But my friend suggested Chinatown so I figured wtf. Just days before I'd had a conversation with a fellow baked goods/sugar enthusiast about the dearth of good chocolate chip cookies. So perhaps it was the universe's xmas gift to me that Eastern Bakery was open and my busting gut didn't dissuade me from going in. Otherwise I would never have discovered that the perfect chocolate chip cookie was to be found in a filthy Chinese bakery in Chinatown. The cookie, dubbed "chocolate chip cookie monster" (says it on the sign), is a rather large choc chip cookie covered in chocolate with a scattering of m&ms adorning the top. 
I didn't expect much, but figured the chocolate and m&ms would at least make it ok. Holy crap. Best CCC I've had in decades. The cookie was dense, bready, moist but not chewy, with a fine crumb. 
I thoroughly enjoyed that cookie. I thought about it for days, trying not to go back too soon. I've had 2 since. Just finished one. As good as the first.  I've informed my friend of my discovery. CCC have found a place in my revolving repertoire of baked indulgences. But only the Eastern Bakery's chocolate chip cookie monster. 

Some day soon I'll try their plain CCC. Hopefully it'll be comparable, though obviously not as fantastic.

Perhaps Mrs. Fields should get a baking lesson from this Chinese bakery.
author: Allucaneat G.

description: Almond cookies and pineapple bun were OUTSTANDING!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Monica E.

description:
This place is INCREDIBLE!  The sesame seed buns are amazing and even better - the bean pancakes :O!

The best part is the price - you can order, order and order some more... and it'll most likely be under $5.  I love going there and just getting a ton of sesame seed balls and pancakes (their melon cake thingies are pretty good too, but I prefer red/mung bean).

The only bad thing is this place doesn't feel that clean to me, but the food is so amazing i don't even care.
author: Guy D.

description: I've been coming to Eastern Bakery for decades and its not because Bill Clinton went there. Its because I have a sweet tooth that demands sugary concoctions that they seem to have perfected.
author: Patrick B.

description: their eggtarts are alright - not bad, but not as good as golden gate either. cheaper though.
author: Melody L.

description: Umm this place is AMAZING. Baked pork bun or steamed pork bun? How about both since each only costs $1?! Yes, this place keeps me fed during the darkest hours (economically) and it's delicious. I love grabbing breakfast here on the way to school. Aside from the pork buns they also have terrific egg custard tarts and lotus cakes. Check it out! Great snacks galore.
author: Mina G.

description: wow what a find, order the pork bun you can not go wrong it is under 1.50 and super good.
author: Todd W.

description:
little piggy has a a confession to make. . . . 

yesterday, piggy ate . . . . a BBQ PORK BUN!!  the shame! (/(oo)\)`  but it gets worse . . . i even found it to be quite tasty indeed!   

*cue existential crisis re:pork consumption by little piggies here*

seriously some of the best cha shao filling ever!  piggy's going to eat more little piggies, because they're yummy!  although, the "bao" part could stand to be a bit fluffier, but perhaps that's because i slipped in at the last second before they closed

tried a bunch of their baked breads, which are equally satisfying to little piggy tastes.  i've never had a pineapple bun with so much of the pineapple-y part (the top crumbly portion), which of course is the best part!  

piggy approves, and they're even open relatively late, which is excellent for lazy piggies who like to sleep in until the sun goes down! (^(oo)^)v
author: Vicki Y.

description: It's in the touristy part of Chinatown (actually, what part isn't?) and with huge pics of Clinton's previous visit to the shop, it seems like you've walked into a tourist trap.  But it isn't too bad, you could get away with better quality and prices at the shops off the beaten path in other parts of the city.  But for what's it worth, I'll still give it three stars.  I added one more because the lady behind the counter was speaking PERFECT english when I got there, the next ones in line were obviously tourists and all of a sudden she had a strong Chinese accent.  I had no idea what she was saying when I left...
author: Mark D.

description:
I purchased apple pies.  They were the worst apple pies I have ever had.  The filling was gelatinous with hardly any apple filling.  We were very disappointed and threw the pies in the trash.

This bakery has changed ownership several times, and the quality of their baked goods has gone down from years past.  Even their coffee crunch cake is not what it used to be.
author: JO L.

description: Four stars for the steamed pork bun alone.  It was fresh, warm, sweet...it was divine.  The chocolate dipped lotus moon cake was ok.  We got a few other things, moon cake and not but the pork bun was the only one that stood out.  It was yummy and cheap!
author: DJ S.

description: Over the years I would get a Coffee Crunch Cake here to bring to birthday celebrations. "I haven't had this since I was a kid!" was the typical response. This is the same cake that Blum's bakery used to serve. You won't find a whipped cream cake anywhere else for the same price. Be warned that if you want to be sure that they spell the name right, you will need to present it to them in person. It somehow gets lost in translation over the phone.....but then who cares when it tastes that good!
author: Arlene C.

description: It's all about steamed/baked pork bun. Yum!!! Go buy one dozen and save ur $$$!!!!
author: Erika Y.

description:
This place is filthy and I cannot understand why the S.F. Health Dept
doesn't get on their case.  Yes, alot of tourists go in there.....but do
they ever return is the question???  The steamed buns are good, but
I always get that feeling "humm I wonder exactly what they put in this)
Never sit down and eat their food - the tables are always filthy and
never cleaned.  The coffee crunch cake is good, although the crunch
is very sugary and sticky - and cannot be compared  to the Blum's
original which we San Franciscan's were so accustomed to.
The place is worn out - a mess - and dirty, dirty, dirty.  
Enter and eat at your own risk.  P.S.  The chow mein is the oiliest ever, and I mean the lowest form of oil.   Stay away!
author: Girly Foodie F.

description:
Ok, it pains me mentally and physically to give this place 3 stars because I grew up eating the goods from Eastern Bakery. But, it's just gone downhill. Big time.
The only good thing there that I will still eat is their sugar donuts. That alone gives it 3 stars. The other stuff? Well, here's an example: my grandma used to buy the apple pie from here and it was delicious pie. Just so good. Flecks of cinnamon, rich crust, everything you want.
I decided on Chinese New Year to get a pie and let my daughter experience the goodness. Sigh. Sob. Sigh again. It was horrible!! The filling tasted like chemicals and had no flavor. It's consistency was exactly like rubber cement. The crust left a worse coating of grease in your mouth than eating a candle and 6 dozen Slim Jims. I had to dump the whole thing in the trash.
Plus, it looks cluttered, unclean and unsanitary. When you order a char siu bao, they have to go in the back for 5 minutes to get it, and then when you get it finally- it's a little ball of disappointment.
Go to Honolulu Cafe if you want a good bao.
In closing, I'd like to say that I would be SO sad if they were to close down and go out of business. I just wish they'd clean up their act. Literally.
author: Jessica O.

description: The cha sao bao (pork buns) are truly delicious. I can't stop thinking about them. Highly recommended.
author: Judy T.

description:
i usually come here for their custard pies. they make the best ones in chinatown.

staff is pretty nice.
service is pretty quick.
place itself can be a little dirty and looking run down, as it is in chinatown, but some of the non-immaculate places make the best food.
author: Bonnie Y.

description: I love getting baked BBQ pork buns here. They are fresh, warm, big, and so yummy! And for $0.90, it's a freaking steal! Helps keep your energy up to continue maneuvering your way through the crowded streets of Chinatown.
author: Vivian L.

description: Well I finally got the chance to try their significant coffee crunch cake that everyone is talking about. I didn't have it right at the spot cos I thought it would nice to save it for tea break. I was all excited but when I had my 1st bite.... I'm like, what's all the fuzz about?! The sponge cake layers was puffy, light and full with egg flavor but I have tried much better sponge cake. The cake is way too sweet for Chinese bakery. Well, I don't know, I might be over-expecting. Anyway it's gonna be out of my list next time when I head up there again.
author: Ms Piggy W.

description: we went here to get some sesame balls and butterfly cookies. i think its cause i ate the sesame balls a little later and not right away but it didn't taste any different then if i got it from any other bakery. i forgot about the pork buns though and might go back for that. the butterfly cookies were pretty good though but not neccesarily worth the special trek that i took to get these.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: This bakery is conveniently located in what I think is central Chinatown. It's dirty! I've never eaten here, I just order get in and get out. It pisses me off that they don't even have like cases to put the baked goods in! They put the food you buy in a brown paper bag so ghetto! So maybe bring your own Tupperware. Although this bakery has some die hard fans! My dad loves this bakery, and has been going here for 21+ years. Whenever I go downtown my begs me to pass by here to get half a dozen steam buns/baked buns from this bakery. He's a big fan of the bbq pork ones, but sometimes requests the chicken steam buns. My dad also likes their rice cakes. This place is always busy, there's always a line, but it goes by quick. It's a little annoying about how they only accept cash! I wouldn't drive here because parking in this area is kinda difficult. On a funny note, there are huge pictures of Bill Clinton visiting the Eastern Bakery, it's pretty funny and cool at the same time! Prices are normal, which is cheap. Defiantly try it for a cheap Chinatown eat!
author: Diane S.

description:
stop # 1 on the steamed pork bun marathon. ranking: 1st of 6 places.

cost: $1.00. they live up to their claim of best pork bun in the city. the bun itself is great, not too sweet and not dry. the pork came in a delicious sauce, although it seems as though that might make it not as authentic as some of the other buns on our route. surprisingly, it was the most expensive bun we tried, but it was definitely worth it.
author: Monica C.

description: I have gone through 10 different bakeries in & around Chinatown... and when i stumbled into Eastern Bakery, I became an instant fan of their rice cakes & moon cakes. I buy them almost every month(MOOO!). When it comes to authentic, best tasting & best quality Chinese pastry, nothing can be better than what they sell there.
author: Jays D.

description: Came here with the in-laws.  Heard it was famous because former President Clinton visited here and has his picture up.  This place was happening!  People were in line for various items such as pow, sio pow, little pastries, mooncakes, etc.  I liked the pork and chicken sio pow.  The prices were decent as well, that we stacked up on sio pow, and pow.
author: Tony D.

description: This place is so old school /  retro, they also make huge donuts, they have everything here! they even make old fashion apple pies just like home made. Every bakery has a certain style, the stuff from this bakery has a unique old fashioned home made look.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Delicious pineapple bread and sesame seed ball. Prices were good and food tastes fresh. The sesame seed ball was still warm
author: Eric M.

description:
everything is cheap and delicious.

my favorite is the 60 cent steamed buns (black bean & lotus). yum. not in the case, but definitely worth asking for.


side note: the lady outside is always saying "freeeeeee sampuh", but never once have i actually received a sampuh. minus one star
author: natalie c.

description: Mmmmmmm pork steamed bun!!
author: Alyse A.

description: My best friend and I were craving a sweet snack but wanted to avoid Union Square. We decided to head to Chinatown and lo and behold Eastern bakery's sweet (pun intended) window  caught my eye. My friend wanted to try the Chinese tamales but I declined. I went for the moon cakes and the sesame balls. The sesame balls were damn good and not too greasy. I should have bought them in bulk because I would eat one and then kept going back for more. My friend had the butterfly cookie, which was just alright. But the really nice thing is they have so many options that you have to try a couple of different things. Plus they have tables in the back to hang out at and soak in the ambiance or watch tourists and locals get their fix. If you prefer hang out on the bench outside on Grant where you can people watch. Perfect place to take a breather from shopping or cruising the city. I will be back every weekend.
author: Gina c.

description: I have never tasted anything as good as their .50 cent pineapple bun....seriously.
author: Alicia W.

description: BBQ pork buns and moon cakes are good here.   Guess I'm single sourcing locations in SF Chinatown.  Oh, and of course, there's that pic of Clinton, which is kind a creepy.
author: Al V.

description: Bean filled cookies are really good here. The steamed cha siu bao and zongzi are pretty good too.
author: kirin r.

description: the buns weren't as heavenly as other reviews described.  very bunny, not enough meaty.  8T
author: Ethan L.

description: OMG....I live close by on Nob Hill. I walked into the kitchen area by mistake (screen door on Commercial St.)  Just walk down the stairs and look for yourself. I rest my case and my black bean buns!
author: Paul M.

description: Visited at 8:30 AM (opening time) on a Thursday in February.  Only one lady behind counter, no other customers.  The entire time, my mother kept tugging my sleeve and insisting it must be overpriced since it was in the "touristy" side of Chinatown.  Went in. Saw the President Clinton-was-here photos and the sign that said, "We've been here since 1924, BEFORE THE GREAT DEPRESSION, ..." Ordered two pork buns and 1 slice of the coffee cake. The woman behind the counter disappeared into the back.  As we waited in the empty store, a pigeon strolled in through the doorway, hopped up on some bags behind the counter, and began rooting around for crumbs, to our amusement.  Wondered a little at how clean it could be.  Woman came back with the buns, heated.  The buns were not glazed, and the pork filling was undyed and good.  Two buns and one slice of coffee toffee cake (which I thought was too sweet) was $5.00.  I wasn't impressed by either enough  to say they were SUPER good, but it was certainly good.  I later ate a pork bun at another dim sum shop along Stockton Street  where they were .90 each and found it inferior to the ones I had at Eastern Bakery.  I have yet to try Golden Bakery though.
author: Carol S.
